This is a game for anyone who like creativity. You mine ores, and use it to build ship block by block.

I find it enjoyable to design ship with different sizes, stack it with weapons and devices, then send it to battle.

There's a bit short coming when the game doesn't have a clear objective. Once you get more ore than your need, build the biggest ship that you wish, there no campaign or end game content aside from doing some contracts given by base station around the system. That unless you play with scenarios, mods, or someone organized servers. That's fine since this game is more of a sandbox than an open world RPG.

In term of mod, there's plenty in workshop for you to try. You can download new blocks, more game contents or other player's ship/station blueprints for your use. Although, the game kind of heavy in term of ram should you install too many mods or GPU should you have too many objects in one place.

Overall a nice space sim sandbox to play. Perhaps more fun if you have friend or a nice server.

I personally would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys a challenging sandbox game. Yeah, it's extremely difficult at times, but wow there are so many different ways to express your creativity. Also, DLC are a nuisance, but I feel they're worth it since we're able to support Keen as a developer. They sell their game for only $20. and thats not a ton of money for a growing company like Keen. I recommend if you're starting out, not to purchase the DLC, as you can upgrade to ultimate edition later, and that way you know you actually enjoy the game, and understand it.

The explanations given in this game are far too shallow for a game as intricate as this. The tutorials offered are all just in-game links that redirect you to YouTube where they have a SERIES of videos that are ~half hour in length.

That being said, it can be fun after persevering through the daunting beginnings. If you are a person who doesn't read the manual and wants to just figure stuff out, it can be rewarding to see your inventions work as intended after blowing up and revising them many times. I only recommend the game under the above condition, because this game will scare most people away with how complicated it seems.

It also has no defined objectives. You can start wherever you want and go wherever you want but the actual game that is presented here is basically "how am I going to do that?" All of the play is encapsulated in that key word, "how."

Easy construction of amazing space craft and rovers, mining rigs, mining ships and rovers.  Build bases, mining rigs, rovers of all sizes, mobile bases, space ships with collision and gravity effects, rotation components like hinges and rotors, and linear motion via pistons.  Jump to space and encounter space pirates and defend yourself.  Annoy them enough and they come after you continuously.  Or hijack trade ships.  Bored with the default eight planets and moons, there are dozens of player created planets to pick from.  Space pirates too easy and you want more combat there are dozens of player created NPC encounters to try out.  Want more types of corridors or other building blocks there are hundreds of player creations to try out.

nearly 2200 hrs in, i should probably review this game. honestly, everything to be said about this game can be said by @splitsie, and i would tend to agree. this game is awesome. for those that have zero idea about it, or are on the fence about it, just realize that this game brings to life your childhood building block creations, and then you get to fit them with guns and blow up other building block creations. from peaceful applications to the most sinister warfare motifs, the developer and the community continue to break limits in terms of imagination. in a fun/$ ratio, there's no better bang for your buck, in my opinion. play casual or hardcore, role play or mod to your heart's content, you're bound to find a play style that fits you.

Out of the box, a little boring past 50 hours, with mods... MY GOD. The limitation is your imagination (and the engine of course).

Want to build the Millennium Falcon? Sure!
Wanna build a Death Star? Do it.
Want to build an actual spinning Babylon 5 station? YOU BET!
Want to build the worst handling and least combat effective vessel you possibly can? Yep. You can.

I did it and I exploded immediately. and you know what, it was amazing.

I honestly cannot over state how much joy this title has brought me and I recommend it to absolutely any space survival builder fan. With the only caveat being;

You. NEED. Mods.
No questions, you do, don't think you do? your wrong. Space Engineer mods are what make Space Engineers, Space Engineers.

Partner?, nope! Space Engineer!
Crotch goblins? Ewww, just Space Engineer!
Pets? Feed them and then Space Engineer!

There are already high-quality reviews that do a great job of discussing the solid reasons of why you should not get Space Engineers, so I'm not making one myself, but making sure my input counts. Simple as that.

I know your looking for a a idea of my opinion, as well as the state of the game. Please see the reviews of, Snow, and TJ_Taz. They might not be the best in detail, but certainly are *Hopefully* the least in potential provoking reviews that still do a good explanation.
Here's some conveniently placed links to mentioned reviews:
Snow: https://steamcommunity.com/id/kibbewater/recommended/244850/
TJ_Taz : https://steamcommunity.com/id/TJ_Taz/recommended/244850/

I'd also like to add to some reviews just a little bit:
Snow: Individually any one DLC might not be too much, but if you elect not to buy them for *insert your own reason here* - having discovered some of the more darker secrets of Keen, in my case - you miss out big time. Though if you do own the game, by my experience, eventually your hand will be forced due to the heavy limitations of zero DLC bought. (Mods will mitigate what I describe to a extent, I mean, just look at the "hours at review time") 
Oh and one other thing, Keen's whole argument of "This content is not pay to win" is, for select packs, true, but with others.... (I'll let you investigate this on your own)
TJ_Taz: KSP is referring to Kerbal Space Program, specifically the first one and not the second.

I will end this review with a simple quote. "Space engineers: The best game you'll ever play, but also the worst." - TJ_Taz

[h1]Space Engineers was once a standout sandbox sci-fi builder, but it has long since collapsed under the weight of its own never-ending unethical content-paywalls.[/h1] Even if you are desperate to play this sort of game, it is NOT worth the price of the base game + all current AND future DLCS (nearly all of which contain uniquely-functional core content), even if you get them all on a steep sale. 

Keen's current approach to the game's ongoing development is as follows:
[b][i]"Here you go, take these lite-versions of my in-engine development tools and this handful of stock/free assets that I've cobbled loosely together with some spaghetti code, and knock yourselves out. That'll be $20 - oh, and you can expect regular $5 DLCs accompanying minor 'updates' half a dozen times a year, with each containing more low-effort content alongside increasingly-annoying limits to your gameplay options if you don't pay [strike]the ransom[/strike] up. [u]You're welcome![/u]"[/i][/b]

Yhe vast majority of Space Engineers' new official blocks and block variants—i.e. its creative opportunities—remain gated behind the cost of its current and future paid DLCs. 

[h1]"Strictly cosmetic DLCs," my space-blistered engineer's posterior.[/h1]

The shill echo chamber claiming that these DLCs are "optional"—meaning that their content has a strictly cosmetic impact on gameplay—have either genuinely never bothered to compare them to vanilla assets, don't actually play this game enough to have noticed the functional differences, or are just THAT level of moron. (Yeah, you know the tier I'm talking about!)

[h1]Don't support Keen's predatory monetization strategies.[/h1]


[hr][/hr]
I actually have nearly 800 hours played in this game all in all, and I'd love to be able to recommend it, but the vast majority of my time invested was pre-release - before Keen went apesh!t and ruined it by making us pay for every tiny little thing (and then started calling those "content updates"). As it is now, once you purchase the game you then need to spend an additional ~$70 (as of 2024) or so just to avoid missing out on CURRENT critical DLC functionality (i.e. blocks) with no substitute or alternative in the base game. A year from now, there'll be more to spend. Worse even than the simple fact of core features released as paid DLC, [b]many of these functional DLC blocks are ones that the community had been requesting for years in order to address major inconveniences, absences and/or outright bugs with the original block-set[/b]; those inconveniences, bugs, missing and broken features still exist in the base game - and if you want the quality of life fixes/patches for them, Keen wants you to pay for them. Want blocks with totally different connection/conveyor points? You get to pay for those, too. There are now many, many things—practical, sensible constructs that most creative people will think of eventually—that you just cannot build without those DLC blocks. 

Beyond being a shitty way for Keen to treat a community that has overwhelmingly supported them for such a long time, it's also completely unethical. 

But wait - there's more.

[u]Some of the content currently gated behind paid DLC was once native to the original game[/u]. Under the guise of "retiring" blocks, or removing them for "performance issues" or "more testing," many old blocks (most of which worked as well as anything else for years) are suddenly reappearing in DLCs - sometimes very minimally reskinned, but in many cases straight out of our old early access screenshots. [b][u]This is absolutely unacceptable![/u][/b]

IF you can get the base game AND all functional DLC for about $20 total on a steep sale, I'd say it's worth [b]considering[/b] it (especially now that SE's closest competitor, Empyrion, has been acquired/ruined by Funcom) - but keep in mind that whenever the next (significant) content patches drop, they'll ALWAYS be gated behind yet another paywall. As long as we keep paying, they'll keep doing it... so for the good of computer games everywhere, PLEASE don't encourage developers who take excessive advantage of their already-paying customer bases. Voice your concerns over their—and the industry's—recent shift toward anti-consumerism and unethical money-grubbing as a development ideology. 

Speak with your wallets, because money is the only language Keen cares about.

The biggest problem with this game is there is nothing to really do. You can make cool and amazing creations and stuff after that there is nothing to do. There is no real end game or challenges that you can apply to solve problems because in all reality  80 percent of creations address problems that are not there to be begin with.

Modders and scripters hold this boat together but sadly a lot of them are retiring or leaving. The developers have done nothing to address this issue besides some obscure social media posts talking about a new engine with actual water simulated. That is cool and all it does not address any of the issues of space engineers one. Even with modern hardware the game is not made to utilize it. There are a lot of performance issues still and while it was not as bad as it was 2013 its still there. Also the bugs like driving along in your rover and you hit a small bump and it sends your rover flying into sky only to land losing a bunch of shit. 

After visiting this with friends this game is just a glorified tech demo still after all these years. Even with the updates sure but at the end of the day once your done with your personal goals you realize that there is nothing but a dull and empty sandbox. Keen has had all this time and barely done much with it. In a sad sense it was to be expected like they did with Medieval Engineers. 

Actually given this studio history I am not surprised. They made a game that a lot of potential but they have wasted it. They let the community hold the fort and sat back making cosmetic DLC and barely fixing long standing issues that have plagued this game since its inception. To be expected since they abandon Medieval Engineers and still charge but have the community make the game  instead when they released dev tools. 

I would be surprised if they actually go all in for a space engineers 2 game but I high doubt given there history. Space Engineers 2 or any sequel if there is one will be one of low effort. Probably be the same dev cycle as this one. Take a every long time to fix things and add things into it. Make a lot cosmetic DLC and modders hold the fort. Still not have any challenges for you to overcome with no end game goal in mind.

It's all fun and games until the physics decides it is a good day to fling you across the planet.

Jokes aside, this game is actually WAY more enjoyable than I originally anticipated. It has a steep learning curve, sure, but after a few YT tutorials and lots of experimentation, the game easily becomes one of the best survival games out there. Also, this game is great with friends, whether you are exploring, or just doing some good old PvP.

Convoluted.  
The interface and workstations are unclear for refinement and assembly.
I suspect that with MANY hours, I could muck through the game's intentions and learn how to do things.
I do see the community is very helpful, and super supportive of new players.  That gave me hope!

However, even with nice people around, a game should not feel like working a second job with mandatory study hall and research time on the weekends.

This is just a sandbox style builder game with some physics.
Speaking of physics, flight controls and navigation are also not intuitive, and less than responsive.
Again, just a very sloppy game.  Not fun, hard to learn, goes no where.  
My leisure time was more like frustration.
If what you like to do in your free time is get frustrated by non-intuitive games while friendly people tell you it just takes time and cheer you on in social media?  Give this a try.

Whatever your preference, I highly recommend watching some gameplay content on Yewt Oob to see some of the cool vehicles the community has built!  It shows you the 'end game' perspective, which helped inform my decision to NOT dedicate much time into learning this game.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

So many newbie traps it makes me want to refund it, but by the time I got that mad I'd already played well over 2 hours. If you do buy it, do so to play with friends to teach you the ropes. If you are going in solo do yourself a favor, don't select the first scenario for your first game unless you like having "access denied" spammed at you every time you try to do something, effectively trapping you in the first room because presumably you don't know how to hack doors because you just started playing. First Jump for a tutorial on basic stuff but you still might want a guide on how to actually build things or to tool around in creative mode.

Do a custom game. Turn off progression unless you want to build a bunch things then grind them down just to farm up 'research'. You can't change game settings on a saved game unless it is creative mode, be aware of this. Save frequently, save so many back ups, do not try to ironman it. I built a lot without saving, 95% built my first vehicle that I fussed over for about an hour and a half, then when I left to go check something out it disappeared. There's a trash cleaning system that will do this if it is unpowered or whatever, you can change that in the admin settings, I haven't gotten around to trying it out because I just lost several hours of progress reloading my last save hoping that at least some of my admitted overly ambitious first vehicle would still be there and am sick of this.

I'll probably delete this review later when I try again FROM SCRATCH but I am so blindingly mad at the moment.

I bought the game, started my first survival world, gathered resources and built the start of my first base. the time came to build my first rover. built one, had wheel suspension wrong and had to scrap the whole thing to fix it. built a second one, and the wheels where unresponsive. watched four youtube tutorials on how to build a rover. built rover number 3. still had issues with wheels and vehicle configuration. got a friend with over 50 hours in the game to help and take a look. he got some stuff working and again i built it wrong, so i scrapped it an started over. with my knew knowledge on how to properly configure the car, i built it and set it up. however I once again must have done something wrong because i started to configure the settings and all the wheels turned left and wont respond. 
I have no idea what I'm doing wrong and all the googling and youtube tutorials Ive tried aren't helping solve my issue. 
if i cant figure out how to build a rover with the help of multiple tutorials and googling and in game research as much as possible, then there is a problem with the game. great concept, poor execution. I give up.

Decent creative threshold. Has plenty of physics related content, oddities and block manipulation. 
Space travel? Oh my goodness. It took days on Xbox for me to not have anxiety and panic attacks floating in space. Hahaha, so sad.

I do have some issues I would like to bring forward, followed by some interesting ideas for new ingame content.

ISSUES :

Server lag : The monotonous building of large structures and massive ships is great except when players PC's have to communicate with servers, the information isn't always saved and bits and pieces of built structures vanish into thin air as if not built. Generally an issue when there is packet loss between player and server... You need to find a way to balance the communication... maybe decrease packet size to just binary information, orrr.... have players builds store data into packets that get sent to the server every 30 seconds to 20 minutes depending on server host options/choices.

Thrust Power : It is hard to determine exact thrust needed for leaving planetary surfaces to orbit and space. Each player should have a Calculator that is built in game that allows them to input block count, power source and weight and have the calculator display exactly which thrusters are needed for each type of use. It would be really cool to add a feature that allows players to have access to Engineering tables. Tables that allow defining timing, autonomy of thrusters and guns, shields and refills from a single spot (the way its currently displayed is just too much in such a small space).

Wolves : Great to add an NPC that is "natural" to earth like Planet, but they are really over powered. When you start earthside and you land near wolves, you have 0 hope of survival. the couple clips of ammo and pistol will kill 1 maybe 2 of the 5 wolves that attack you. An endless cycle of needless death.

Cave systems : They dont exist, which is strange because theyre more common in reality than the ores that exist... Kind of a bummer really.

Exploration : There is little to none. I mean that literally. The surfaces of all planets don't have anything worth exploring. There is no ancient buildings, crypts, crumbling civilizations... notta.

Escape Pods : For some strange reason they don't exist, even though in real space travel in the future escape pods will be a crucial element to survival and is on every ship in space.

Gravitational Fields and Stationary Objects : All planets and most objects with mass in space have a field of gravity. If you go to space, asteroids aren't stationary, not in the least. All things with mass attract smaller objects with smaller masses. I don't know the science behind it but its true.

Turning Asteroids into Moveable crafts : Yes this is an odd thing to point out... one that won't make much sense until you finish reading this. If an object in space is given thrust, even the tiniest amount, the object can be moved. I should be able to encase an asteroid 50% with blocks and throw thrusters onto it and move the asteroid where I want it.

Gear : For all the things that can be built, why can I not make my own gear? All the required things are already available, except for dyes...

Food : The good ole sustenance angle. YOU CAN NOT SURVIVE ANYTHING WITHOUT WATER AND FOOD.... a seriously crucial element left out of the game.

NPC's : The worst of the worst. They are over powered right away when they should be matching the players threat level and power.... They shouldnt have drone ships if I dont have one... Makes the game a little unbalanced.


Now for Ideas :

Ideas

Food
Crafting station that allows new suits to be built
Hydro dependencies for sustenance
Fire - for damage and for lighting sources and cooking
Floods
Extreme Weather Patterns or Extreme Storms
Alien life - come on you don't seriously believe humans are the only intelligence?
Warp Drives - DO NOT EXIST AND SHOULD NOT BE IN THIS GAME
Animals - not a lot just a few to bring more color, life and depth to survival

This game is simply a space-based sandbox created by Keen Software House and I have been playing this on and off for quite a few years now. You can traverse planets and asteroids, mining wherever you go and building new ships along the way, experimenting with the technicalities of a ship (the inner workings).

Whilst I am by no means someone who has been as enthusiastic as the others from the get-go for this game and as a result haven't really necessarily played for long periods of time at once compared to others who play this, unfortunately by this point I can no longer really truly recommend this game to newcomers.

 Let me explain.

This game has been, for a surprising number of years, been on early access and has just recently within the last few years "released". This, in my mind is completely false as the game has multiple glaring flaws that shouldn't even exist for a released game.

First, the bugs.  Holy moly the bugs. I have multiple times, on occasion, locked myself inside a planet as a result of continuously voxel mining and end up inadvertently glitching myself through the terrain, preventing me from ever getting my stuff back (unless I want to mine the entire planet out). Pistons are often very glitchy and are at times unstable despite being probably one of the most important blocks in the game. They can cause builds to explode for little to no reason with sometimes no warning whatsoever (the only time you CAN tell is when they are behaving extremely erratic). I have also had issues with connectors causing buggy things to happen, specifically ships being rubberbanded back to them, at times even if they are seemingly miles away. Other times, with pressurizing rooms. Despite having situations where a room is fully repaired and sealed with blocks that don't have gaps as well as having sufficient oxygen in tanks as needed, vents will simply refuse to pressurize rooms with said oxygen for no apparent reason. I have tried several times to relog into a server or singleplayer world that had this issue and even tried grinding the vent block down and then replacing it yet (even putting it into a different area in the room) but it almost never worked to fix it.

These bugs have been reported to Keen through the support forums for years but every time they do get reports on the forums (which they get a lot of), they are disregarded/ignored pretty much completely and the original reports receiving replies from countless users have employees that seem to not even try to even solve the issue whatsoever as they continuously ask for information on the bug report stating they "aren't able to reproduce the issue" despite countless accounts from other players and multiple videos and world files clearly showing how to replicate the bugs and to this day are still left unresolved. Here is just one example: https://support.keenswh.com/spaceengineers/pc/topic/ship-rubber-bands-back-to-groundconnector

Secondly, the combat system. The combat system has been nearly nonexistent since the early access up until recently with the Warfare II update. They have for years, only have added a missile turret and gatling gun for use on ships. That's it. With the Warfare II update they added barely any more weaponry blocks than before and are nothing special (just a few minicannons and a railgun). If I recall correctly, there are less than 10 weaponry blocks to choose from unless you want to account for weapons created that abuses exploits created by the instability of pistons and other niche use cases such as using reactors as bombs. Personally speaking, if not for the modding community that has gone through so much effort to help the game blossom in its own terms, I find it highly unlikely the playerbase would be as large as it is right now. If you're able to without buying the game first, just take a look at the amount of mod support for weaponry for the game. Virtually pretty much half of the content is dedicated solely specifically for combat.

Lastly but not least, the diversity of things to do in the game. Unfortunately this is probably where the game fails the most in. The only real challenge the game presents you with when playing survival worlds/servers is landing on top of a planet, building a base and rocket through a large amount of effort and seemingly countless hours spent and then launching said rocket into space. Past this point, there is basically almost nothing to do besides mining asteroids or attempting to find a trading station to buy things (particularly zone chips for a safezone for your base) or raiding a pirate space station which are extremely hard to find. The only other raiding options are planetary installations which are more common, however severely lack in giving the player any real challenge and more often than not I have raced at them with just a hand grinder and multiple respawns, no ship needed. Past that, they don't even give much of a respectable amount of loot inside as the buildings are often quite small in size and lack much of a defense. The same can be said for pirate drones that spawn from space stations. They usually either have grinders or gatling guns to defend themselves and can spawn in packs but respawning with nothing but a grinder in hand and racing at them before they can kill you themselves is enough to defeat them if you know how to strafe enough with your jetpack. This makes arming a ship in the game basically completely pointless besides maybe killing annoying stragglers and completing escort missions from trade stations (which is probably the only actual challenge you will be getting when you launch a ship to space).  Everything interesting is few and far between and the only thing that actually saturates the whole area is asteroids. This is part of the reason why both players and ships are limited to in-game speeds below 125/ms. The only option to go any further is to use jump drives but the game forces you to go to a different planet/moon if you want to obtain the additional resources necessary to build one which doesn't make a whole lot of sense. Either that or you start on earth-likes moon and you get all of the resources needed, however it defeats the whole purpose of having other planets as an option to start on. The only real way to bypass these limitations or to just try to stay interested in the game enough to continue playing past this point is adding mods that add more content that just isn't really there to begin with such as Modular Encounters (an NPC related mod).

People often praise this game stating that things are working as intended, that waiting a bit for  monthly content that adds barely anything of notice is better than no game at all, excusing game-breaking bugs that have been ignored for years by Keen without being fixed whatsoever and defending the fact that half the content is locked behind a paywall. People often state that buying DLC for "only a coffee cup's worth" is fine and merely refusing to pay it means being a cheapskate but that statement simply does not hold water if said DLC adds up to cost about the same as an entirely new game.

If it's merely a sandbox game where you want to build in to your hearts content and simply nothing else, this game may be just what you want. But for those wishing for a survival experience, that of which many do indeed play, it disappointingly fails to meet expectations. 

I am almost certainly convinced that the majority of the community still playing this game are simply denying any of the flaws of this game, refusing to voice valid criticism that Keen seems so unwilling to listen to, because they are afraid of losing the possibility for the game to be actually finished from development one day when it has such an alluring and seemingly polished concept at first glance, fearing that it may end up as abandonware just like Medieval Engineers and Miner Wars 2081 did.

In short, do not buy this.

I have played this game for over 3000 hours in 5 years. I have every DLC (aka we need money here are some cool block skins for 5 bucks, not really complaining I get it, SE 2 just better blow my mind). Do I like this game? Yes, and no... For the entirety of owning this game I have had a love hate relationship with it. The base game for what it is, is amazing, I personally have not found a better sandbox creative building physics game. If you like to build and problem solve it will engage you for hours however I have found that the base game lacks the engaging features it needs to keep it interesting. There are hardly any enemies and most of the time you must seek them out. The only real reason to go to space is for uranium, the planets all have the same ores to offer. There are space stations that offer random tasks to do like bringing them resources or escorting a transport etc. Other than that there's no real sense of adventure or danger. Thankfully there is a vast community of people much smarter than myself that create mods to make the game more enjoyable, although using too many or the wrong ones will significantly hinder your FPS. All things considered though, if you like space exploration and building I would highly recommend this game. 

If Keen reads this:
Your game has kept me entertained for hours, but as you read above it needs some work, and seeing comments on your updates I'm not the only one who thinks this. I stay up to date of on everything I can about SE 2, water is a great step it the right direction and the physics look like a lot of fun. I don;t know your plans but I would recommend a more engaging survival mode with more to do, fight and find. Also If it were a toggle or just part of the game I think atmospheric drag for planes and helicopters would be a hit and add a new challenge to flying in the new game. 
Thank you for everything you do and keep up the good work!

Space Engineers is a 100% sandbox game. There is no story. The only objectives you receive are ones you make yourself.

As a side note, yes, many of these issues can be fixed with mods. However, mods have a tendency to have unintended conflicts and are sometimes not updated alongside the current version of the game. 

Positives
Building can be fun, albeit somewhat restrictive. The voxel-based game play means that building larger and larger ships becomes infeasible quickly (thanks square-cube law). Most ships you can reasonably build cap out at 200 meters in length, any longer and they begin having a significant impact on performance. You aren’t going to find any massive capital ships that are several kilometres in length.

Creative mode is a blast. There are thousands of ships on the workshop you can import, play around with, and pit against each other. I spent dozens of hours and many quiet afternoons building ships of my own and watching them fight it out against player-uploaded workshop creations.

Negatives
The survival mode falls somewhat flat. There are minimal survival mechanics. The most enjoyable part of survival is the planetary game play. Resources are limited and you need to build vehicles and bases if you eventually want to build a rocket to leave the planet. Once you venture into space, the game becomes much less interesting. Mining in space equates to flying to an asteroid, drilling, and flying back. After a few hours you resource power-creep so hard that there is very little challenge. There is also very little reason to explore the solar system, as you’ll find more resources than you could even use from visiting your first few asteroids.

Neutral Comments
Spaceship gameplay is all about inertia. There’s no magical sci-fi ship drive that makes the ship move. Your only method of propulsion is thrusters, and you will need to build thrusters on all six sides of your ship in order to move in a controllable manner.

There is a 100 meters-per-second cap on movement in-game. It makes travel waaay too slow in what’s supposed to be a space sandbox. I understand why they did it from a game development/balancing standpoint, but it still feels way too slow. I know there are mods that increase or remove the limit, but those also come with problems of their own.

Enemy AI is mostly dissapointing. Wolves & Spiders, the only hostile planetary mobs, are actually disabled by default in survival mode because for the most part, they are just not fun. Enemy ship AIs usually just fly directly at you, or try to orbit you at a distance. 

In conclusion
It’s a great space-themed Sandbox. It doesn’t have the staying power of Minecraft or Terraria, but it’s a fun experience for people who want to be, well, Space Engineers.

I really liked some parts of the game. The game-ending event occurred when I started a building project and went off to do something else for a while. Don't feel like looking up everything that's required) your thing gets deleted as garbage. I had played too long in the new area to restore the station with a backup save. I think the game has been around too long to have such a severe issue. So, that was the end for me.

With that being said: I like this game to a POINT. That point is where the game forces me to Trick it into working. I loath the Small Grid/Large Grid system incompatibility. I loath the "Sub-Grid" "Clang" wonkiness. Most of the blocks are already too damn big (A small grid block takes up a 1/2 of a meter cubed, and so does a 1cm. thick plate, but has the armor integrity of a cardboard box) no matter what I build it's 3x larger than it needs to be. But even worse is to have a "Large Grid" component be the same size as a "Small Grid" but I can't put it on a Small Grid ship is asinine. i.e. I can't put "Large Grid" Refineries or Assemblers, or Med Bay, or etc. etc. on a "Small Grid" ship unless I do some wonky crap to trick them into working.

I'm changing my review to negative as I do not appreciate the size of these blocks for the integrity they provide, and can only hope that SE 2 rejects the Large/Small Grid crap and just lets us build.

If not, I'm done. Time to move on.

February 2024: This game still stands out as exceptional in the space sandbox genre.  Still looks nice, performs better, and has an active multiplayer community.  I'm really looking forward to the possibilities in SE2 which is supposedly somewhere in the development pipeline!

July 2016: Still my favorite game ever.  We're in beta now, there is a stable branch, and we have planets and dx11!  Things have come a long way and still promise to get better!  Worth 10 times the price.

March 2015: An adult form of minecraft in space that is waaay better.  While a little buggy and in Alpha, the game improves each and every Thursday.  As a fan of strategy and sandbox games, THIS IS MY FAVORITE GAME EVER.

God its kinda hard to write this review, not really but still...

Space Engineers? where do I start.. SE is the type of game I play on a religious schedule so much so that Ive bought friends the game in hopes I can draft more onto my crew.

Where does the game shine? Free build, allowing the player to build what ever the F they want is a game changer. Want to make the all spark (giant cube) fly through an atmosphere or space? you can do it! Want to make an exact replica of the death star or a x-wing? you can DO IT!

Do you like survival? The survival is basic but brutal and the game does not hold your hand at all. Want a harder challenge? try scenarios or even go for mods to make survival harder.

Do you like no limits creative? Creative is exactly what you think. Like minecraft, creative allows you to build what ever you want and in any size without the need to grind.

The game also has an economy and a in game currency (not micro-transactions) you can trade all types of materials and even sell your ships or buy pre-built ships.

Now honestly what do I give this game? with 1282.7 hours on record on the time of this reviews I give it a 8.5/10 the reason being is because the game lacks a proper end game or "reasoning" to continue past getting to space, even the whole purpose of using the economy system in a private world or server is pointless. Furthermore the purpose to get into PVP is also purposeless as it provides no real incentive to do so.

Honestly I will still play this game and I don't recommend this game to anyone as it gets boring, this is my opinion and thoughts. Best of luck Keen.

Ever heard of Space Engineers? Oh, you haven't? Well, allow me to introduce you to the game that single-handedly turned my thriving social life into a cosmic black hole.

Before Space Engineers, I used to see the sun, you know, that big bright thing in the sky. Now, my primary source of light is the soft glow of my computer screen as I meticulously engineer my way through the cold, unforgiving vacuum of space. Who needs vitamin D when you have the satisfaction of perfectly aligning your virtual space station's solar panels?

And let's talk about sleep. Remember sleep? That thing you do at night? Yeah, that's been replaced with just "one more block" or "just until I fix this thruster." My dreams are no longer about flying or showing up to work naked. Now, they're about mining asteroids and dodging space pirates. I wake up clutching my pillow, thinking it's a rare ore I've just excavated.

Social life? Oh, it's thriving... if by thriving, you mean me yelling at my computer screen because my virtual spaceship just got obliterated by a meteor. My friends used to call to ask if I wanted to hang out. Now, they just send search parties.

My diet? It's been revolutionized! Meals are now optimized for efficiency. Who has time for cooking when there's a space empire to build? I've mastered the art of one-handed snacking, leaving my other hand free to navigate through asteroid fields.

In conclusion, Space Engineers hasn't just taken over my life; it has expanded and upgraded it with premium modules. Who needs a real job when you've got a thriving economy of space credits? So, if you're thinking about getting the game, just remember: you might start by building a small spaceship, but the game ends up building a universe around you. A universe where time, social life, and basic human necessities become as distant as the farthest star. 10/10, would forget to exist in the real world again.

Is the game any good? Well, this will take a bit longer to answer... I'll come back to that.
Do I enjoy it and would I recommend it? Here the answers are yes and it depends what you like to do.

To put it into a nutshell, basically Space Engineers is Minecraft in Space, but you can actually build complex objects that can move on their own.

You start either in a small drop pod tumbling down to a planet's or moon's surface or you begin in a small ship in space.

I will be honest with you: What now awaits you is a very steep learning curve and a lot of grind until you have come far enough to improve your ways of getting and refining resources.

You try your best to acquire stone, iron, silicon and a few other minerals, out of which you can craft a handful of components, which you finally use for creating blocks. The latter come in two sizes, small and large. From these blocks you build everything you can imagine. Stations, both on planets and in space, ships, freighters, etc...

Fights are quite okay, but since it takes quite a while to whack even a small ship together, hours of work can blow up in an instant. Fortunately the game lets you choose quite nicely how you want to play it, so you can choose to build your bases quite peacefully with no or little interference.

I personally enjoy building production facilities, ships, rovers and other contraptions very much, and that is what I really recommend the game for. With the last updates came a big improvement on survival and economy, yet still there a a lot of things to complain about:

Multiplayer sometimes gets quite laggy and your movement can feel as if you are playing in a bowl of pudding, especially when the server performance is a bit under stress. 
Update 01-2024: Performance has been optimized, though can still be a bit janky if the server gets stressed, but overall way better than when I wrote this review initially

Physics get really weird, if you use a lot of rotors and pistons and the last two hours of construction can easily be blown away by the moods of almighty Clang, especially when you are still very unexperienced with the various quirks.
Update 01-2024: Clang has been tamed a lot in the meantime

Also it is quite annoying that even though armor blocks come in a lot of shapes, some particular shaped blocks are still missing, so you end up with some nasty holes or dents in your design, because the block needed for a smooth fit simply doesn't exist. 
Update 01-2024: Meanwhile a couple of new block shapes have been added, so this problem is way lesser now

However that hasn't prevented players from finding their way around and building awesome constructs (which you can also download from the workshop and add into your game).

A big surplus is that the game has a lot of mods and scripts in the workshop, so you can adapt the game pretty much to whatever you want it to be. Playing together with a couple of fellow other engineers in multiplayer is also a great experience (aside from mentioned performance issues).
Speaking of scripts, if you know C# (or willing to learn it), the game allows you to write your own scripts, be it for providing better information on what is going on with your builds, adding new ways of control or automating the sh*t out of the game (so you don't have to do the resource gathering grind any more, for example).

If you love planning and building any contraptions, this game is very much recommendable and very great. If you love to dig into a game to find out and tinker with it's possibillities, you'll find a lot of challenge here.

However, if you expect a lot of story, want to be taken by the hand and don't want to invest a lot of time into building, you probably better look somewhere else, as the game won't provide you with plenty of that.
Even though it has some survival and economy elements, the most part of the game still feels more like a big sandbox. 

That doesn't have to be necessarily bad, but that means that you have to give sense to the game by what you want to do in it.

I'm surprised how bad this game really is, despite many good things it has. 

The performance is very good. The explosions in space are cool and cinematic. Ship weapons and other stuff are dynamic, and leave other games in the genre (looking at you, Empyrion), far behind. There are factions that feel alive. I've been actively hounded by ships and it feels like in a middle of a war. Some cool vistas, graphics are nice, and ability to just land on planets is amazing.

But that alone doesn't make a good or an enjoyable game. The most fun I had was watching other factions lose ships in hilarious ways. Mining? Wasn't able to do any mining. All ships I flew were immediately attacked and shot down by a faction that apparently wasn't yet even hostile. You will get attacked, but you will not avoid getting attacked, as you see now map, no overall layout of anything. The only thing you see is space and some tagged points. That's it. Scanning for enemies? Mapping territory? I don''t even know how many planets are there in this solar system. Does the game has a galaxy? Many planets? How can I know?

How can you not implement any map or layout is beyond me. Which areas to avoid? I don't know. Where are planets? I have no idea. If my friend with whom I played didn't tell me about factions, I would have zero knowledge about the world and its layout.  Everything seemed to happen randomly. A ship appears and shoots things around me while the tutorial bot tells me that I'm hurt for the 100th time. You either treat the player like a hardcore veteran or like a newborn baby, not simultaneously. If I didn't get resources from wrecks and ships from my friend, buying for space credits, I would have exactly zero progress.

And then you have the most horrible UI I have ever seen, which was designed this way only to sell you overpriced and greedy DLCs. Yes, the only reason I am being shown 300+ blocks to pick from when moving things into my toolbar is to promote the DLC blocks which you cannot have until you buy.

How can you sell so many DLCs with singular reskinned blocks for such an unpolished mess that lacks the most basic functionalities is astounding.
Boring. Nothing to do.

But it does have a lot of systems to adapt to, and for that I recommend using the scenarios to learn. It's not perfect but it helps out. The internet has been very useful for me personally.

Space Engineers is an exceptional game that seamlessly combines creativity, engineering, and exploration to deliver an unparalleled gaming experience. Developed by Keen Software House, this sandbox game allows players to unleash their imagination and build awe-inspiring structures in the vastness of space.

One of the standout features of Space Engineers is its robust and realistic physics engine. The game accurately simulates gravity, inertia, and the challenges of space travel, adding a layer of authenticity that sets it apart from other sandbox titles. Whether you're constructing a massive space station or a nimble spacecraft, the physics system ensures that every creation behaves as expected, enhancing the overall immersion.

The game's building mechanics are a true highlight, offering an extensive array of blocks and tools for players to utilize. From intricate spacecraft designs to elaborate space bases, the creative possibilities seem limitless. The intuitive building interface and the ability to manipulate every block with precision contribute to a satisfying building experience.

Space Engineers also excels in its multiplayer mode, allowing players to collaborate on massive projects or engage in epic space battles. The seamless transition between solo and multiplayer modes ensures a dynamic and engaging gameplay experience, fostering a sense of community among players exploring the cosmos together.

The graphics and visual effects in Space Engineers are stunning, capturing the beauty and vastness of outer space. The attention to detail in the environments, from distant galaxies to the reflective surfaces of spacecraft, adds a level of visual polish that enhances the overall gaming experience.

Moreover, the game's regular updates and commitment to community feedback demonstrate a dedication to improvement and innovation. The developers actively engage with the player base, introducing new features, fixing bugs, and refining gameplay mechanics based on user suggestions.

In conclusion, Space Engineers is a masterpiece that successfully blends creativity, physics, and multiplayer elements into an unforgettable gaming experience. Whether you're a space enthusiast, an aspiring engineer, or simply someone looking for an immersive sandbox adventure, Space Engineers offers a captivating journey into the cosmos. With its realistic physics, expansive building options, and thriving multiplayer community, it stands as a testament to the potential of sandbox gaming done right.

I bought the game ages ago, and while it was great for what it was, a few things have started to concern me.

First of all, this game (and Medieval Engineers) is based upon a very large and complex custom engine built on Microsoft Dot.NET. While this means it will run decently well on a well-specc'd Windows box, when you start doing things like trying to run this on a Steam Deck or a Linux PC through the Proton compatibility layer, things get unstable rather quickly. I seem to remember being able to play this game with full audio capabilities (albeit with some "crackling" as reported by others on ProtonDB), but nowadays I don't get any audio at all. At first I thought this was because of a mod I had loaded, but it turns out, even in vanilla, no matter what version or flavor of Proton I tried, I could not get a peep out of the game. The game also runs quite hot on my Deck, and I run into fan-roaring freezes where I have to force restart the hardware on a regular basis. This is a game from 2013. For comparison, an equally resource-intensive PC game, Starcraft II, was released in roughly the same time frame, but it runs smoothly on my Deck with few issues, as do many other titles including Minecraft which can easily turn a PC into a screaming turbine if you let it. Sure, SE is doing a ton of calculations in its simulation (but then, so does KSP), Dot.NET is certainly showing its age, and it would be a gargantuan effort to port the code to a more optimal framework... but still, it's frustrating to see a 10-year-old game struggle like this.

It's not all bad news. The physics engine, lovingly dubbed "CLANG" by players, can be an endless source of entertainment and while it can be a source of ridiculously funny exploits (CLANG drives, anyone?), it adds quite a character to the game. The detail of the blocks, the huge mod community, and the ability to come up with your own ship, station, and contraption designs to build bigger and bigger things until your PC turns into a glowing pool of molten silicon, all make this easily one of my favorite games.

And yet, the fact that Dot.NET seems to despise Proton is concerning, because it means I would need to build or buy a fairly powerful Windows machine just to play this game. And the direction Microsoft is heading reminds me of why previous executives called Linux a "virus" or a "cancer", and I fear that will only diverge with Valve's path forward, which is more compatibility, more inclusion of systems like Linux, and down the line, likely more efficient hardware like ARM or RISC-V. It's difficult for me to imagine a scenario where SE will play well on Steam hardware going forward.

But, with the advances Valve and the Proton maintainers have made, I could be proven wrong. Maybe this freewheeling beast of a game will become yet another success story, not only running smoothly but without cooking the hardware. So I recommend Deck players hold off unless they like to tinker in Desktop mode and don't mind the instability, or if Proton has a breakthrough that significantly improves the performace of Dot.NET based games.

Tons of fun, tons of things to do, fairly easy to learn the basics, good community, fun decorative DLCs that help the developers, this game has it all. If you like Satisfactory, (and Factorio I've been told) but wish they had more action and content, then this game is for you. You want to shoot a huge railgun at a warship from 500 kilometres away? You can do that. You want to explore the solar system while trying to survive? You can do that. You want to see what happens if you warp inside another ship? You can do that. This game is a sandbox crafting game where you can survive, go into creative more, do campaigns, and more! I recommend doing the "Learning to Survive" scenario first, to learn the basics, then, if you want, you can jump into the "First Jump" scenario, which is a fun and engaging campaign, but alas is pretty short. If you are doing survival mode, then I recommend the "Star System" scenario, and make sure to pick Mars (It is selected by default). Play this game, I guarantee you'll love it, especially with friends!

Many dedicated server admins have given up because they are so frustrated as there's no support with fixing these horrible server bugs.   I would love to give this a thumbs up (and maybe I will in a year or two when it's worth playing).  I have to say, even though the game in multiplayer crashes constantly, it lags when it isn't crashing, released patches don't address anything important to stability, I still managed to log in all the time. In the mean time,  you may want to play another game unless you don't plan on playing in multiplayer at all. If you want multiplayer, do NOT buy this game yet.  Wait until you read it's much better in that area.

Games actually amazing, so ima give some tips for starting the game out. 1. if your just starting, you might want to spawn on earth so you get the hang of it, later when you understand the mechanics more, you can go to mars or even space to have more challenges. 2. When your in space starting off, your #1 PRIORITY is finding ice, cobalt, and maybe silver. 3. Don't get too fancy with builds, just protect them enough to where collisions with stuff do minor damage. 4. if your building a big shuttle and two parts of your ship are connected by something like a large container or hydrogen tank, PLEASE reinforce it, I've learned the hard way. And finally, #5 is have good sportsmanship in multiplayer. There are people bigger then both you and me combined that will find you and everyone you love if you do something wrong, so i beg of you, PICK YOUR BATTLES.

[h2] Evolution of Space Engineers [/h2]
Space Engineers has undergone a remarkable evolution over the years, transitioning from its initial state to a game that is undeniably worth experiencing. The developers have been unwavering in their dedication to continuously update and enrich the game with new content, making it an increasingly enjoyable experience for players.

[h3] Building and Physics Mechanics [/h3]
One of the game's standout features is its exceptional building and physics mechanics, setting it apart within its genre. Space Engineers skillfully balances realism and enjoyment, offering players an immersive experience that remains engaging and entertaining. Although the mechanics of building machines, ships, and bases may initially present a learning curve, the game has notably become more accessible over time. Ample in-game tutorials and a vibrant community of dedicated YouTubers are available to guide and support players in mastering these mechanics.

[h3] Role of Steam Workshop Integration [/h3]
The integration of Steam Workshop into Space Engineers has played a pivotal role in keeping the game thriving. This integration has allowed players to leverage mods, thereby injecting fresh content and innovative ideas into the game. Furthermore, the collaborative partnership between the developers and mod authors has been instrumental in enhancing the game's longevity and appeal. Notably, the game has embraced the input from mod authors, resulting in the creation of new features and updates that align with the community's preferences.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
Overall, Space Engineers has undergone a remarkable transformation, emerging as a game that stands as a testament to the power of continual improvement and collaborative engagement. The seamless blend of realistic building and physics mechanics, combined with the enriching support from the community and the integration of mods, makes Space Engineers an indispensable gem in the gaming landscape.

Absolutely fantastic space game, you'll be busy for hours, even if it's just singleplayer.
Far from a space "simulator", so to speak, it's definitely more focused on the engineering aspect and if you so choose, the survival aspect of travelling through deep space. Now, I consider myself a "space game/sim connoisseur", I've played many of the greats, KSP, this, Evochron Mercenary and Legacy,  X3 etc, so I like to think I know what makes a space game good, objectively speaking. This game has most of the features that I consider essential in a game about space and space travel. Room pressurisation, asteroid mining, plausible thrusters (not just super alien warp 9000), and a good, mostly robust physics engine. The only things it's missing, really, are good orbital mechanics, and better planets. The planets leave a lot to be desired, frankly. They have an atmosphere, they have some trees and mountains and some surface bases and ships (more with mods), but without orbital mechanics or any form of atmospheric re-entry, they do feel just like painted voxel asteroids with a cloud layer and breathability. I'm not making a dig at KSH however, they're a great dev team who take their time because they care about what they're making. Awesome customer service too, hit them up on Insta @KeenSoftwareHouse, always friendly n reply. 
Side note: I usually abhor the building mechanics of voxel based games, typically clunky and unintuitive, I also, upon purchase worried this game would be the same. It's really not. Building might take a tad longer than say, Minecraft, but you won't be left scratching your head because you can't align something or a block doesn't go where you want it. Good job KSH.

Buy this if you're looking for: A fun, spacecraft building and deep space exploration game, great on your own but better with multiple players, with semi-deep mechanics, a decent economy/trading/contracts system and a rather great building system. 

Maybe miss this one if you're looking for: A fully realistic, fleshed out space simulator or survival game. This is not and I doubt it ever will be Elite: Dangerous. I would recommend ED if it wasn't always-online, so instead I'd say go for the very similar Evochron Legacy, or even X3 if you're after a space sim. Orbiter 2016 is also good for real-world crafts. Give Space Engine a look too if you love exploring the universe like myself. 

Definitely avoid this if you're looking for: A casual arcadey space shoot-em-up, some form of RPG or in depth space combat sim. RP might not be my cup of tea, but it's definitely possible in this game, although there are little to none RPG elements such as progression, although the research tree could possibly count.

TL;DR It's fucking great and KSH deserve the money for it, frankly. I may be a tad biased towards games of the space persuasion, but even objectively from a non cosmonaut background, it's a fun game and I'm sure you'll enjoy it. Just, make sure the devs don't abandon it. The slightest hint of abandonment and we crusade, alright? Lmao.

Nah, this game is freaking dead, I was trying to hope for good and even bought most dlc to "support" devs, but they are just too greedy and lazy. 
Game literally had interplanetary potential, but devs have been sitting in the same puddle for years releasing workshop deco content for money. Shame. Keen, please go bankrupt already.

It still feels like the buggy early access it was 10 years ago. 

A TON of the basic content is locked behind paid DLC. The kind of stuff that would be included in any other base builder. I really resent how much you're advertised to while playing a paid-for game. You'll be reminded of all the features you're missing every time you choose a block to build and see that 90% of them are faded out and say "buy our DLC". It takes much longer to find anything because you have to wade through all of these advertisements to find the blocks you actually can build. I would expect this from a free-to-play game.

The "survival" mode is extremely lacking compared to any other survival game, if you come for that aspect you will be disappointed.

Be prepared to scour online forums every time something isn't working. If the shapes of blocks aren't sufficiently connecting, even if it looked like they snapped together, it will create a whole different "grid" and nothing will be connected. You can only fix this by building a specialized merge block to dock them back together. 

Inventory is incredibly small, which makes the game tedious until you have a small vessel for every purpose, mining, refining, manufacturing, ground transport, air transport, etc. Managing inventories is tedious also. 

Basically the game becomes fun once you've beaten the game, and have conveyors between everything and it's all automated. I would suggest it only if you want to play in creative and build stuff without worrying about resources, and even then you really have to buy some DLC for the interesting stuff. 

In 2024 there are simply lots of games that do this better. Satisfactory, Factorio, Empyrion, 7 Days to Die, etc.

TLDR; There is a ton to do if you like building machinery/vehicles. However, once the sheen of sci-fi lego game has worn off you are stuck with a bunch of machines with no solid purpose. 

This review is a Yes, BUT*. This means that if I had to say yes or no, I would recommend it. I have had tons of fun with trial and error building space ships, ground vehicles, weapon systems, and even entire building complexes. There are a ton of block variations, affordable DLC, community support, and so many possibilities for building the sci-fi space scene of your dreams. Playing with friends is highly recommended due to reasons listed below, but even building mining rigs to gather materials is a good time as you make and break a handful of designs before landing on "the one".
However, aside from the base AI ships there is not much life to the universe. Your vehicles serve no purpose other than that which you give them. They have guns in the game, but I can't say I've encountered any PvE purpose to use them. The in game economy seemed built with player-trading in mind, but that goes out the window when anything and everything can be built/harvested. 
In the future, I hope Space Engineers comes along with a Mission Board that gives transport missions which require you to build a vehicle to complete them. Maybe you only have so many in game hours to transport 200k of Iron Ore to make contract. Or bounty hunting contracts. Just some filler so the world doesn't fill so empty. This review has felt negative thus far, but let me end on this-- Space Engineers is an amazing game of design and function. If you can dream it, you can probably build it, and based on the frequency of the DLC I don't see the company giving up on it anytime soon.

I may not have the most hours out there but just these couple hundreds have been enough to completely hook me. I've always been a fan of sandboxes - sure, but this one just clicked for me. 
The game is buggy, the devs are doing odd things with the game, the building system is objectively hard to get used to - but the game is extremely fun. I put in the hours and now i'm genuinely enjoying playing on my own little world, expanding my frontiers having started from nothing. 

Look this game is not for everyone, but i must admit i'm happy i was introduced to it and i wanna see what else i can come up with.

For those considering buying the game, a small list of pros and cons i've encountered so far: 
Pros: 
- art direction is really cool, i love the near-future aesthetic, the weird industrial and blocky look, something you'd see on real missions, something tough and easy to manufacture. 
- vehicles are extremely fun to both build and drive, yes the speed can be limiting - (you can mod it to be higher tho don't go too crazy or physics die lmao) - but there's something so sattisfying to driving around on planets or cruising through space. 
- it can genuinely be immersive. it puts you in the shoes of some engineer out there being deployed into a barren planet to settle and expand to their heart's content, but how you achieve it and the genuine depth there is to it, it's super fun (for me). driving a truck around, hauling materials from point a to point b, crusing through space in your giant ship, checking for fuel consuption, seeing that everything is alright.. it's fun for me.
- sound design is honestly really good. some sounds can and will become annoying but i genuinely enjoy the sounds of menus and most of all ships, all the clicks and clacks, the rumble and the almost sloppy sounding ships just make it feel more real. 
- it's super moddable. there's obviously limits but all the sorta stuff you might want there's probably a mod for it.

as cons: 
- it's not so well optimised, you may need to crank the graphics way lower than your PC might be able to handle. which can make it loose a lot of what makes it so good looking. 
- it's very bugy at times, some things might fuck you up *big time* and completely break an otherwise fantastic immersion.
- DLC bloat, a lot of the great looking assets are locked behind a paywall, you can grab a selection of them while on sale but it can be a bit predatory. I personally bit the bullet, i can't live without my pretty blocks.
- steep learning curve. as much as i want to apreciate the depth and sheer expansiveness of the game and what it lets you do, i don't feel it's *as well* presented. there is a learning to survive scenario but the fact it requires a step by step guide probably tells you it's not good, if you really need it splitsie has some GREAT guides to get you started on most of the game's basic mechanics. 
- air leaks. god i hate how inconsistent the game can be with them. not much to say just do something about it keen lol.

If you want to be an engineer, this is the game for you.  No matter how many parts you have available, the sky is the limit.  It took me a long time to understand this game.  No matter how many times I try to make a perfect ship, I always missed something.  This is one game that will make you think on how you want to engineer it your own design...  Literally.  

You can design simple ship up to capital ships.  Any way you want.  There is no design limit to this game.  There is no right way to play or setup.  It is all up to you.  

This game makes you live up to the name space engineer. 

There is one thing when getting started.  Build a basic refinery and assembler and a mining drill or ship.  This will speed up collecting ore quick and fast. Always watch Youtube game play for more details of getting started.  Plenty helpful tips.

I dug a giant hole into the ground, mined a crap load of ore. I basically hollowed out the crust of the planet where we put our base and the game runs great regardless. It has been a very cool experience in survival mode so far scavanging whatever we can to make our fortress. 

In the night we have seen Aurora Borialis in the canyons and it was green as ever. It looked like the real thing. There is just enough excitement to keep you on your toes. We set up solar panels that just barely got juiced up by the time night fell upon us. It's a good thing we thought ahead and built a battery to go with them just in the nick of time. The situation feels very real and if you don't play it smart you can die, or you could just bump into your friend and kill him because this game hates player on player clipping.  For the most part the game is pretty awesome though. 


Rating: 9/10

With almost a year in this game, it safe to say I love it. Building is awesome, learning how to add more detail into things, and building things I love. Combat is unique to SE, and the block destruction system is just unparalleled. The variety of mods is insane! Being able to get mods to make building easier and faster or to change how core systems work, the modding community makes this game truly special. 

Yes there are bugs, more than a few, but those honestly make the game *more* fun. It introduces an aspect of randomness that makes every adventure exciting. Multiplayer is fantastic. Building with friends, blowing things up, crashing space ships. The variety of things to do makes multiplayer one of the greatest things about this game. Its better with friends.

While I know they are somewhat controversial, after spending so long playing this game I am more than willing to pay out $5 or so a year to support a game I love so dearly. And while true that DLC blocks introduce no new functionalities, they do add cosmetic options that make building all that much better.

Buy this game. You won't regret it.

This game has the most hideous and horrible GUI and HUD I've ever seen. the game system are overly complicated for no reason and the "tutorial" is just FOUR (4) 20 minute boring job training videos for a game.

This game has no actual design, it feels thrown together with the most complicated and annoying systems for the simplest of task. not only that the whole point of the game is to build but why is it that their is not direction indicators for ANYTHING. the HUD in the game has no button indicators, no compass and no indicators for what is up (WHEEL SUSPENSION). lets also not forget the fact that the tutorials were written over 6 years ago on outdated systems and so anything new you're out of luck and either have to figure it out, or go look up a 25 minute video (which is also just the in-game tutorial). i came to play a game not watch a 20 minute boring video of the dev talking at you about how to use the most basic system of the game. the world system is so very nice and the physics is great, but why is that the most basic systems are ignored and not cared for. 

The building could be great, and in fact if you want to take the time to learn how to use the system, it could be used to make the most amazing looking things in a game. The system however is ridiculous, and trying to figure out the build menu is like smashing against a brick wall, it takes forever to build anything because the menu is so clustered with nonsense and the most annoying thing, the DLC block are not able to be hidden so it makes it a chore to sort through to the block you actually need/want and causes the clutter issue to be exacerbated. you get a picture and that's it you need to hover over every block or look at a tiny little picture of the block. so if you're new or are coming back after a long time. its spending 5 minutes hovering over the blocks to find the correct one, fighting with the tool bar system for the building, THEN placing the block for all of 20 seconds before you move on to the next block.

thank you keen for making this game look forward to space egineers 2 on a much improved engine hopefully some day till then im happy to by your dlc to keep you guys going.

Space Engineers emerges as a beacon of boundless creativity and exploration. From the moment you step into this galactic sandbox, the possibilities feel as vast as the cosmos itself.

At its heart lies an invitation to forge your destiny among the stars. The canvas is yours to paint with celestial hues, whether constructing intricate space stations that hum with life or crafting nimble spacecraft that dance through the void. Each block placed is a stroke of ambition, each creation a testament to your engineering prowess.

But it's not just about building; it's about the challenge. The realistic physics engine adds a layer of authenticity, where structural integrity matters, and the laws of gravity and inertia reign supreme. Designing your creations demands not just creativity but also thoughtful engineering finesse. Watching your carefully crafted vessel take flight (or not), obeying (or at the mercy of) the laws of physics, is a triumph that's both exhilarating and rewarding.

Survival mode, with its demand for resource management and life support systems, adds depth to the experience. From mining asteroids for precious resources to managing energy consumption, it's a testament to your resilience and adaptability in the vast emptiness of space.

The thrill amplifies in multiplayer, where collaborative efforts soar to new heights. Joining forces to conquer challenges or competing in grand engineering showdowns fosters a sense of camaraderie and friendly rivalry that fuels the community spirit.

Exploration beckons, and the universe here is your playground. Traverse diverse planets, moons, and asteroids, each offering its own set of challenges and treasures. The satisfaction of discovery and the promise of the unknown keep the adventure alive and beckoning.

Buy and play this game if you want to experience a cosmos of endless possibilities. The modding community enriches the experience, injecting new life and content into an already expansive universe. The support from the developers, the constant updates, and the sheer potential for creativity ensure that every return to Space Engineers is met with new wonders to behold.

In the end, Space Engineers isn't just a game; it's a canvas where dreams take form, where innovation thrives, and where the universe bows to your creative will. It's an odyssey that invites you to chart your course among the stars and craft your legacy in the annals of space exploration.

My partner of 20+ years has probably left me but I'm not sure how many weeks / months it will be until I notice. 

If you enjoy building things in creative or survival style & solving problems whether they are meta-world gui issues <snicker> or in-world problems of your own making, give it a shot. I bought the base game on sale for £7-£8. I've basically ruined my 'marriage' for just a pint & a half (the last time I went to a pub). 

Usually I have to indulge in a campaign of returning home drunk & soiling myself in the hallway before I'm left in peace.

The game was great for building. KSWH was, at first, brilliant. They cared, and did their best.
The game is still that great creative building game... but it has been abandoned. In 10 years of ongoing updates since release, more if you include early acces, and even with all DLC, the game still feels dead.
The recent AI update feels like a barebones tech demo at best. 

For anything other than a creative building mode, you need mods, or a server environment, which is horribly imbalanced because...

Originally, the first two DLCs were purely cosmetic. This was, at the time, declared to be intentional, designed start to finish with no multiplayer imbalance to ever come from owning the DLCs. The problem is that the rest have all had functional architecture, so called "cosmetic" blocks that are in fact extremely functional in PVP or server environments, giving more compact designs, sleek and more easy to hide, and more defensive due to smaller hitboxes, with less emissives or light sources to identify with in dark spaces (everywhere but dayside surface on planets.) 
Worse, they were specifically catered to that exact environment, the combat and pvp updates in particular had the worst of these blocks despite being targeted toward those groups, including defensive firing positions that fully defend the shooter. There's no way it was designed to keep balance with the non-dlc players in any form.

In addition to the lack of updates in general, when they do release "free" updates, they're alongside DLC and only done in attempt to get people coming back and buying.

For reference, I play PDX games. I love my DLC-adjacent updates, and in case of PDX I agree they have quite aggressive DLC policies, but their updates.. well, they actually have updates at all, and both normal and dlc-adjacent updates are extremely solid. Plus, any content owned by the host can be used by all players.

SE has no changes except for DLC-adjacent 'free' updates, and compared to the beginning, they're barely a shadow and a laugh at what the developers once were, while server environments require every individual to own each DLC to utilise them.

A very broken game with great potential.  

Spent about 6 hours on the game and found the game non-intuitive and the tutorial system is useless.  Player tutorials are much better.

You will spend a lot of time learning which keys (alt vs ctrl vs shift + letter/number/F-key) do in order to get anything done. None of which is intuitive. This results in an unnecessarily high learning curve.  Developers desperately need to hire a Human Factors Engineer.  

Part of the problem may be focus on the part of the Developers.  Players can use xBox/PS5 type controller (no alt/ctrl/shift/f-keys).  This game may have been built for game controllers, which I don't have.  PC players may have been an afterthought.

There are minor bugs and some of keys simply don't work when they should.  This feels like a good beta.  

For those who don't mind many hours learning the system, you will be rewarded.  There is gold there.  You just have to dig harder than you should have to.

Recommendation:  
Keyboard/Mouse: Wait until they improve the user interface.  
Game Controller:  undetermined (it may be deserving of the 91% approval rating).
