[h1] TL;DR: [/h1]
⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

[h2] A Stellar Engineering Playground [/h2]

[hr][/hr]

[h1] Detailed Review: [/h1]

[h2] 1. Narrative and Visuals (5/5): [/h2]
Space Engineers scratches a unique itch, standing out as the best 'space survival sandbox' available. Its design, especially for those with an eye for design and programming sense, is unmatched. A solid 10/10 recommendation.

[h2] 2. Gameplay and Unique Features (5/5): [/h2]
While entry may have a high bar, Space Engineers excels in gameplay, offering an unparalleled 'space survival sandbox.' The in-game tutorials are subpar, but after the initial learning curve, the game becomes a clockwork of creativity.

[h2] 3. Optimization Woes (5/5): [/h2]
Despite occasional oddities and friction issues, the physics engine works well, allowing for the creation of interesting structures. However, dedicated servers on personal machines may impact performance, leading to lag and physics interaction problems.

[h2] 4. Soundtrack and Audio Design (5/5): [/h2]
Space Engineers captivates players with its challenging yet enjoyable gameplay, focusing on building and overcoming unique challenges. The game's physics create a puzzle-like experience that evolves based on the player, the planet, and their friends.

[h2] 5. Bugs and Technical Issues (5/5): [/h2]
While some aspects may be broken, like the physics engine under certain conditions, the overall enjoyment of building and solving puzzles overshadows these issues. The game's survival mode may seem like a missed opportunity, but the joy lies in overcoming challenges.

[h2] 6. Replay Value and DLCs (5/5): [/h2]
Space Engineers offers an exceptional replay value, akin to Minecraft but set in space with the ability to build ships, space stations, and bases. The game's broken aspects don't diminish the overall enjoyment, especially for those who love building, solving puzzles, and automation on a large scale.

[h2] 7. Community and Modding (5/5): [/h2]
The game thrives in a multiplayer environment, encouraging collaborative building and making accomplishments more satisfying when shared with friends. Space Engineers' openness to modding enhances the overall experience.

[h2] 8. Value for Money (5/5): [/h2]
Considering the depth of content, cooperative multiplayer potential, and the satisfaction of building and exploration, Space Engineers offers excellent value for money. The game's continuous development and maintenance contribute to its lasting appeal. 

If you just want to enjoy the experience pick up the base game, but if you feel like supporting the devs pick all the DLCs as they are only decorative blocks and they do not add anything new to the game mechanics.

[h1] Personal Thoughts: [/h1]

Space Engineers resonates as an engaging space sandbox, providing endless possibilities for creativity and exploration. Despite its flaws, the attachment to self-built creations and the game's open-ended building make it a captivating experience. The lack of a conventional story might not suit everyone, but for those who relish the joy of designing and experimenting, Space Engineers is a stellar choice. Whether you're a meticulous designer or simply enjoy building and tinkering, this game offers a rich and rewarding gameplay experience.

Space Engineers is one of the best sandbox survival games I have ever played and I love it immensely.

The Community Workshop shows me the best of creativity and concept thinking. There is never a shortage of help when it comes to trying to learn and understand how to make use of this game's extensive capabilities, enabling people to endlessly experiment and play around with what they can do.

As far as the game itself, I have yet to experience a game that allowed me to exercise my creative ideas and play around with the concept of physical limitations and careful planning when it comes to survival. This game allows me to build some of the greatest ideas I've ever come up with and see them come to fruition.

I have played other games with similar concepts behind them, and nothing to date compares even remotely to the fun I have playing Space Engineers. 

I think Keen Software has knocked it way out of the park with this one. I doubt I will ever stop wanting to play Space Engineers!

I originally reviewed this game quite negatively, and I stand by several parts of that negative review.

But my friend urged me to continue playing and I have sense changed my mind on if the game is worth buying.

The physics engine is quite odd in many places, downright bad in some, but for the most part it does what you need it to do, and more, very well when it works. You can build a lot of interesting and fun things with the engine, but it prefers space and has some problems with friction it seems like.

Your game with run worse on a dedicated server on your own machine, im not sure how, but it will. And it is a LOT worse, not enough to chug, but enough to feel the lag and the physics interactions seem to suffer for it being on a server vs pure client.

The most enjoyable part of the game is building things and overcoming the unique challenges your builds create, its like a puzzle that can't end, and it gets harder or easier depending on you, the planet, and your friends.

If you're into building things, solving puzzles, automation all on a large scale, this game is probably for you.

Expensive, poorly optimized, forgotten.

The game has had no significant changes since early access. It is the worst possible waste of money. 

The game was released in a largely undeveloped state, and then Keen immediately abandoned it and announced two new games -- Medieval Engineers and Space Engineers 2, both of which it promptly forgot. 

The only new additions have been expensive DLC packs of content that has existed on the workshop for free for years.

There is nothing interesting in the game world. The multiplayer is buggy. Planets were added as an afterthought. The entire game is so poorly optimized and developed that it is more of a proof-of-concept than the quality you would expect for the price.

Keen had the audacity to ask for the 'Labor of Love' award, and frankly they should go fuck themselves. Do not buy this game.

Changing the review once again, and probably - at last.

Both me and this game have went through a long path, and it was a bumpy one. A lot of changes were made, some for worse, but most were probably for the better. DLC's didn't turn out to be as much of an issue as everybody had expected, and they do add some neat options for people that are really invested into game, with a fair share of free updates for everybody. Gameplay is probably the best out of all space sandboxes out there. Story is nonexistent, bits of lore are mostly scattered across files and folders of the [i]Deluxe Edition[/i] DLC. Best thing about soundtrack is that you can turn it off. Ping on multinational servers is just atrocious: be it dedicated or player-hosted.

TLDR: buy if you love designing, engineering, building, space and exploration. Do [b]NOT[/b] buy if you want story, soundtrack, characters and whatever. You can do roleplaying, but I wouldn't advise it.

I'll preface my review to say, I have not completed any Scenarios in the game nor played on any public servers. I've played on dedicated servers with friends & single player, with easily 90% of my time played being single player. 
The game has a high learning curve and because of this, takes a lot of time to get comfortable (i.e. 100+ hours due to large variety of blocks and build potential). The time investment to learn is why most my friends quit playing. I found the built-in tutorials rather useless and went to YouTube to resolve all the issues I've encountered along with teaching myself how to use blocks to automate remedial tasks, big thank you to creator Splitsie for the tutorials & how-to videos. 
Overall, your experience with the game will vary greatly depending on what effort you put into it. Don't be afraid of adding mods to the game, they easily make the experience significantly better. Quality-of-life mods are a great place to start. I added more NPC encounters later on and got properly messed up by MES. Glad to say I've since returned the favor.

I purchased this game on the 2nd of December 
Going in I knew that it was going to take up a bit of my time as I always have enjoyed games where the limit is what you can imagine (and create functionally).
My friends had suggested it to me a few times.
As of writing this review it is 12:55AM on the 21st of December and I have spent over 160 hours designing ships, cars, motorbikes, forklifts ect.. 
The end is not in sight.
My friends fear for my safety as I've stopped sleeping and eating regularly.
I am still learning how to use everything to it's full extent.
I go to sleep with tutorials playing in my ear.
I have started carrying a notebook to draw up designs I see around me or to whip up something when inspiration strikes. It is consuming every aspect of my life.
When I take a brief pause to look at my girlfriend and reassure her that I am still alive, all I see is a collection of hinges and a few well placed connectors.
6/10 Could use a few more decorative blocks

Space Engineers feels more like an early access simulator than an actual game

It's an open sandbox that's never added a single goal in the game that you don't create yourself, which makes the gameplay feel pointless.

The core survival gameplay consists entirely of mining to get the resources to create a ship that requires you to painstakingly weld together every part, or design a complicated welding system that feels like it's fighting the game's engine to function and has a high chance of getting obliterated by a physics bug. 

Even if you manage to sit through the tedium of making said ship, then what? There's no enemy NPC faction to fight with it, no distant stars to travel to, no variation in the same endless asteroid fields and barren planetary surfaces.

Maybe this is ideal for some people, but the lack of content alongside the endless stream of DLC makes this feel more like a corpse of a game that gets propped up to sell cosmetic DLCs

As you might be able to tell I have and am enjoying this game quite a lot, and I recon this is my second most played game just after Minecraft. There isnt much I can say that other reviews havnt already covered in all detail someone could need so here is my summary.
The Good: Modability, Creativity, Near endless scale, not even the sky is the limit.
The Bad: Klang, Inventory Management, CPU on fire.
The Neutral: Servers are nice but due to performance restrictions the scale they allow for is usually too small to peek my interest. If you are into spending hundrets of hours on a behemot project you probably cant do that on a server. If you want to just build for a few hours and then ruin some other poor engineer's day they probably are quite enjoyable.

It's Space Legos.  There isn't much in the way of "point" or "goals", at least in the single player flavor.  It is strangely satisfying to bootstrap up through the lower tech trees, gather resources, and build weird stuff freehand though.  I would recommend checking out the modding forums pretty early on though.  The base game is somewhat limited in scope, but can be greatly expanded with some simple (or complex) mods.

One of the best sandbox games, -- the quantity of optimization and content updates this game has seen since its beginning shows an extremely high level of developer input, one of (if not) the most desirable traits for a video game. The sheer amount of community content and latent potential that this game has makes it playable for endless periods of time -- something rarely found, the only other example that comes to mind being Minecraft. However, there are a few struggles that should be expected. 1. - There is a sharp learning curve that can be daunting when first playing. 2. -The computing requirements for this game can be extremely high, if you plan on building anything with over a few thousand blocks expect to need a fairly expensive computer. Once you get over the learning curve - the game seems to come alive with its endless possibilities of creation, engineering, and destruction.

Space Engineers is a sandbox gaming gem, where ship building takes center stage, offering players an endless playground for their engineering imagination. The freedom to design and construct spacecraft is unparalleled, creating a sense of ownership and pride as you launch custom-built vessels into the cosmos. Crafting colossal space stations or nimble rovers feels intuitive and satisfying. Space Engineers delivers an immersive and thrilling sandbox experience that keeps you hooked from the moment you embark on your interstellar journey.

there is some barrier of entry, play the tutorials, watch some walkthroughs. most of all remember the title, this is a game about engineering. if you're having a problem, your inventory is too small, your ship is taking too long to construct, you're spending to long ferrying supplies from one place to another. it is up to you to Engineer a solution, THIS iS THE GAME, THIS IS THE PUZZLE. Build a wagon to carry your stuff, build a crane to aid construction, build a pipeline or a supply drone. and finally, learn the game play systems available, some important ones that are easy to miss or get askew are the build planner, the blueprint system, and the scripting system
The build planner is quite straight forward but easy to miss entirely if you skip the tutorials.

blueprints, DO NOT DESIGN SHIPS IN SURVIVAL, thats what creative mode is for, so that you can design ships work out the kinks, make them pretty. create a blueprint and build them from there DESIGN FIRST, CONSTRUCT SECOND engineers have been doing it for a few thousand years now, works great.

Scripting, you dont have to write them yourself but its not hard to learn and its a good life skill. Quite aside from that there are plenty of useful scripts just waiting for you on the workshop, PARK is a great place to start i use it all the time.

Space Engineers is a borderline case of recommend / don't recommend, but after thinking about it at length, I am giving it a thumbs down. There are glimmers of fun to be dug up from the refuse pile, but at the end of the day, the game is more pain than enjoyable. Even the term "game" is a bit of a misnomer; it's more of a game engine somebody forgot to make a game out of.

· There are two extremes of gameplay; creative and survival mode. In creative you are just building stuff, but nothing you do matters since you're invincible and have infinite resources -- why build a mining rig when you don't need to mine, why build a spaceship when you can teleport everywhere? Survival mode on the other hand is an unholy mess of bad game design, from an irrelevant progression system to some truly torturous building mechanics.

· On that latter point, people sometimes call this game "Minecraft in space". It's vaguely true, but the blocks are 2 and a half times larger in every dimension (16 times the volume), too big to jump on, are plain and ugly, you have to assemble a single cobblestone block from 100 rocks and a bag of concrete, you can only carry 20 rocks at a time, and you have to stare at epileptic strobe lights for several seconds each time you assemble one. It's insanely tedious and all you can really build are rectangular rooms with nothing going on inside — unless you buy the decorative DLC blocks, then you can copy-paste the same bed, kitchen and lockers over and over again.

· Ah yes, the DLC. The game creators want you to buy the DLC. They really, really want you to buy the DLC. There are some 14 DLC packs, each containing a few cosmetic blocks so you can simulate having a toilet in your spaceship. As a reminder that you don't have these DLC packages, your build menu is full of these blocks, grayed out and taunting you every time you select something to build.

· Keen Software has some sketchy business practices. Space Engineers will repeatedly bug you to waive your privacy rights when launching it. They are responsible for Medieval Engineers, an abandoned early access game still up for sale at $10. People have noted a lack of concern for security, so if you play online this game may very well give hackers a way into your computer.

· For inexplicable reasons, the game keeps separate folders for your saves and mods depending on whether you're playing with an internet connection or not, either of which becomes inaccessible when you play under the opposite conditions.

· For all of the hours-long grind it takes to build things, it is insanely easy to destroy them in seconds. The physics bugs in this game will absolutely tear apart the thing you spent a ridiculous amount of time assembling. Multiplayer lag and desynchronization will leave you wondering why everything just exploded. Combat is a matter of who has the guns with the longest range, and the other side gets the pleasure of being torn asunder before they realize they're being shot at. The autosave feature seems designed to capture that moment right after your rover's suspension launches it kilometers in the air upside-down.

· The vanilla speed limit for any vehicle is 100 meters per second (224 mph). This can be modded up to about 500 m/s before the physics bugs take over. Contrast the SR-71 Blackbird at 983 m/s, the International Space Station at 7,660 m/s, or Voyager 1 at 17,000 m/s. For a game about space exploration, you move painfully slow. Yet the player is fitted with a jetpack which accelerates to 110 m/s with the lightest touch, often with lethal results. Ship-to-ship combat typically results in the NPC ship running away at maximum speed, and thanks to inertia, will continue drifting at maximum speed after its engines are shot out, rendering it unrecoverable. Even if not for the speed limit, overly abundant asteroids make extended flight in open space a bad idea, so you're forced to teleport from place to place using a jump drive.

· Contrary to its age and general lack of content, this game makes your GPU run hot. Spending time on a planet in particular will turn your PC into a space heater, which might be a plus in the winter, but not so much the rest of the time.

· Like most good games, Space Engineers has excellent mod support and the community has done an okay job of patching its flaws, but even with mods, it just doesn't feel complete or well-integrated. None of the mods really create an impression of being in a living universe where anything you do matters. Many mods are non-functional due to game engine changes over the years. Even finding mods that work well together is a bit of a slog.

Not to say it's completely bad. Once in a while you'll be flying through a canyon and you'll think, "okay, this is kind of cool." Scripting a cruise missile to follow the terrain of a planet, keeping itself aloft against the pull of gravity, can be fun. But, it's bad. For $5 or $10, sure, it's probably worth the price of admission, but not at full price, and definitely not with a full pack of DLC.

Mark Rober would approve

Pretty Good.

Pros:

Mods Are Easy To Install (Practically Part Of The Game)
Ran Well On My Laptop
You Can Dig To The Center Of Every Planet
You Can Share Build Blueprints
Has Survival/Creative Gamemodes
Has Multiplayer
Uses Actual Units Of Measurement For Thrusters (Newtons), Rotors+Hinges (Newton Meters), Gyro Override (RPM).

Cons:


Vanilla Speed Limit Is Slow (110M/s Jetpack, 100M/Sec Grid Thrusters, ~105M/Sec Grid Gravity)

Unmodded Hand Weapons Are Worse Than The Hand Grinder At Destroying Grids

DLC Is Displayed On The Pause And Menu Screen

You Cant Use a Projector To Have Any Subgrids Along With The Main Grid (Subgrids Are Grids Attached To The Main Grid By Rotors, Pistons, Hinges, Magnetic Plates Or Connectors)

DLC Items You Dont Own (Paint, Blocks) Stop You From Being Able To Steal Other Peoples Blocks.

After playing for a few hours, I feel like I can review this.

The absolute worst part about this game is (multiplayer) server lag, and the lack of people playing it. 
The Idea is grand, and pretty well developed for a game that entered beta in 2016, and only recently fully released.

It does however lack any sort of drive once you get the resources you need. What I mean by that is, you can produce anything you'd like, and there's not really anyone that's going to try and take it or stop you from progressing. So it does get a tad boring sometimes.

Best way to sum up this game is Minecraft meets space. You have absolute freedom to build and do what you want, and that's something a lot of games advertise yet rarely ever truly deliver on (Talking about you Starfield)

This may be the single greatest open world sandbox ever made. Since purchasing it in 2015, and recently since 2020, I have played this game almost religiously, at least once or twice every week. Sometimes I'll play multiple sessions in one day, every single day of the week.

It is a game so absolutely full of content, it's captivating and is one of few games to really give it's player limitless creativity; whether you're building massive flagships, quick gunners, underground missile silos, sprawling space stations, spy satellites, rovers, space elevators, AI controlled robot armies, the list goes for what you can do.
And the multiplayer allows for massive battles between large fleets of players, the workshop and the programmable blocks allow you to see and use the fantastic tings people have created for this game. 
This is a game I think about almost anytime my mind is free, I constantly think of ideas, experiments and projects I can happily occupy myself all within this one game.

I have bought every DLC for this game and as long as I have money, I will keep buying new ones, I do not regret a thing as I enjoy every second I've spent playing this game.
And for a game that uses an engine from 2013, It looks and plays really damn well. We do have watch out for when Klang decides its time to harvest...

I really wanted to like this game. I'm even the kind of person that likes grindy games like these. But the grind isn't the issue here. The UI and Menus are a mess, the controls are completely unintuitive, the graphics are bland at best, and everything feels generally clunky and unrefined.
There isn't really anything "fun" to do, either. I find a lot of fun in exploring, but getting to the true exploration part of this game would take far longer than I'm willing to put the time in for. As far as I got, the standard world terrain was mind numbingly boring. And there aren't any ruins or anything on the planets to rummage through, other than thousands of kilometers of dirt.
For a game supposedly "designed by engineers" or something like that, it certainly doesn't feel like it. 

TL;DR: This game sucks.

Meh.... too many restrictions when building and the overall blockiness of your ships gets really annoying after a while. Ive put in enough hours to know that this game has more limitation than freedom than your given.
A block build system that makes everything look the same, its hard not to end up with something that already looks like it was subscribed to in the workshop.
The blocks are varied and have multiple sizes and versions, the armor blocks come in several variants but you really have to struggle to get some of the blocks to work. Some come in half sizes but will take up a full space. Windows will make you pull out your hair in frustration as you struggle to get air tight and a nice looking build. Windows have will take up a whole block space and leave you with a spot in which you can't use due to the collusion mesh, as a matter of face, all the collusion meshes will cause you frustration. Some simply are just useless.
Sleek is not in this game nor the developers vocabulary. Simple ideas like a ramp are practically impossible that are also air tight is well impossible. Grid sizes Large and Small don't combine. The amount of mods that are available should tell you what is missing this game. Oh yeah light passing through your ship walls will drive you nuts. The AI blocks leave a lot to be desired, simple things like making a drone require patience and sheer will not to issue a gypsy curse on the developers.

Is there anything that can match this games concept? yes but not as polished as this is and those other ones tend to look like puke with lipstick on. Oh yeah expect a boring gameplay as there isn't enough npcs to fight or interact with. Spiders? big deal. Survival? Meh.. Creative? hmm no point.

There is just too many negatives and not enough stuff to do that makes it not worth it even though I will come back to it again in the future maybe but for now it comes off the system as it isn't fun anymore.

I've spent thousands of hours in Space Engineers, and I can confidently say it's the best grid-building survival PVP game in the world. The fact that the game and its code are over a decade old speaks volumes about its uniqueness and enduring appeal. There's simply nothing else quite like it.
  The 3D scaling is captivating, allowing for infinite creations and a sense of endless possibilities. The existence of official servers with infinite kilometers is a testament to the game's ambition. What truly sets Space Engineers apart, however, is the unwavering support from both the community and the developers at Keen.
  In my three decades of gaming, I've never encountered more responsive admins. The dedication to player engagement and continuous improvement has not only enhanced my gaming experience but also stimulated my mind and imagination. Keen has successfully created a game that brings excitement to the core of my being.
  As a devoted player, I want to express my gratitude to Keen for their commitment to excellence. Your work has not gone unnoticed, and I genuinely appreciate the effort you've put into making Space Engineers a masterpiece.
  However, with all this in mind, I can't help but express a hope for the future. Please don't sink resources into frivolous endeavors; the world needs a Space Engineers Two. With the foundation you've built, imagine the possibilities of a sequel that pushes boundaries even further.
  Thank you, Keen, for the incredible journey so far. Here's to the hope of many more adventures in the cosmos! 🚀

Do you like sandbox games? Do you like building ships and huge creations? Do you like automation? How about space? You like the vast, infinite luxury of space? If these things sound cool and neato to you, sell your soul to our almighty lord Clang and join us on a space sandbox adventure. Also the workshop community is amazing with mods and creations that update everyday constantly, and the overall community is super supportive and welcoming and will help you with any questions you have. I highly suggest this game.

Update:
After 993+ hours, and a lot of thinking, I can not in good faith still recommend this game. The developers have switched to a predatory method of taking very minor tweaks, even ones that had already been made freely available through modding, and locking them behind individual DLC's, creating a paywall for anyone wanting to get the full game experience. I feel as though it goes against what I wanted with this game, and my ability to access it. Had the developers instead opted for an optional donation plan or something of the sort, I have no doubt the long time fans of this game would have helped fund something they've already sunk hundreds of hours into. This game lost its soul, the engine is still buggy as all hell, and any further development will forever be paywalled. Very sad to see it happen.

Game has been out for 10 years. It's still full of bugs and chronically empty. 75% of the updates since I got the game in 2017 have been cosmetics and DLC.

Its hard to describe how I feel. I love building things, but you'll spend hours building a literal Death Star and when you place the final block its all like "why the hell did I spend four hours making this?" and then its just a saved blueprint. 

FYI the learning curve for this game is pretty high, for making complex things that is. 537 hours in, and i'm still finding new quirks in the physics and such. That doesn't stop my contraptions from spontaneously turning into dust though.

You can build some fantastic things, but what they can actually do is massively limited. Sub-grids have AWFUL mechanics, using hinges and rotors is just so painful, all it takes is for one block to clip another and your whole ship will go spinning off into space like Team Rocket blasting off. Touch 2 grids together in a funny way and both will just disappear and your character will fall into a crater with a bunch of loose O2 bottles and ammo boxes.

Survival mode is long-winded and lame. Mining minerals is boring, processing and construction is extremely slow and boring. High learning curve.

Building is honestly like trying to service a fighter jet with Walmart tools. Deleting blocks accidentally and having your entire structure collapse is a frequent issue. The physics just do not cooperate. Complex designs are often impossible, and even simple designs fail spectacularly. 



The worlds are incredibly empty, and the NPC factions feel extremely bland. The economy system is extremely hollow. it just... went nowhere, really.



The game exists now as a bit of a DLC farm. The devs don't seem to care much about what players actually want. The game is entirely propped up by the amazing modding/workshop community, by creating workarounds and fantastic content that could've been in the game from the start. Without community content this game would be the most boring game ever, and after 537 hours its not enough anymore... This game could've done some really awesome things but has ended up uninspired, lacklustre even, falling far short of its potential.


Note: 
1. Build a tall tower and stick a rotor on top.
2. Build a long, horizontal row of light armor blocks on  the rotor. 
3. Stick a bunch of thrusters on the horizontal bar pointing in one direction, so as to make it spin in one direction.
4. put a control seat on the end of the horizontal bar
5. max out the rotor's torque and velocity, max override the thrusters, whilst in the seat.
6. this breaks the game's speed limit, and also the physics.
7. Launch out of the solar system

Alright, have to change my review from the small funny bit I had earlier;

This game is hogwash.

I love it to pieces and it's one of the reasons I absolutely love creating giant mech designs, big bases and factories, but holy crap is literally NOTHING in this game functional, minus a few guns and some wheels, and even THEN those have their moments... Ever seen a gatling turret try to take down a meteor? It's pathetic.

First things first, Rotors, Pistons, Hinges and all the other additional movement options are a total scam. They rarely work half the time, and when you put in the limitations or rotor locks, the game will literally just ignore their perameters and keep going, which usually breaks what you were working on to begin with.

Not to mention the massive issue with hulls and armor (Seriously, the best armor in the game is super strange, all you need is a large tire and some heavy armor and suddenly it has 6 times the strength as normal heavy armor.) Half the time the hull won't even protect what's inside it and the machine'll get gutted anyways despite what armor you put on it, not to mention the total bitch that is repairing a small ship.

Merge blocks and connectors work as intended, so good on the devs for finding out what superglue is and how to use it.

Don't even get me started on the terror field that is Survival in this game. "Oh? You want a way to actually get materials? Too bad lol, go out and punch a hole through the awful voxel plains to try and get a fraction of the materials that you actually need and hope your ship doesn't break from the extra weight."

It doesn't deserve the "labor of love" award, it doesn't deserve your time, and as someone with 700+ hours in the game, I can firmly say that it doesn't deserve mine.
Mined for 10,000 years.. Crafted for days.. and built a massive rover... JUST TO CRASH IT IMMEDIATELY!! Would do it again.

This game is like Morowind GOTY edition was drinking buddies with a 1960s astronaut and they decided to make a game about space so they played Halo and removed all the "story" elements, and removed all the first person shooter stuff and this is what you're left with. It's just an exercise in tedium and stupidity unless I've missed something but after 2.5 hours, I should at least know what the point is, right?

**Edited 11/28/23**

  It's been 9 years and about 380 hours at the time of writing this. Considering I've been playing this on and off since 2014, that's not a lot, but I've been around for awhile nonetheless so might as well write a review.

  Space Engineers is a single-player/multiplayer sandbox building game set in, well, space(and planets).  Space Engineers has been through a lot in the years since it was created.  Insane bugs, bad performance, poorly behaving rotors, and lag that would sometimes make PUBG cower in fear.  And through all this, it was fun.  Space Engineers has been enjoyable for years, even with the lag and bugs.  Since Update 1.187, many issues have been fixed.  Multiplayer and single-player games are much more stable, and Space Engineers has never been better.  

Pros:  

  >Very few things in this game are impossible.  You are essentially only limited by your imagination.
  > The game looks stunning.  
  > Recently the game is getting much easier to run and becoming more stable
  > The universe you occupy is quite large, with the Earth, Moon, Mars, Alien Planet, Triton, Europa, and Petram.  Each of these planets has their own environment and gravity level.
  > The modding community is huge.  There are tons of high quality mods out there with more being made all the times, that can either totally change your game or just add some tweaks.  Mods can fix almost all problems one would encounter (usually). 
  >Community is generally very friendly and there are plenty of servers to play on.  The people on the Keen Software House discord are some of the nicest people iv'e ever met.  They'll help you with any problem or questions you have.  The server community is also large.  There are countless communities for you too join and play with if you want a multiplayer experience.

Cons:
 
  >Vanilla exploration can be a little boring after a while.  Mods like Exploration Enhancement and Air Traffic can make it much better, but the vanilla exploration experience is still a bit lacking
  >Survival can be a little bland after you make it to all the planets and build all the things you want to build.  You'll still have at least 60-100 hours of gameplay in a vanilla world, but after that it slows down a bit.  Mods can help with this aswell.
  >DLCs are still hit and miss.  Not all of them are worth it and some are only really worth it for one or two blocks (Except you Decorative Pack 2, you're perfect.)
  >Bugs.  This is an inevitable problem in every game but I'm going to mention it anyways.  Space Engineers has fixed a large amount of the game breaking bugs but some still remain.  Your rover hit a tree?  Your rover goes flying.  Rotors have been known to be very buggy but still usable.  KSH has a big report page where you can report any bugs you find. 

TLDR:  Great game. Still getting updated and maintained fairly decently(ish) after 10 years.  Must buy if on sale and your like sandbox survival games.  The mods and multiplayer communities make the replay-ability very high.

Keen Software would rather milk this game for all the cash it can generate instead of fix its bugs. Some of the bugs I've run into include:

- Multi-grid ships falling in gravity, ruining any kind of interesting ship design
- Air-tightness sometimes not working properly, ruining our space station setup or causing behaviour like open rooms on a breathable planet being devoid of oxygen
- AI recorders not following the flight path set
- AI-controlled ships careering directly into terrain even with 'collision avoidance' on
- Programmable blocks occasionally ceasing to function
- Things controlled by timer blocks not being triggered in a consistent manner
- Not being able to enter specific times in timer blocks, instead having to rely on a slider with discrete steps
- Frequent multiplayer desync

Like the devs, my friend and I have given up on the game.

Space engineers is a massive, open world sandbox game about exploring and building in space, with a wide variety of things to explore, whether you want to explore derelict stations, build factories on distant planets, create massive battleships or just blow something up. This game has it all. While its survival may be lacking in content, and you may get bored quickly, it can be solved with an active workshop community, creating brand new scenarios, mods, bases and more. It may seem daunting at first, as there are a lot of mechanics to learn, you don't need them all to have fun. You can even do it with friends. Space engineers has a lot of different multiplayer opportunities such as servers or directly connecting to a host. If you need a story driven game, this isn't for you as the game encourages you to make your own, but if you like games like Minecraft, then this might be the one for you!

Regardless of the good and bad patches over the years, this game is well worth the money. Plenty of things to do, explore, build, and if you get real nerdy, programming inside the game to set up automated processes etc.

Nominate this game for the 'Labor of Love' reward! It has been in development for a very, very long time, and despite some questionable choices and some very gamebreaking and or funny bugs, I think personally the devs show some love. They made a most wanted update, for example, which added a ton of useful things.

If you're really into building stuff, this game is great - if not, you won't have nearly as much fun (i guess you could roleplay or something, but i've never really understood roleplaying so that's up to you to decide).

However, the survival systems are kind of neat and the space simulation aspects is damn good.

I haven't really played the scenarios (probably should though), but they seem like a decent compromise of both systems.

As someone who's never really understood why people love building stuff, I wouldn't recommend Space Engineers for those similar to me (i.e. you play games for the gameplay, story, etc. - not to build stuff).

But if you do enjoy building shit and/or love space/sci-fi, this game is perfect. I've seen several cool builds of ships from Stargate, Star Trek, Star Wars, etc. - so if you wanna make your own (or even design a custom ship) then this is the game to get.

The DLCs are also good if you wanna make your builds more thematic. $5 for about half a dozen blocks (and usually a skin alongside them) isn't that bad of a deal.
I only have 730 hours in this game, but they're all good fun hours and not boring frustrating hours.

After 300+ hours I can recommend the game for builder fans.

Almost a decade after release, no other building game has managed to capture the same magic that keeps me coming back.

While still lacking somewhat in mid-to-late game progression and goals, as an open-ended construction sandbox there really is nothing that comes close. A very active community of builders and modders offer loads of content to keep you inspired and fill in many of those gaps.

Ultimately you will want to be happy to set your own constructive goals, or derive motivation from multiplayer challenge. Veterans of Minecraft and other construction games will already be familiar with this almost inevitable aspect of the genre.

The initial learning curve is fairly high, but you'll be able to design drivable and flyable vehicles quite soon (once you've gathered enough material). The design possibilities are rich enough that you will find yourself continuing to improve and refine your skills over many hundreds of hours of gameplay, and you will never completely exhaust the game's creative potential. There is much more satisfaction than frustration, and again the community has a lot of help to offer.

Issues of engine performance and physics stability during development have been 95%+ dealt with, so don't be dissuaded if you read reviews with those complaints. Visually the game is swoon-worthy gorgeous, even on a low-end machine (more than 8GB RAM is strongly encouraged, though I am not unhappy with my 8GB on a very old i5 and GTX 760).

EDIT: 10 years in, I still love this game.

An excellent game all around, perfect for unleashing your creativity. It has grown much from how it started, and I'm quite happy with how far it has gone. If you want a game that combines construction, exploration, and space combat into a nice package, this is a game for you.

Over the years, Space Engineers has continued to astonish the world with it's amazing graphics since 2015! If you've ever wanted to explore a galaxy fighting off deadly robots and building up your ship; overcoming all sorts of engineering challenges that may follow then THIS is - THE - game for you. [h1] Space Engineers [/h1]
My absolute favorite game.

It was the first game where I reached 1000, 2000
3000+ hours, and will probably get more soon.

It wasn‘t always fun, but that could change with mods,
playing on servers, playing with friends, building and
just making something new or exploring bugs.

[h1] One of my first paid steam games [/h1]

It was one of the first games which I bought, and also
soon after I bought my first dlc‘s for I don’t recall the date
but that was probably 2019/2020,
since then I bought / received every dlc since then upon release
and even bought the Space Engineers plushie (Nr.1193)
I discovered the game with a video of a man flying his
plane, which then explodes twice, he then flies back into the
cockpit and soon after the plane explodes, then I watched videos
from Captain-Jack or LastStandGamers, tough I never played on
either of they’re servers.

[h1] Little Device history [/h1]

It wasn’t long after I got my first PC where i bought Space Engineers.
It was an Ryzen PC with the following Specs :
[b] Ryzen 3 2200g, 8gb RAM (later 16), 1TB HDD. [/b]
It ran fine at medium settings, and could even build bigger ships in
Space with fine fps, tough after a few updates performance dropped.
This is where I got my first PC with a dedicated GPU :
[b] Intel i7-4700k, RTX 2070 super, 32gb RAM,
 M.2 boot drive and 1TB HDD [/b]
I sold that pc and soon after got my first self built pc :
[b] Ryzen 7 3700x, RTX 3060 ti, 32gb RAM, 1TB m.2 storage,
6tb surveillance HDD‘s and a lot of fans. [/b]
This is where I am currently playing SE on.
SE is a laggy game when it comes to voxels.

[h1] 100 Hours [/h1]

I wrote my first Review at 100 hours.
In that time I figured out how to play survival, craft, automate,
make drill rigs and beat the game easily.
I started a survival world with a friend and we got pretty far.
I still own this world tough we don’t play on it anymore.

[h1] 1000 Hours [/h1]

1000 Hours in is where i got really invested in the game, also it was
Quarantine time so I had a lot of time to use.
I got into mods, servers and publishing BP‘s.
My first server was an Keen Server DE #2. (I believe it was)
We played with a few random players (don’t recall everyone) :
Lorddome, Enderstar, and a few more.
After a week of being inactive our base was attacked and we stopped.
I also started playing on a modded survival server called Hn-Z.
This is where I met Father Goat and his Goat Cult Faction.
We traded a lot and shared a lot of items or rovers.
It was really fun, I started playing while there was an event and
I won so I started with a lot of uranium.

[h1] 2000 Hours [/h1]

2000 Hours into the game and I was still hyped to play each day,
it was still quarantine time and i was still playing on Hn-Z and modded
Survival, i started playing each dlc scenario and got every achievement
at the same time as Enderstar99, i built a lot of vehicles and ships,
also started using custom Thumbnails for my ships, tough I gotta add an
Description and some more images still.
Most of the time I was playing survival, modded or vanilla.
I started playing on Keen De #2 again where I made a little YouTube series :
https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLyWau3dmWngPGZFXWXbE7gkHeJaPprkM9
We got really far, even got trough a server reset due to an exploit, but we never 
got to use our ships, they disappeared in the end.
I also stopped playing Hn-Z soon After.

[h1] 3000 Hours [/h1]

3000 Hours into the game the hyped kinda died down, I was still exited
to play the game but not as much as before.
I started playing on an Server called Space Limited Asia, where Goat
played too, after we established two mobiles bases and drove once around 
the planet the server got wiped, soon after we established a base on triton
called the TRL Rover Facility, it was a huge base that should look like a
wrecked rover, it never got finished because the conveyer to move your items 
was modded and got removed, but it was glorious. Enderstar99 has an 
YouTube Video showcasing it too :
https://youtu.be/r9SZ6guryI4
It wasn’t finished but still.
We also participated in so called Mobile-Base-Races, where we
used large rovers to finish races.

[h1] The Red Legion [/h1]
[b] The Red Legion or TRL [/b]
was an faction created by me inspired by the red legion from
Destiny one and two, also a little bit by the color of my then
current pc case which was black and red.
Everytime I joined a server I created the red legion, most times I published 
a Blueprint I put it in the red legion collection :
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2393626310
Since then I have been expanding it, or using it in other games.

I hope to expand this with 4000, 5000 or more hours someday.
Till then,

TL;DR: Better than Starfield.

Been playing since the Early Access days. Fun sandbox game for Space nerds like me, it's not exactly super-realistic but that's okay, too much realism tends to get in the way of having fun. It's not as hardcore as you would expect but it can be a bit difficult in the beginning. Building ships and stations can be fun or if you're in survival somewhat of a challenge depending on your aspirations.

However I think they need some more "Exploration" elements in the game, like abandoned wrecks and stations with a narrative driven story that you can discover what happened to the wrecks and stations and why they were abandoned.

The DLC aren't too expensive and you don't have to buy all of them if you don't want, you can also earn skins in game when you play Survival mode. And they're easy to get.

So yeah overall enjoyable.

I have been playing this game on and off since its birth. Its Time I leave a review. 

There is a lot of reasons to love this game; The Mod Community is diamond quality imo, most the people who run servers love this game with a passion that brightens SE as a whole, and the developers who work on this game have built it brick after loving brick. I watched this game go from a few bland looking rocks in space to a fully exploitable solar system. Games like this that really raise the bar aren't just games anymore; They are an artistic marvel, and a testament of how far man kind has come as a species that we can simulate gods majesty all around us in an immersive experience that at this point in history seems one of a kind. What it truly does is paves the way for more to come I should hope.

This game will test your patience, your attrition, and your imagination. It supports the idea of space exploration and its all around just a fun base/vehicle building/exploration game. 

Some suggestions if you do end up playing this game. Firstly give yourself a lot of time to play because you will need it. If you don't have a lot of time to play SE its doubtful you will really be able to dig into the really cool stuff you can accomplish. Second is be picky about your server and be nice to the people who run them. They have to deal with peoples silly problems all day and some people take their frustration of the game out on the people who out of the goodness of their own hearts + love of the game willingly help run these things and do all they can to offer a quality experience. Third is simply play with friends or make friends while playing.

Some of my best gaming experiences have been in SE to the point where its not just a game to me anymore but a load of fond memories and a symbol of a shared human experience that wouldn't be had without so many people who above all love its concept.

SE is a pretty good game, only hampered by it's lack of information.  The games has tons of potential and from what I've seen, you can pretty much create anything you want with the building blocks and automation and programming tools built in.  But just figuring out how it all works will take some time.  The game seems to shoot itself in the foot here, making you fight the game more than the environment.  If you've got the stamina to figure it all out, though, you'll have a great time.  Overall I'd give it a C- for a beginner, A+ once you climb the learning curve.

If you are here for the Vanilla game you might be a bit disappointed, this is no super game. If you are here for a balls to the walls Mod supported game to be really creative in then look no further. This is a blanco canvas, with a huge palette of paints and all the brushes you could wish for to build whatever you feel like and then fool around with it any way you want. Want to build a Death Star and crash it into a planet? Go ahead. Want to build a Dune Buggy and race it like a madman? No problem. Want to arrange a huge multiplayer space battle, just find a bunch of fellow players. Space Engineers lacks the polish of modern AAA games but then it's not an AAA game. What it has in spades is ways for you to be creative and to share your creativity with other players. It's the only thing that counts for an Engineer.

Also a shoutout for Medieval Engineers, The Community Edition. It's SE's lil brother and currently run by a team of dedicated players.

I Found it...

The controls are easy to remember and there is easy to follow tutorials that the game encourages you to watch when opening the game (this can be disabled).

It follows the same trend as most other survival games (spawn, gather basic resources, make crafting station, gather higher tier resources, build better crafting station, expand base) but this one is different, how you go around navigating around a planet or through space is decided by you, use your suit backpack or make a rover or even a spacecraft.

And that is where it gets better, rather than having premade vehicle models that you have to use, you get to build the vehicles yourself (or of course buy some basic ships from stations). this game lets you design and build whatever you want in a 'Scrap Mechanic' esque way, whatever idea you are inspired by can be brought to reality in space engineers.

There is some neat scenarios the game offers aswell as an open solar system in either Sandbox or Survial where you can do what you want.

Unlike most games there is no set 'border' to remain in, you can easily stay planetbound or go off into the deep depths of space far from contact.

Space Engineers supports multiplayer and has many servers that you can play on or even create a private session for your friends to join you on.

There is workshop support and a blueprinting system which allows you to share your creations with others and download the creations of other players.

Relationship status can be increased with factions by completing contracts for discounts in their store, or relationship status can be decreased by attacking ships belonging to the faction.

161 hours into this game (as of the time of this review) and I still picture me having hundreds more hours of entertainment

The possibilities this game offers are endless.

I bought this game around when it released in early access back in 2013 2014. Its been a pain in the ass following development but this game has consistently provided an experience unlike any other. I quit playing after accruing around 2000 hours, the game entered a rough patch in performance optimizations when updating to the newer Direct X. surprisingly i was still seeing content from the YouTubers playing the game so i didnt let the game leave my mind. Coming back to it today i'm amazed with a little modding and setup time its like Minecraft, Elite Dangerous, and D&D like stuff in an almost Garrys Mod sense. Overall touchy but great game Im Excited to see more development of Keens new VRAGE 3.0 Engine i want to see more capabilities in this niche Genre of Survival/Builders.

[h1] My Summary [/h1]
Let me first off by stating that this game doesn’t have a storyline for you to follow. This entire game is based around what the player can do. Personally I do not find playing without NPC mods or QOL mods fun. The range of what you can do in vanilla is decent but when you start adding stuff like NPC Encounters the game just gets bigger and more vast. This game has come a long way since I started playing it in 2014. The game has advanced so much since I started and it seems like it never stops advancing. From the DLC’s, Multiplayer and to the workshop the game just is infinite in what you can do or find. As of this review I have 640+ hours in this game and I still love playing it.

[h1] Should you get SE? [/h1] 
Honestly if you like to build, figure out problems, and just explore in general yes you should get it. The base game is only [u]$20 USD[/u] and yes there is the “Space Engineers Ultimate Edition '' which includes the base game, SE Deluxe, and all the DLC’s for [u]$70 USD[/u]. Personally I believe that $70 for everything is not bad at all but if you want to you can wait till there is a sale. With that If you get bored from building, mining, and thinking then this is not the game for you. This game can take a lot of grinding to build bigger ships and fleets.

AWESOME!!!!!!!! (This was all I could come up with back in Nov 2013, only a month after game release)

Now its nearly May 2016 and I have got over 5200hours playing this game, I still think its awesome.

In the last 2 years or so this game has come a long way from what I remember it was like not long after release. We now have planets to visit and build on as well as a world that is 1Billion K's across to explore. Although, much of it is empty space with asteroids throughout, each and every world can be customised to suit your gaming wishes. There is 100,000's of mods available on the workshop that you can use to make your game experience how you would like it. If you enjoy Star Trek for example, there is many Star Trek themed mods that you could have in your world so you could build the Enterprise or maybe a Klingon Bird of Prey. There is over 200 planets that have been created by the modding community that you could populate your world with. 

The choices of gamemodes suit many different players, Single Player Creative mode where you can build whatever you wish without the need for resources. This is a great mode for designing and building ships or stations for blueprint creation for use in other worlds and also learning about all the functions of the many choices of in-game blocks. Single Player Survival, with this gamemode you can challenge yoursef to find the resources you need to build your hopes and dreams. There are several scenarios to choose from, each with differing setups to start a game, for example the Easy Start Scenarios give you a station on a planet with 3 basic ships to get you started in the game. in the setup for each game you can customise the setup to make it however challenging you want. From inventory size, crafting speeds to settings like pirate drones and even cyberhounds and alien spiders which will attack you or start chewing through blocks on your base to get to you.

Then there is multiplayer, you can host your single player game on your own machine to invite friends to join in, or there is many dedicated servers to choose from. I have been running a dedicated server myself for over 2 years now (spaceengineers.com.au). Now, I will be honest and say the multiplayer Netcode is still a WIP and at times, issues in game will frustrate you to no end. Don't let this put a dampner on how you feel about the game, the developers have stuck to their weekly update schedule and slowly but surely everything is getting better. As with all Alpha development games, some patches can end up breaking the game for some, but be patient as the team will surely have the issues patched up soon.

Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys building, using and showing off their creations. There is a plethora of player creations on the workshop, including blueprints that other players have created that you can build in game. You are only limited in this game by your own imagination. Search for Space Engineers on youtube too, if this review hasn't been enough to convince you, i'm sure some of the fantastic videos of player creations, machinima and the like would be enough to push you over the edge and make you want to buy it.

Hope to see you in game one day, and if you found this review helpful please give it a thumbs up.

This will be the third time I have written a review for this software. I love the IDEA of this software. The premise, the ease of use, the open ended possibilities, etc. are just amazing. After a ridiculous number hours (over 10k) I have spent using this software I still can't recommend it. My review is based on my current belief that this is NOT A GAME. Because of what it is, I have spent a ridiculous amount of time trying to make it into a game that I would like to play, which is a survival game that is not solely combat oriented. 
The modding community has made it more difficult for me to simply walk away from this title, as there are many new mods constantly adding to the game on a daily basis. We all recognize the potential here, and because of the steady flow of mods there is the potential to have one of them trigger that niche mechanic that makes my quest for my best GAME experience a reality. Sadly, that has not happened in the 10 years.
The easiest method of making a play experience that I would love is to make a series of campaign missions. This is where I believe KEEN has really dropped the ball. The original tutorials were replaced with a number of stand alone missions that are unconnected. Each subsequent DLC usually has a single mission or interactive environment associated with them. Why is there no base campaign that runs you through a number of environments and situations in story form? The DLCs could have added more content to the campaign without much difficulty. I'm not asking for a lot here, 4 or 5 inter-connected missions to start with, and then 2-3 missions per DLC would have been fantastic. Throw in the ability to reverse engineer how those missions were made and so many modders would have run away with the mission making this product would have easily been the most popular game on Steam for many of the previous years. 
We did get planets that were never intended to be part of the game, but they are mostly dead lifeless worlds. At best on each world there is one global predator that is actually a recurring NPC, and the biggest threat in space or on the surface are pirate ships and bases that launch waves of drones. Meteorites that always hit the ground leaving hemi-spherical holes in the ground instead of standard shallow craters (come on guys the ground is far harder than you give it credit to being), that if used will slowly degrade your game experience because of the extensive ground deformations. The only thing in the game that should do significant damage to the ground are Drills. While I'm at it there should be concrete, or some building material that is made of the the most common to mine material on every planet-like body other than refined metals. 
I really wish this product had a finished game as part of it. I wish that planets had animals, and potentially other inhabitants not just the ones that are trying to kill you. I would like to see the ground on planets nearly impervious to weapons fire or explosives. Every time I sit down in this environment dreaming for thousands of hours to make this into a game that I would like to play ... I wish it could be more than just more disappointment. The amount of unlocked potential is more than the pathetic quest for liquid water, which modders have made and has not added anything to this being a game. To me games are fun, and while I can amuse myself to a small degree with all the what-ifs to this product I still can't call it a game.

There are a ton of space shooter games out there that simulate several kinds of space flight. They allow you to be merchants, pirates, fighters, traders and so on. Some space shooters allow you to travel to other worlds while others let you explore the expansive galaxy.

Space Engineers takes space flight to a whole new level of space flight. This is not just a game, it's a creation tool. Space Engineers, not only allows you to fly through space and battle it out with your enemies, but this game lets you also "DESIGN" your ship the way you want it, exactly how YOU want it. Space flight is no longer about just ships, it's about designing and showing off your ship designing skills. You can design fighters, freighters, destroyers, titans, carriers, even space stations that take HOURS to travel the entire station. You can even design fighter ships inside the freighters or space stations, so you have something to defend your stations or freighters. Not only can you build your fighters, but you can also travel to asteroids and drill for minerals to design stronger materials to make better ships/stations for yourself.

Space Engineers also lets you do either single edit where you just edit the ship on your own without others watching you, or you can have others join you online, either as allies and team work your stations, ships, destroyers, or you can battle it out against your friends to see who will have the best fighter ships and who can build the better ships.

Along with that, if you think you have designed a good ship, you can post your ship creations on the Steam site and you can also check out other designs that others have made and see how they designed their ships. (UPDATE = As of now there are over 1,000 pages of Workshop items to view and download. Ships, stations, animations, asteroids, destroyers, mechanical devices, there's just no limit to what you can do.)

Space Engineers is no longer about just space flight. It's about taking the entire "Build Your Space Empire" to a whole new level of build and destroy. Build it, design it, add on to it, tweak it, create it, and use it, any way you see fit. Space Engineers is no longer about the game, it's all about "YOU". What ship do YOU want to design, and how will you control the space empire? Space Engineers, you know you wanna be one... ^_^ (The game was still in Beta when this review was given, but during this time, they had updated the game so that you can do online battles or coop, how ever you want to play online)

I wrote a really long review updated over many years but all you really need to know is that Space Engineers is marmite: If you love it you'll spend thousands of hours in it, despite the initial steep learning curve, and the shallow sandbox beyond, you'll keep coming back for the ongoing updates, design freedom, and the server shenanigans.

Keen Software House remains unparalleled with their dedication towards Space Engineers since its conception. They released two weekly updates until the game was released from early access, with one of them being entirely dedicated to bug fixes. By no means was it an easy process, but I challenge anyone to argue that larger companies have done the same (Looking at you Bethesda, Electronic Arts, Activision, Blizzard, and Ubisoft). They also didn't stoop to the lowest form of modern game development and add advantageous micro transactions.

This "was" an awesome game that allowed you to build creatively & build just about anything you could imagine. Then the DLC flood hit, and suddenly there was a pay wall to be allowed access to core building components. hidden behind the cloak of "don't you want to support the Devs?".

I have no issue with supporting Dev's, but the DLC flood that locked away core building components behind the pay wall was too much.

So as the Dev's got greedy, I stopped playing. But sadly so many players have been willing to dump loads of money into DLC after DLC just to have a full set of core parts for building, the game has gotten worse instead of better.

Space Engineers isn't an MMO where you might expect to pay a lot over time. But Keen seem to think it should be with the flood of paid DLC they keep pumping out.

So as once I could have recommended this as an awesome game, I can no longer do that with a clear conscience. . .

Just wanted to warn everyone about Keen House Software (KHS).
This company has questionable practices that border on crowdfunding through Early Access.
The result is that out of their four main games, Miner Wars, Miner Wars 2081, Space Engineers and Medieval Engineers, three have been dumped, abandoned and totally unfinished. The forth, Space Engineers, is in a steep decline into developmental obscurity.

For those that were most vocal about the criminal way Early Access (EA) customers were duped and dumped, they have engaged non-paid moderators that abuse their position and hide behind a wall of total authority. They will ban you for totally personal reasons, in some cases, permanently, from their game forums. You will be banned for 'complaining too much' or 'bumping old threads'. And that would be ok, if they were consistent with these rulings. But they are not. They will pick and choose whom they don't like and then ban them without a warning or a right of reply.

KHS and it's forum moderators have a long history of customer abuse. They will draw you in with promises of a 'wonderful' game and leave you with a buggy mess at best. And god help you if you complain too much.

So, a word of warning, don't ever purchase from this company.

A word to the Steam administrators, KHS is abusing the EA system and using it as a crowdfunding platform for it's other non-related projects. May I suggest that they never be allowed to use the EA system again.

Space engineers was an incredible game and was worth every penny, 3-4 years ago.
The game has been for the better part of the time left abandoned, slow burning by the developers.
The worst part is it's not their fault (the devs) about the lack of new content over the best part of 4 years. This is due to the scope of game functioning as a fancy physics engine with the ability to build space ships. The game has polished inventory, controls and UI/UX. It's just old.

Currently the game recives block content as DLC and while it's mostly cosmetic i consider it dead file weight. The game has an economy system, and has missions quests and tons of other cool features but they all lack cohesion.
Recently bots were introduced to the game, and now you can automate certain tasks with fancy AI blocks.
The problem with this game is a lack of actual things to do, for casual environments. Single player is a simple dead end with very few challanges and boils down to "how quickly i set up my grinder pit"

The game has an extremely low amount of actuall things to do, besides sandbox endless play. You build a miner get materials. Build a small outpost base and from there you're set.

The "challenges" are theese random encounters, well due to the way this game works fighting them makes no sense, it's way easier to just spam your players body at them to try to get on board stop the ship, then slowly grind down your way to the power sources, disable the ship then hack all the turets and throw it in your grinder.

Fighting theese ships is purely for fun as it's both a risk to your resources AND makes you loose on your investment. The quests are boring and very limited. 
Buy it on a sale for at most $20 for maybe 100 hours of play.

A very fun game that is definitely worth buying. Even in singleplayer, it's fun for hours. But multiplayer is the best experience. I really appreciate the large base of players who create mods and the developers are constantly working on improving and expanding the content in the game. The high hardware requirements are a bit annoying but given the nature of the game, that's understandable.

Final Edit: Something didn't sit right with me about the review. It turns out not only did I use a Gyro Override (which flipped my vehicle) but Tires can have nearly every attribute manipulated including steering angle and suspension.

This made the game far more enjoyable and opened my eyes to its potential.

Does it still feel like bland planet generation? Yes.
Does it take too long to get any interactivity outside of construction? Yes.
Is the game saved by mods? Yes.

So it's a coin toss but no longer a irredeemable. This just comes off as one of those things you will love or hate.

Give it a shot and decide for yourself.

Progression seems to be punished. There are no enemies, no animals, no ambience. Just dirt and you with ineffective vehicles that are obtuse in design and prohibitive in nature. 

This is just a mess.
I intend to never play this again.

Not worth your time...  I always wanted to try this game out, as I heard good things about it. However, 10 years of development, and this is still pretty much someone's highschool prototype project, and not a viable game that anybody can enjoy. Of course, for a very few with whom this "game" clicks, they will enjoy it. However, the survival mechanics are frustrating, the progression is shallow. And after 40 hours of play, the only satisfaction I get out of this game is when I reload the save file to undo whatever happened after something horrible has gone with game physics.

Overall, this game is perfect for individuals who like to play in "creative" mode and then smash things together while watch them go boom. For others who are looking for a "game", there is none here...

Its really, really bad. If you only ever play games in creative mode you might like it. I thought with a survival mode there would be some structure, but it just feels like an empty sandbox. I like space settings, I like building games, but I also like having something to do, some sense of purpose. This game just doesn't have that. I hesitate to even call it a game.

Getting started is a complete mess. The tutorial videos are tedious and not very helpful. Far too long on camera and movement, then jumping to quick select, but I don't need to know how to setup my toolbar if you haven't covered what blocks or tools are yet. Survival mode feels like an afterthought so don't expect much help there. If you try jumping right into the game, maybe learning as you play, just expect disappointment.

If you try to jump right into the intro to survival scenario, they do give you some tasks to help you learn. Unfortunately about half will get stuck on the first task. This happens if they go to oxygen first (closest task on the left). You will be tasked to refill your oxygen, but you cannot. See the base starts with an incomplete conveyor block and until that block is built you cannot refill oxygen. Instructions on your first block repairs are a task slightly further away. The specific block build needed isn't even covered at all. At least if you go to the closet task on the right first to refill health and energy it mentions that it isn't connected to oxygen.

Its really annoying because it doesn't take much thought to come up with a better intro scenario. Let me arrive on a ship bringing the parts for the base, build a starter base to learn about basic construction, power, oxygen, mining, refining, while the ship provides a safe starting environment and supplies. Then teach me about ship construction with a little mining vessel. If you imagine anything like this is in the game you are mistaken. 

If you instead play First Jump you will realize how they things you might build, might be incorporated into some kind of really light scenario. Its a really short and light scenario and serves as a crude intro to controls. It will at least actually explain how to repair a block when you need to. It will also introduce you to combat and just how bad that is. Though don't be surprised when it asks you to fight or run early on and you realize it hasn't even introduced fighting yet. How can you be teaching at the level of how to move and interact, turn  on lights, and then forget you never mentioned picking up, equipping or firing a gun.

[h1][u]UPDATE[/u][/h1]

I've had a couple of years of pretty steady play in this game and have even delved into running my own dedicated server for this game. With that said, I'm adding to my review.

What I said in the original review stands, but I would like to add that the workshop for this game adds layers to the experience that I hadn't yet taken advantage of.
Though not required, I have since purchased ALL of the DLC for this game, I simply love 'eye candy' and that's exactly what the DLCs add to this game.
The workshop is a very sufficient alternative to buying the DLCs if you don't wish to buy them, but know this: Some of the blueprints on the workshop have been made with these DLCs and if you don't own them, then your downloaded blueprints may be rendered completely useless.
This is what partially encouraged me to get the DLCs as I could afford to do so.

The Space Engineers Modding Community is awesome.
I've added numerous mods/scripts to the game over the last 2 yrs. and the majority of them have made life just a bit easier in the SE world, but as with anything on the net, be careful what you download. Many of these mods are very useful, but there are also 'sloppy' mod makers out there that just throw their mods together with no real testing beforehand, and as such, can cause problems.
Read the descriptions carefully and if a mod does NOT have a description, I advise that you ignore it and move on, no matter how 'cool' it may look. (Personal experience speaking here)
The lack of a decent description is a clear indicator of a lazy author and/or a 'lazy-made' mod.
Steer clear of those to avoid potential issues.
I've come to prefer 'Quality of Life' (QoL) mods as they generally add to the experience without drastically changing the basic vanilla gameplay, at least not that much at any rate.

I've compiled a collection of my favorite Space Engineers mods and I will share the link here to help out any of you possible new players that may want to try some decent and well-made mods out in your games.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2835900032
