The game knows what it is and is good at what it does. 

If you're looking for a Minecraft-like game where you can sink thousands of hours into building colossal vehicles and heavy machinery block-by-block and then using it all to demolish the environment, this game will definitely scratch that itch. 

This game also had way more opportunities for vehicle-to-vehicle combat than I was expecting, which was a pleasant surprise. 

There is certainly a learning curve to the UI and controls, but the game points you to some good tutorial videos and there are two tutorial scenarios that give you a firm grasp of the basics. 

It goes on sale pretty often, so if you see it 75% or even 50% off, I would recommend snagging it - even without the DLC, you'll definitely get your money's worth in terms of content.

EDIT:
Some tips for beginners doing their first single-player custom game on Survival mode:

Go to the Advanced Options:
1. Disable 'Block Destruction' (enabled by default) - collision damage is pretty nutty in this game, so if you leave this turned on, expect to crash and burn... a lot.
2. Set 'Meteor Impacts' to 'Armageddon' - meteor storms are actually a GOOD thing because they leave random ore deposits behind, some of which are normally extremely difficult to find such as Uranium and Platinum.
3. Do NOT disable 'Voxel Destruction!' Turning it off will prevent you from being able to mine resources! 
4. Enable 'Spawn Wolves' and 'Spawn Spiders' if you want to be attacked by wild animals :D
(both are disabled by default)
5. Max out inventory size and the speed & efficiency settings for tools and equipment if you want the game to go faster.
Good base game, but mods improve it a lot.

I loved this game but it's kinda pointless. Perhaps I just have too many hours in this game but I feel like there's no reason to play. You can construct a massive station that can deploy a bunch of drones that can harvest whatever resources you want and create a massive ships capable of eradicating entire asteroids in mere seconds, but why? In games like Factorio you build an ever expanding factory to fight off the local fauna and build a ship to get off the planet. During your play through you are working towards a tangible goal. There's also many sub goals like researching the next set of items and creating a new assembly line to produce a new component. These motivate you to keep expanding and keep playing. There isn't an equivalent in SE. You do whatever cause you feel like it. It's a great sandbox. If that's all your after then you'll have a good time with this game. If you want substance, however, you'll be disappointed.

Space




















































































































































































Engineers

Space Engineers offers an enthralling open universe where the possibilities seem as endless as space itself. This game, with its boundless opportunities for exploration and creation, has become a favourite of mine. Here's my detailed review, delving into what makes it a remarkable experience, as well as some of its downsides.

The Good:

Exploration and Creativity: Space Engineers thrives on the open world it presents. With a vast universe to explore, you'll never run out of places to go or things to do. Whether you're flying through space, building bases on moons or ice asteroids, or crafting colossal space stations to house your fleet of smaller ships, the game encourages unbridled creativity and adventure.

Multiplayer Delight: The multiplayer experience is where Space Engineers truly shines. Teaming up with friends to create, explore, and even indulge in comical antics is a joy. Watching your friends' characters flop around in zero-gravity while using jet-packs adds a whimsical element that keeps the game lighthearted and entertaining.

Robust Game Creation Settings: Space Engineers offers an extensive suite of customisation options, making it perfect for those who prefer a non-combat focus. You can tailor the game to your liking, enhancing the creation and expansion aspects of your journey.

Optimisation: Despite years of development, Space Engineers remains impressively stable and polished. Even on a mid-range PC, the game runs smoothly. It's a testament to the developers' commitment to optimising the experience for a wide range of systems. Notably, the game also runs flawlessly on Linux, even on unsupported systems, thanks to compatibility with Proton 8.

The Not-So-Good:

Price and DLCs: The game's initial price of £15.50 is reasonable given its calibre. However, the main issue arises with the plethora of DLCs available. While these add cosmetic items and support the developers, the cost can quickly add up. Some players may prefer purchasing the complete game with all DLCs or none at all. With the extensive list of DLCs, it can result in an additional cost of £55.86, potentially even more if more DLCs are introduced. This might be a deterrent for some players, even those deeply enamoured with the game.

Conclusion:

In summary, Space Engineers is a game I would wholeheartedly recommend to anyone looking for an exciting, creative, and multiplayer-friendly experience. With over 100 hours played, I still find myself captivated by its universe. If you have friends to share this journey with, it elevates the experience even further.

When it comes to DLCs, they are optional, and your enjoyment of the game can be complete without them. Personally, I'm selective about the DLCs, choosing those that offer functional items. However, the choice of whether to purchase them or not is entirely yours.

Ultimately, if you decide to embark on this space-faring adventure, I hope you have as much fun as I have had with this game. Game on and explore the expanses of space to your heart's desire.

Space is ok, the planetary side of things is a total mess.

Features that should be baked in are left up to the community to fix by scripting.  

Want to make a rover with an adjustable height? Sorry the wheels no longer talk to the ship when on pistons. There's a script for that but braking isn't possible. Not to mention that attaching one wheel suspension to a piston if fine, then trying to attach another one further along the craft just will not allow you to orient it properly. 

Nix the extending suspension, and just build a non adjustable height rover? You better avoid slopes because the rover then loves to runaway going downhill, then flip over, or alternatively rip out the under carriage and explode. Going up hill is no better.

Do an atmospheric flying miner you say? Good luck staying level. Trying to mine while flying is frustrating. Bump the wrong pixel, and flip over tumble and explode. 

If you like spending hours researching why things don't work the way you expect maybe give it a try.  I regret not only the purchase, but the time spent trying to make sense of the mechanics.

I wanted to review this at 100 hours of game but it felt I knew too little.
At 200 hours I can say I explored most of the immediate game potential.
I say immediate because if you want, it can last thousand hours if you get into timers, programmable and AI blocks and so on.

Basically the game is pointless, there is raw materials and tools and stuff to refine it. Once you get that in the first hours of play, i'ts up to you where you want to go.
There is no story beside some short pre-scripted missions in single player only.

You can build whatever you want, then go in space and colonize asteroids or build flying space stations or battle fortresses.

They put into it some REALLY CLEVER buid blocks like hinges, rotors, timers, merging blocks, blueprints of the stuff you build and printers to build it back and others that allow you to build machines yourself like automatic drilling platforms or whatever. The use of these blocks really makes this games for those who want to actually engineer solutions to problems and invent weird stuff.

That said, the game it's pretty fun, expecially with friends, if you like the pointless building of stuff after you grasp  all the game mechanics and stuff to get there (which for me, even it's a steep learning curve, it was major part of the fun).

Now to the dark side.
The devs are a little lazy about community bug feedback and there are some nasty bugs around since years and reported multiple times which aren't getting solved. Lot of requests by the community doesn't get attention and the game suffers from crashes from time to time and you will soon or later resort to the modding community, which is the real strength after the dev work, because it's enormous and well done. lot of people liked this game and added a ton of mods for it to do almost anything.

For the discounted price it's almost a thievery, this game is really good and bearing the developer problems it's annoying but the game is so good that you will keep playing anyway

This one's a little rough. I absolutely love this game, it is near and dear to my heart. I met my fiance on this game, moved 3,000 miles to be here with him. It has vastly gone downhill. The developers used to pump out all this new content, guns, missiles, planets, graphics improvements, (usable, as in functional and does something different than the current-in game) blocks. Years later, we've seen thruster reskins, new skins, and minor decoration updates masked as "Major Updates".

When did you give up Keen? When did you say "Ahh yes, this game is complete. The players can now be on a planet, mine said planet, build ship to leave planet, and exist in space." The AI update was... A joke. It added some blocks that are kinda okayish AI wise but are really all and all just point-to-point gps "i go here, now i go here." You still have to tell it what to do, or program something to tell it what to do. 

The (first) warfare update was okayish. They added some new guns, the artillery gun and the autocannon. But that's it gun wise. Still no big daka dakas. No large battleship cannons to put on my massive battleship without needing to rely on 50 mods that may or may not exist tomorrow. 

There's no ultimate goal, there's no AI to interact with, the multiplayer is vast and laggy. Singleplayer with extra steps and you can't have your own custom playstyle. I'm just over hoping the next update is going to be a big one, one that actually changes the scope of the game. Something that makes me excited to hit the play button again and see what the devs have cooked up for me. I'm just   o v e r   i  t.

I hope you guys can get out of whatever rut you're in right now, because its hurting the game and killing your existing playerbase, not to mention anyone who wants to try the game, or has been waiting for it to be "complete". Still feels like an Early Access title at full release years later /=

Yet another "Major Update" that just adds skins, including the VETERAN skin which was only meant for those who have been with the game since the beginning, which is a huge spit in the face for over half your playerbase. Love it.

My friend was AFK and i decided to take one of our 2 ships to go mining (This is on Earth by the way) so as i was mining for ice for our hydrogen engine for some reason the aircraft had a complete meltdown and wouldn't respond to any inputs, and no it wasn't a weight issue or a thruster issue the best we can determine is its something with the gyroscope because it has happened before and the only to fix it is by overriding it and praying, which resulted me in rolling down the mountain and banging it up pretty bad. I then decided my best bet was to take my newest ship i built for mining up to the mountain again to get back the ice i lost in the result of my previous expedition, to this point everything was smooth, i had my ice and was returning to base, and then a really bad rainstorm set in, which resulted in loss of visibility, as I was getting closer to base i failed to see one of our windmills which resulted in a high speed collision ripping out the underneath of my ship and flipping it on its roof (and again i lost all my material because it destroyed my storage containers), by this point I was very upset but I knew my ship was salvageable and I could repair it and get it going in no more than a hour, blown away by the sequence of events that had just happened i decided to text my friend about it all, while it was still raining and with the noise of thunder and lightning in the back ground, as i was explaining the lovely time i was having on this game my character GOT STRUCK BY LIGHTNING. Just as I figured all I can see is the  new wreckage of my ship strewn about and completely destroyed my ship with just the cockpit and a couple engines left. [h1]2023: State of the Game[/h1]
[h2]So close yet so far.[/h2]
   Is it a game yet, I ask myself after another year of inactivity. I download the updates, and start fresh. And every time the answer is, "No, not quite."
   It's called Space Engineers, but they want you to start on a planet. You spend 5-10 hours mining stone to get a the beginnings of a base, that has no storage, because storage, rovers, and ships are locked behind cobalt, a rare mineral that is too deep for your ore detectors to see.
   You spend 20-40 hours finding minerals, and upgrading your base to be capable of building a space ship. You spend another 10-15 hours designing and building the ship to get to space. You then abandon all that hard work, and your rewarded with having to find all the mineral again, this time, in space.
You can participate in fixed and empty economy, trading, or doing the most boring missions to earn money. You can fight computer generated factions of space pirates that have unlimited resources, including ammo, that will hunt you down, and spend as much time as is required to destroy every computerized component of your ship or base while firing continuously, while you had to earn, mine, refine and craft every bullet that you use. Leaving you at square one.
   I feel like a beaten lover. I keep finding myself attracted to these games, that are 10-15% away from great. As if, somehow, if I just loved them more, or kept showing my support, that they would change, and stop mistreating me.
This game has the capability of being wonderful, but as is, it's vast, empty, and uncaring of your time. It's better with friends. It's better when PVP is well organized. It's better with mods. But as a base game, a survival game where progress is centered around building larger and more complex vehicles, and smaller and more specialized vehicles, it falls flat, even 800 hours, and ten years later.
Space Engineers, we love you. Be the game we know you can be. Stop coming home drunk and expecting us to clean up your mess.

The progression may be self instigated, but man it is satisfying to have everything come together to make your very own, personalized, well-oiled, optimized, intergalactic enterprise. Adds some good wrinkles to your brain.

And mods seriously change up the game loop. You can change what is usually a rather barren sandbox into a bustling solar system with just like 10 mods. For people with potato computers, this is 100% not for you. Your system has to have high-end graphics and a pretty beefy CPU. Compatibility is also a bitch for this game. It won't work if you're on a Mac. I'd go for at least a Windows 10 i7-6700 3.60 GHZ CPU if you plan on getting this. If you've met these requirements, it's a fairly decent game. Updates are actually pushed pretty frequently, fixing a lot of bugs while also having a high chance of creating new ones. 

There is a lot of annoying mechanics that the game has that are there to intentionally make the game challenging, such as components not being able to move through small grid conveyors. Most of the challenge of this game comes mainly from ship building and designing things opposed to actually doing contracts and fighting. The ship building mechanics are fine if you're okay with the vanilla limitations, and some blocks are a bit jank especially in the physics area, such as rotors, hinges, wheels, and pistons.

Multiplayer is extremely unoptimized, and you will encounter frequent lag, rubberbanding, and connection difficulties when playing on a server beyond maybe 2-3 people, especially if you're hosting the server yourself.

Keen Software House themselves are notoriously bad with PR, their moderation team in the Discord banning people for posting harmless gifs and calling them idiots when they refuse to listen to the rules while simultaneously bending the knee to anyone who gets offended over words like "retarded" when being used in a general statement. Definitely lives up to the neckbeard Discord moderator stereotype. Furthermore, they emphasize greed and bland DLC content over prioritization of making the base game less lackluster and optimization. Keen at the moment is comparable to a distant cousin of EA.

Overall, it's a decently fun PVE or PVP game to play if you're playing with friends, but if you're on your own in a survival world hoping for a challenging PVE experience, you will not get it from this game without mods.

It's a really awesome basis for a style of game I wish this was more like. $20 seems very appropriate if you have friends to play it with. Probably worth a try if any of the building seems interesting to you, or if you just wanna make the most accurate Cylon Basestars and UNSC frigates you can and have them fight. To its credit, this game really does seem to be always improving, but I have some gripes related to that. 
For the longest time, this game performed painfully, both due to my build and some optimization issues. Now with a machine that could probably easily handle the resource demands of Space Engineers, I have a hard time looking at how much space the game takes up. "30+ GB? Since when was SE so huge?" 
Don't get me wrong, I think this game has interesting content for many hours, but I wonder if I burn out on this game sooner than other games. You can use any spaceship you can imagine and build, then revel in its glorious destruction and mutilation, but what next? 
Being so much larger on my storage drives without being able to fundamentally change the gameplay much puts Space Engineers at much higher chance of getting uninstalled after time away than other games.

LATEST UPDATE BROKE ONE OF THE GAMES MOST POPULAR MODS AND MADE MOST SERVERS UNPLAYABLE. I will update my review as soon as it is fixed and I can play the game again. Edit: to give them credit, they did fix the game breaking bug within 24 hours.

It feels a lot like minecraft, the main draw is the limitless sandbox, but once you beat the ender dragon you're pretty much done, it doesn't get any harder. If you go into this game with that sandbox mindset it is downright incredible, but if you go into it wanting to build bigger and bigger ships to kill bigger and bigger things then you're going to fairly quickly reach the limit unless you start doing custom stuff(it does have workshop and there are some pretty neat mods). And unlike minecraft, there are no big servers where you can just join and play a different gamemode, I'm not sure if the game can handle it or not, but there aren't enough players to find out. Your best bet is to find a community that has their own events or play one of the larger servers. My personal favorite is the draconis expanse server which is very well run and adds a lot of depth imo.

The sounds in this game are plain terrible, so many sound bugs when using realistic setting. And even when they are working as intended, it's like it's coming through the cheapest headphone cable you can find, there is almost a scratch to it. You'll probably just turn it all the way down or off.

I'm recommending this game because despite the problems I have found a lot of fun in it, but someone with different tastes might find that the problems are not worth it. I'd pay triple this price for an updated space engineers with an engine that doesn't break so easily and properly done sounds, but that is never going to happen, this game is not likely to receive many, if any, major updates going forward. It's an incredible foundation with amazing opportunities, but set in a pretty lifeless world. The mods are also great and can make up for some of the games shortcomings.

Giving a positive review too offset all the brain deads that think buying the game makes them entiteld to free updates and content for life and for some reason also think game developers make games out of the goodness of their hearts... So kids. It's a business and they need to keep the employees paid. that's how this works.

I like this game but the lack of content makes it hard to keep playing. Sure I get to make any kinds of vehicles or contraptions I want with a wide range of blocks to flex my creativity and problem solving, but SE does not provide many obstacles for me to tackle with my builds. There's no reason for me to build a battleship or program an auto missile. There's no reason for me to build an orbital satellite or explore endlessly into space with an exploration cruiser. There's no goal, no enemy to fight - really there's nothing much to do BUT design and build.

If that's your cup of tea, SE will provide endless fun with many many opportunities to spend long hours fretting over minor details and the function of certain blocks. You can do the math and figure out how much thrust you need to launch a certain load weight into orbit, and you can build and design anything you can dream up of. But if you want to apply these things - well that's where this game falls short.

You have been warned.

I didn't really play the game a lot back when I got it in 2016, but as time has gone on I've really become more interested and invested into this game by it's incredible modding community. There are so many core mods that fundamentally change and add so much to this game, and thinking about it now, Space Engineers is really only kept active by the hard work of people tackling poorly optimized systems to turn this game into what it likely should have been. The base game itself would be okay if this game was marketed as a building simulator, but it is almost entirely just building. Nothing else. It's shown as an exploration and problem solving game, but the only problems are what you create for yourself and the shitty server lag. There's no real depth or excitement beyond building things. It would be a long dead pile of abandonware by now without the Workshop.

Modders have given this game a full fledged AI rewrite with dynamic difficulty and unique encounters with hundreds of custom made ships and stations, a much needed combat system overhaul, custom worlds and much more three dimensional challenges. Not to mention the insurmountable quantity of custom blocks, items, scripts, scenarios, and downright awesome builds. SE is MADE by mod makers at this point, and has been for years now.

And now most of the largest core systems that the modding community needs has been turned off arbitrarily, with no warning, betas, or any other kind of assistance. I know its entirely within Keen's right to make such changes, however it really is a fat spit in the face to all the mod makers and enjoyers to make a rushed, half baked pile of garbage "celebration" in the face of all the effort the community has gone to realize the game Keen couldn't, or wouldn't provide.  These people are the reason you are still turning a profit for fuck sakes! Sorry, you can't have your community-made content that generates no direct revenue to us, but you can have two blocks (one of which is fucking bugged as I'm writing this of course) and a flare gun. Also you can spend $2 to buy two skins they gave for free years ago and one random new one. Cosmetics. Asking for money as an anniversary. Honestly, modders should be asking them for money for the amount of stuff they put up with, especially when it comes to arbitrary changes.

The route Keen has taken on this unfinished game has been like a mobile game. "Here, a semi-working product, now lets add more paid cosmetic blocks than there are in the base game." This is what they've done, and it's getting old. There is still so little optimization for the kind of gameplay that was envisioned for this game, that modded singleplayer is really the only way to get good performance and large ship battles together. 

There has been videos and demonstrations of that a Space Engineers 2 would look like, and while it seems interesting and has some improvements over things like voxels in game, I honestly don't think I'll be picking it up if something like it ever releases from Keen. Much to how other people predict, I too believe they would likely squander it like they have done this game.

There was a lot of potential in SE's vision, and I truly do enjoy this game, but it really is getting worse and worse as time goes on.

Keen, please fix. -Mynxellon

[h2]This game is really good however the survival progression is very short once you know what your doing.[/h2]

This is because in survival you need to collect the resources and materials to build anything but once you build a good mining, a good welding, a good cutting, and a decent combat ship for the very very rare space pirate. There is no point in continuing to play survival mode. You might as well just switch to creative after that.

The Creative side of the game is great however, I have zero complaints for that. Although I like building things for a reason. I could build a very large ship capable of holding and sending out smaller resource collecting ships. But why? What could I do with that ship? I guess I could collect a ton of resources. but why? Once I realized that the answer to that was almost nothing. I completely stopped playing. I do have many hours in this game yes. and honestly I don't know where most of them came from but all I know is that I enjoyed every single one.

I don't mind all the DLC, mainly because they are all really good. However there is just nothing to do with the things you build. Yes there are pvp servers but I feel like most of the player base does not play on those so I never really played them. [i] I also don't like getting all my stuff destroyed and stolen while i'm offline. [/i] Yes you could collect a bunch of stuff but to build what? I just wish there was a purpose to the things I build and the weapons I add to them instead of just building them to build them and shoot them at some very easy AI.

This game is really good but I don't see any pve or survival update coming anytime soon due to the DLC's being the main focus. So I shall leave this game a not recommend review [i] I wish steam had a neutral option for reviews.[/i] and I wish the devs the best of luck with any future projects they decide to work on.

This game is like Lego. If you enjoy building your own fun, whether by following instructions or goofing off, there's a good chance you'll get a kick out of Space Engineers. With that said, this is not a "game." The campaigns and stuff are not the meat of the product; there's nothing to do that you don't establish yourself. The addition of AI ships and stations and all that certainly provides a measure of variety and randomness, but most of what you do will probably be self-directed. There's no mission, no endpoint, unless you make it yourself.

I happen to enjoy creating scenarios and screwing around with world editing. If that sounds like fun to you, this is a solid purchase.

I like this game, and I would recommend it if you enjoy RTS and space-based games. It's very themeic, endless customisation, and overall a pretty cool game.

One major gripe I have with it is the Warscore system. It's essentially this: you have two 'civs', Civ A versus Civ B. Civ A is a colossal, multiplanetary, robot-driven, hivemind empire. It hates organics, and wants to purge the galaxy. Civ B is a smaller, democracy-based, pacifist empire. Easy game, really.

But in the declaration of war that Civ A has to sign, they have to state the terms of this war. I'm not sure why (aside from game-balance), but this purging, killer robot has to state which planets he wants to take and strip of life. So he does: all of them.

However, that's too much! See, each planet has a certain currency of "warscore" behind it. You can only afford small amounts. So, the killer-genocide machine says "Ok, I'll take...5 planets." he can afford 5.

He does it with ease, and at the end of the war, Civ B accepts surrender, and cedes the planets. Now, it'd be even easier to take Civ B, but the war system has pulled another neat trick: A PEACE TREATY FOR 10 YEARS PRIOR TO THE WAR!

So, while the game lets you create a hivemind, genocide machine, who's mission it is to purge organic life, and can't even hold diplomacy with them, it also tells you that while this machine has no respect for organic life, it does have respect for:
-How many planets they "should" take at a time- wouldn't want to let this end too quickly now, right?
-Peace treaties, because while we are purging their population on other planets, it'd be barbaric to declare war again!

It's a very silly system for war, but also a big system in the game. You can get perks to make things cheaper, but even with all that, it still takes too much warscore for you to Blitzkreig an entire civilization off the galaxy.

7/10- good but the warscore system is quite silly

Once you get past how to find the various ores (get your drill out and fly around with extra hydrogen tanks) and control eccentricities it's lots of fun.  Or as others have said it's like mine craft in space.

Allows creativity to flow with creations, lets you fight on land and in space, lets you build factories, create vehicles to do all sorts of things, have shootouts, it is coop, pvp, and pretty fun overall

The main issue to overcome here is literally just user-error, I promise, this will become more apparent the longer you play, be it construction of a vehicle, or construction of a mod list and so-on, always ponder: am I doing this **** right? 

Currently running 305ish mods in conjunction with each other, it all be functioning smoothly for single-player/multi-player, just so people get a rough idea of how far you can push it, the star system still loads up in 2-3 minutes and has barely any errors. 

Takes the term "sandbox game" to a new level, scripts are your friend and there are a lot of user-created ones that work and will make your lives 1000% easier. 

This is NOT a game to play without using mods, you are just reducing the overall experience you could be having by leaving out countless features that enhance the game.

If it doesn't exist then you can make it yourself and add it, there are a plethora of tools available to make this easier, as well. 

The modding community for this is unlike any other, truly out of this world, endless support and tutorials for everything you could ever need; modelling, textures, in-game scripting help, ect... All available through discord servers steam guides and github, where people are usually available to answer any questions.  

I'll save you some time and effort and just say, if something requires another mod to run, it needs to be ABOVE that mod in your mod list for singleplayer/multiplayer. 
As an example, if something requires weaponcore to run, you need to put that mod ABOVE weaponcore in the list. Not everyone gets that memo and I feel like it is genuinely one of the most important things that I learned far too late.

Honestly? One of the best games I've ever played. It's not very expansive, it doesn't have a lot of direction, and there isn't much to explore, especially without mods. And yet, I've never played a game as committed to its physics and mechanics, that allowed you to have so much control over what you build. It is nothing short of remarkable. If they gave a little more direction - not even missions or anything like that, but better scenarios with developed factions and more places to explore, then this game would be near perfect. And most anything that the game lacks is present in the incredible modding community. Mods sure don't make up for a company's mistakes in a game, but it absolutely makes the game that much more enjoyable, and Keen have been pretty helpful and encouraging with the modding community, especially compared to a lot of games of similar caliber. Overall, I don't think I've played a game with such great flaws yet such incredible strengths. Definitely worth the $20.

I love/hate this game! I love it's features and the ability to build nearly anything you can imagine. That it has a creative mode that allows you to work out your designs before spending many hours building them in survival mode, which mode is great to have all on it's own (survival mode that is). There is so much to do in this game that I found myself spending several hours doing things when it felt like just a few minutes had passed. Which brings me to the part I hate about this game - the learning curve! Wow. It has a significant learning curve that in some areas seems like the "curve" is a straight line going up! I just want to take a moment and recognize the many players who have helped me get a handle on this game - even though they are not aware of doing so. Players like Beeblebum who made some tutorial videos you can access on YouTube. Also Splitsie who's tutorial videos that are now some 5 years old are still solid examples to follow and get into this game. Kanajashi has some very good example videos as well. There are MANY others who spend great effort and time to do this for new players, with great cost to themselves in time and effort (spending all that time in the game specifically to record demonstrations and then more time and effort in editing it all down so a new player can digest it) - I don't think these people get enough credit for all that they give of themselves, and that it's all for free on YouTube! 

Once you get a handle on things, especially the simple things like knowing to hold the Control key while clicking the left mouse button in order to get the text input for things like specifying the number or percentage of the movement of a piston for example, I think it was Splitsie whom mentioned this in one of his videos. That was a game changer for me at that time! THANK YOU SPLITSIE! Where was I, oh yea, once you get a handle on things this game can really become an environment to get lost in. It's beautifully done, when you are immersed in the game time fly's by, as I said before, hours seem like minutes.

I have found one thing that I just don't get, maybe it's just me, but sometimes I get real heavy lag in my game, but only when I'm connected to the internet. Once I've disconnected the internet and play "offline" I never get that lag. Even though I tend to play in the games setting of "offline" as long as I'm actually connected to the internet at all it will eventually cause a lag in my game that requires me to exit and come back in, only to get that lag again in a few minutes. Never seems to happen if I'm physically disconnected from the internet.

I tend to write books when commenting - even when commenting in a YouTube channel, so I apologize for going on and on ... and on. Just get this game, find some tutorials on YouTube (the people I've mentioned have great and simple to follow ones) and get to becoming a great Space Engineer! (I'm still working on that last part myself - a long, long way yet to go, but that's just me.)

this is a love/hate game - at times I love it, and other times I hate it. It is confusing and buggy as fuck - sometimes you just need to reboot the game for things to work, other times you'll go crazy trying to find that "needle in a haystack" that is preventing things from working. Survival mode is WAY too monotonous, and Creative mode is way too cheese. There's no real automation, and what automation there is is WAY too confusing - if you work really hard, you might be able to get your miner vehicle to automate going from Point A to Point B, but resources at Point B are limited. There is a 100 m/s velocity which is WAY too slow - you'll easily spend an hour (real time) doing nothing but flying from 1 planet to another - and you cant do anything else during that time, because the velocity will kill you if you get out of the chair. There are random, strange sounds like your ship being destroyed despite no enemies being around (bug?). The color-designation of an "off grid" piece ("burnt orange") is WAY too similar to a broken/incomplete piece ("crimson red"). NOTHING in this game is well described. There is no way to "hide" the massive number of pieces that require DLC, so if you havent bought dlc then scrolling through the "available" pieces is highly annoying as most are not actually available, but because the descriptions are so poor, you dont know what any of them do anyhow. For example, there is "light armor" block and "heavy armor" block, "Large Thrusters" and "Thrusters"... and they want you to "engineer" stuff ("ships") without knowing the weight difference between light or heavy, or thrust power between thrusters, and that's not even getting into the whole large vs small block discussion, which doesn't always seem to work right. 

There are parts of this game that are truly amazing. Building a ship and flying into space, with the sun and other planets, is really a good feeling. Getting something new to work, and constantly trying to make working things better is also really cool. I've heard, but haven't done, that you can actually import C code and run it in the game - but given how difficult even the most basic thing is in this game, I will probably never get there.

Review 5.0:

Don't.

In me, you're looking at 3000 hours of anticipation, expectation, waiting, waiting, waiting, waiting, disappointment, anger, and desperately trying to get [i]something[/i] worthwhile out of this investment trap I got myself into.  To put it simply, Keen "turned players into payers," and for years they've been living the high life off of dopamine addicts buying silly virtual makeup compacts and mods ripped straight from the workshop.  The few bits of content created by Keen are creative opportunities wasted on schlock (Lost Colony is okay, but only because everything being lifeless and abandoned is the entire point).

It was an exciting premise, wasn't it?  They shot for the Moon, boys; ultimately just a dead, colourless place, lacking atmosphere or warmth or anything to do but stare wistfully at worlds where things actually happen.  And they left a crater.  I'm done.  This sham is going into my 'eyesores' folder for good.  Even if you don't care about the money, save yourself the years of frustration and disgust.

I downloaded this game with the hopes of being able to create something yet 200 hours in I am giving up. The only reason this game exists is because it is the only one of its scale and type. If any other space themed sandbox building game were to come out it would likely be better than this for a couple of reasons. 

-The way the building grid is organised is fucking terrible. 
         -There is little compatibility between small grid and large grid. 
         -Building in large grid limits one 'block' per grid. This means that a light bulb takes up as much space as a full block. 
         -Building anything in gravity gets fucked up. 
-Decorating your ship requires 5+ DLC
-Programming your ship requires insane amounts of work and the UI is frustrating to work with
-Poor performance + requires unreasonable amount of storage
-Overall annoying UI
-Poor graphics
Ect. 

This game wasted an awesome premise.

R5 2600
GTX 1070FE (no GUI on the dedicated server so the GPU has no bearing on server performance)
32GB  3200 CL16 DDR4 RAM
Samsung EVO 950 512GB Steam drive

Not the fastest, but far from minimum specs & way above recommended specs


Pros & cons


Pros:

There are a LOT of mods available on Steam, 

Their dedicated server is free

It supports scripting

You can make your own weapons and complex machines  by combining blocks

The menu background videos are entertaining 

Large youtube presence

When it does run, it's a lot of fun but ONLY in it's modded form.


Cons: 
Mods are ONLY supported in experimental mode, which the devs are quick to tell you is unstable and may not be supported.  

So while there are over 125K (Not a typo, one hundred twenty-five thousand) mods on Steam they all are on a use at your own risk basis.  Mind you, the mod devs themselves are much, much, much more helpful than the game devs

Unfortunately, mods are what make this game fun

There is NO undo so when you delete something by mistake, you have to re-create the missing block or blocks

The dedicated server is primitive and takes hours to set up and get running

There is logging for the server, but interpreting the logs is not documented and is pretty much useless

Scripting is best suited for programmers, especially those proficient in C, so not really scripting, more like programming to compensate for the many, many deficiencies in the game

The UI is very basic and primitive.  To get a compass, minimap, or even color in your HUD or build menu, you will need mods. 

This game takes a LONG time to load with a decent list of mods (like literally, minutes...) so it's a good thing that they are at least interesting.

The game save 'backups' don't work.  Too many times I've lost hours and hours of work because neither the primary, nor any of the backups, nor even the prior file saves will load without crashing.  And for help, you only have the worthless log files (see above)

Also, the save files are wayyyy too fragile.  What do I mean by that?  I have had games cease to load right after saving them just because I lost power or the game locked up and had to be aborted.  That is nothing short of ridiculous.  and as mentioned  in the section about the useless backups, loading one of the 'backups' doesn't allow me access from then on to any of the work I had done in that game save.  All that time and work ends up being wasted and the save is effectively worthless, complete with all of its 'backups'

...and the 'cons' list goes on and on.


Purists will all say, 'don't use mods then'.  Sorry Charlie, I use mods, period.  If it has mods, I will most likely use them.  If you offer modding support it needs to be backed up with tools and at least a useable means of diagnostics. Otherwise, you might as well not even bother to include modding support.


And here's a thought for something which would knock everybody's socks off...
How about putting effort into fixing the problems it already has instead of making more $$$ grabs with skin changes???



Summary:
Single player-  It's an ok game when it works but know all of your work is going to be lost at some point no matter what you do to protect it.  There are a lot of other voxel based games out there, some of which are nearly as old, and many others which have better gameplay, graphics, features, capabilities, and most importantly, stability.  And while Space Engineers is not the worst of the voxel genre games, it's closer to the bottom than to the top compared to the other dozen or more that I personally either own or have played.

Multiplayer-
The game is an ok time killer which *can* be fun if you get a decent assortment of mods to work together, but be prepared to spend a whole lot of hours troubleshooting, adjusting, troubleshooting again, adjusting again and waiting on the server to do multi-minute loads in between all those adjustments.  Also, know that your game will be lost for good despite any number of 'backups' you might make.


Bottom Line:
I can only recommend it if you have nothing else to do and you already have the game
Or
Get this when it's discounted at least 90% off, (although more would be better), and be patient and willing and ready to spend a lot of time fiddling around if you decide to run a server

This really kills me because I like the idea of this game, I just hate the execution. This thing really, really needs some kind of loose goal for solo survival, something like Minecraft with a couple of basic mobs and a final boss. Something to really challenge your engineering skills. Building feels really, really clunky, requiring use of the whole keyboard, And when I say that, I mean the whole thing. That would be fine if you could do everything with just the keyboard, but no, you either need to move your off hand all over your keyboard or you've got to keep moving your dominant hand between the keyboard and mouse. It feels way clunkier than it needs to be, and I would really recommend taking a page out of Blender's playbook by just having a rotate button (like R) and then a simple XYZ rotation GUI. Anything that lets me keep my off hand in the same spot so I don't have to completely upend years of gaming/CAD experience. Graphics are pretty nice, though performance on my mid-tier PC was pretty crappy. The fact that a lot of the best looking and performing stuff is locked behind various paywalls is also pretty lame.

Overall, interesting concept, clunky execution. - 5/10

Not worth it to be honest. Any "Updates" are just half assed DLC reskins of the base models. It still has an overabundance of potential, but with the devs seemingly having no intention of adding anything meaningful, I'm afraid this is just an abandoned title.

This game is great. I bought it back when it was early access and had no planets and I've had a blast along the years. Recently I decided to get back to it and the developers decided to become really pushy with DLC. They litter the in-game build menus with options of DLC items you don't have for no reason other than to push you to buy the DLC. It's sad to see the developers of a game I enjoy so much resort to this sort of actions to get more money. It just seems desperate. See I didn't get the DLC because I was just returning and I had no idea how to play the base game anymore, let alone with the DLC, but now I just don't want to buy the DLC and give you the evidence that shady DLC sales tactics work. In fact, it makes me want to go play Satisfactory instead.

This issue has been brought up to the developers through the official channels. They believe it's working as intended. As in, they didn't accidentally forget the menu littered with options you can't select to push you to buy their DLC. They think it is a legitimate sales technique, to pester their customers for more money in such a way.

My negative review is a small act of protest against this behavior and why it is being done. It's just unprofessional and greedy behavior. Your greed turned a customer that was happy with your product, to a customer that is annoyed by your desperation based business model.
Abandonware for anyone who doesn't want to spend money on pointless DLC skin packs.

It's a great game, I enjoyed playing it when I was younger and hope one day I'll come back to playing it. Hopefully one day they'll add NPCs. I love building and crafting in this game, and exploring space is always fun. I recommend this for those that love building bases and building ships.

Space Engineers is horrible.
First, there is no tutorial, the pathetic ones they give, don't teach you how to actually do anything.
One example is "Refill your O2/H2".  But they don't tell you how.
The other major problem is movement.
Bad movement will kill interest in any game.
When you turn on the jetpack, and move your mouse in any direction, you end up spinning out of control.  It's maddening, it's sickening!
I thought Empyrion was bad, this game is 1000 time worse.  Because at least Empyrion had a "Level Out" key to right yourself.  Thre's no such key in this.  It became unplayable.
plus the movement, in jetpack mode, will constantly kill you, with impact damage on everything you touch.

There is a lot of stuff in there, that could be an awesome game.  Until they fix movement, it's a hard pass!
game good me like as you can see

SE is a game that doesn't really have an end goal. It's like Minecraft in space with voxels.
The ability to create is incredible, and more gets added constantly.
Much like Minecraft and maybe Skyrim though, this game is elevated by its mod community. 
SE will give you some hilarious moments, and a way to create.

However, there are some downsides.
The base game doesn't have all the content (mainly parts and skins) that the DLC has, and if you want to design anything worth a look, you will want the DLCs. They are fairly priced though, not P2W, and most importantly, will not stop you from playing from someone who does / not have them.

The physics engine is pretty good, though weird clangy stuff still happens, so save often.

PVE still doesn't really exist without mods. It's coming, I think. But until then I suggest running mods like MES, and don't expect the world. Mods will give enough to tide you over, but we're all waiting for Keen implemented PVE.

Brings me to Keen - one of the few dev teams I've seen who actually listen to what their playerbase says about their game. How far this game has come in a few years is partially thanks to the listening ear Keen gives us. I know they gotta add stuff that makes them money, I have zero issues with it, but the adding requested things and general bug fixing is great.

It's still a bit difficult to get into the game at first. There's a bit of a wall you have to climb before you know enough to make what you want happen. It's not inherently bad, but the game could do with a "New players start here, we got a guided walkthrough"  section like many other games have.

All in all, worth my 1200 hours. I bought before planets were even released and there was enough to keep me interested. Nowadays there's just more and more to do and make with all the new parts they add. You get some for free every update, and if you don't mind $5 here or there every couple months, you get a lot more.

A Pronominal!!! game that has only gotten better over time what used to be a buggy but still entertaining mess of a game has now become a much more fleshed out, content filled masterpiece that surpasses many AAA titles being released these days . Though it still has the apparent bug here or there (though I haven't personally encountered any on my recent vanilla run) nothing like what it once was and the content that's been added has now given so much more possibilities to this game. The dlc's are a bit of a (minor) frustration but its done well in that they at least are more less cosmetic thus not removing potential content or creating "cut content" for a price, as well as not making it a pay to get an edge type deal and they are at a somewhat reasonable price so im not really devastated by it. 

I would Love to see another bundle pack added for all the dlc that are not currently included in the deluxe or add the (function adding dlc) to the deluxe. As I do agree that the game deserves some extra revenue which helps with further development, (as long as the content is worth the price being charged.... Looking at you Creative Assembly, Sega, all the rest hahaha 🙄😑😡). When you tally up all the dlc and it's much more than the actual game that's when there's an issue!

All and all it's DEFINITELY a game to check out! it's a incredibly complex game with a steep learning curve but also has a very well made tutorial to get you through it and really has an endless potential and that's something I personally never say EVER!

Great game, definitely recommended for all of you to play. You start off somewhere and build stuff. It's all fun until u start to build a rover and spaceship. The rover will run through obstacles or fall towards a cliff or move too fast and get flipped upside down and unmovable. It just stayed there forever. Sad, lonely, devastated and unmovable and was forced to spend an eternity alone on the darkest night. The spaceship however is quite interesting because it is guaranteed to explode whenever something goes wrong. You build a cool-looking spaceship, u enter the cockpit and u think to yourself "Finally it's done, let's fly!" but unfortunately it's too heavy to fly. Boohoo. You added more rockets to it and now it's ugly. Boohoo. But hey at least it can fly. So u managed to fly and u fly so fast and the gyroscope fucked up your flight path and you crash into the mountain or straight up to the ground. Its explode. Its deadass explodes. If u were lucky only 1/4 of the spaceship's body is destroyed. It's hard to repair because the whole spaceship is not balanced and adding a rocket to stabilize it will only make it much worse as the rocket will only push it away and move constantly. Been there done that. So u thought to yourself "What if I build a new one and it is like this, perhaps it will work" for the next new spaceship. Spoiler alert, it doesn't work. Something will definitely go wrong somewhere and cause the spaceship to explode. So yeah, u repeat the cycle of hell again and again like Doctor Strange confronting Dormammu. Overall what a great game! Fun to play! Stress-free game! Woohoo! It would be better if they made the surroundings less dark when in space or in the building. I used the torch light but it looked so dark. Well, that's it from me! Enjoy the game!

Frequent glitches, poor optimization, and every new update being a cosmetic DLC cashgrab;
This game is in a very bad spot development-wise.

The Multiplayer isn't much better:
Poorly optimized netcode, frequent framerate stutters, and common physics desynchronization. 


That being said, there still are things about it to be enjoyed, such as the nicely simplified Minecraft-like building mechanics, the generally well-behaved physics engine*, and the deformable voxel terrain.

*Klang disagrees with this statement

My TL DR is: 
If you want to have a smooth and seamless block-based spaceship building experience, don't play this game.
If you like to build sci-fi stuff and explore the modded content it is super fun.  No real story so if you like to RP it can also be fun

Great sandbox builder with good variety of blocks and environments. Can have depth if you are willing to set restrictions for yourself or use mods to increase difficulty. Dlc's are fairly priced (still get them on sale) but most are thoroughly underwhelming in terms of content usually providing only a small selection decorative blocks. This is the game for you if you like the idea of building ships, trucks,/rovers, bases, space stations, etc. and surviving in the void of space or the atmosphere of planets with varying gravities and oxygen levels. Can be great fun with friends or on a multiplayer server until the simulation speed dips then it is almost painful to play. (it is a lot like lag, but is not usually ping related, more due to optimization.) Game can feel aimless if you dont find much joy in building or basic survival aspects, the economy is very barebones with only a few types of missions and no story content outside of scenarios or your own "roleplay".

all in all an 8.5 / 10, great building game with many ways to be creative in your builds but the barebones survival and economy mechanics leave you desiring more. With the right mods this game is easily 10 / 10.

Space Engineers is an incredible game. I'm absolutely in love with its messed up physics and mentally unwell fan base. As a Clang worshipper myself I must reccomend this game. No, it's not the best thing I've ever played and sure it can be boring at times but it has a charm. You can build absolutely anything. The ability to spend hours on something and see it actually work is incredible. Engineers work out of necessity, and I love that feeling about survival mode. It's a little slow at first but feels great. The game itself does feel empty, but with mods it can be insanely fast paced and full of action. From new enemy bases and npc ships to literally just HUD colors and animated interaction. I'm not too fond of the devs Making the updates all just re-skin DLCs but I still buy them cause they're cool. Game is pretty fun with a group and hilarious but can also be a great way to relax by yourself if you're into that sort of thing.

TL:DR Space Engineers is an amazing game for someone with an Engineers heart. Fun with a group, and while it has flaws is still a great game. Especially with mods

Absolutely love this game. It's the absolute sandbox, survival, crafting, base-building survival game. It's a must have. It's so rewarding to get a base going, build some mining ships, transport ships and auto mining rigs. Not to mention the first time you get a ship from planet to space and back again. Unfortunately for me I was showing off to my wife how cool this game was and had drones attacking me in space (vanilla) had to run for my life! So my first space XP from planet was short lived. But I will return. My goal is to go from planet to moon, mine some stuff and return home in one piece. I can't think of any game out there that let's you do that. You literally build everything and go. I recommend watching some tutorial videos to get you going. Not sure if I'll get in trouble, but recommend watching "The Collector" on YouTube. The series isn't done at the time of this review.... It really shows how the endless possibilities in the game exist.

I've been playing this game since WELL before it's release. This is by far the number one game I have always come back to, and can't imagine NOT coming back to. At times, sometimes, I wish the game had more of a PvE element to it. The Spiders/Wolves are... ok. The A.I. enemy drones are... ok. In truth, the environment is the enemy and is always attacking... but sometimes I wish for more, actual combat. Something that uses cover. Something that augments it's ship. Something that LIVES in the asteroids, just waiting for some unsuspecting astronaut to delve too greedily into that rich vein of platinum. But it's a building game. And for that I really believe it's banging on all cylinders. That's the reason I'll always be back.

It's a fun game. Until you encounter the numerous bugs and lack of any useful features. You'll never know how many thrusters you need for your ship to not crash (there is nothing telling you how much lift power each offers) when its either empty or full. Nothing telling you how much fuel time you have or how much fuel usage you have.
The biggest bug is the simple fact that sometimes even the smallest damage to your ship will cause it to explode. This is known as Klang (Yes the community has given it a name since it's such a big issue that has never been addressed from day 1 of release 10 years ago). Landed a ship softly on your connector? Tried connecting the ship to your base? Explosion, your cargo, engine and internal conveyors are all damaged, now you have to remove parts to get inside and fix them. Tried mining a mineral ore? Game doesn't recognise that it's there, proceeds to throw your ship around damaging it. Back to base to for supplies because your thruster is damaged.
Overall the game becomes increasingly annoying and painful to play due to bugs in the game engine. Great idea and good looking game but an absolute travesty and horrid example of development.
Playing on planets or anywhere near gravity is an absolute waste of time. Broken physics engine, broken lighting engine and buggy voxels will simply cause your ships to explode and crash for seemingly no reason.
There is basically little to not information within the game to help you on your journey. For example you might be spending a lot of time looking for resources such as Cobalt and Platinum. Well heres a tip (found this in a random comment on the wiki) - if you see black spots on a ice lake those are resources under the ice.
There is no reason to visit other planets. They offer nothing of value that yours already doesn't have nor have anything else going on for them.
You can spawn in space but you'll quickly realise there is nothing really to do other than building a big space ship to... do nothing with it. Sure you can hunt down clunky, weak and random AI but that gets boring quickly. 
Or you can try Multiplayer and enjoy the lag, bugs and the rare chance of meeting someone in game.
I bought this game in 2015 thinking it will be developed into a gem. I've now tried it and have left disappointed. Barely any content, bugs that have been there for years. What did the devs even do with it this whole time?

I decided to get this game since it came bundled with Hardspace: Shipbreaker, and my monkey brain said "Game about taking apart ship in space = Good, therefore Game about building ship in space = Good". I regret to say it's not particularly the case.

The game itself is of the same stripe as Minecraft (Gigantic sandbox with a tiny bit of survival mechanics) and while I fully acknowledge this genre is not particularly my cup of tea, there are several issues with it that go past that:

First of all, the ingame physics are incredibly janky, to the point it could give Bethesda a run for its money. I assume that it's kind of inevitable, considering that it's aimed at handling potentially massive structures moving at high speeds with a lot of interactions between different parts; so something is bound to slip through the cracks. But even, it can be seriously frustrating.

The UI is an absolute mess. If you are working on anything bigger than a small ship/platform, it's is an absolute pain to both navigate and operate.

There's simply nothing to do. Once you got the absolutely basic survival needs taken care of and have some resources, there's nothing to push the player forward. The game itself kind of acknowledges this by offering some more conventional, objective-centered missions, but they largely fall flat due to how shallow the game mechanics are: The "research system" is completely tacked on. Combat on foot is an exercise in frustration due to the enemies having pinpoint accuracy and you dying in three shots, requiring you to play hide and seek with the turrets until you destroy them. The diplomacy system and commerce system...exist, I guess.

I assume you can get some fun out of it if you play it as a multiplayer experience (Probably with a hefty helping of mods on the side), but if you prefer single player games, don't even bother with this one.

[h1]Before you buy it... Read this![/h1]
I won't waste your time, I promise. Let's get straight to the point.

[h2]What is this game about?[/h2]
Space Engineers is an amazing game, like few I have ever played. And I am a guy that plays many genres like RTS, FPS, strategy games, city builders, RPGs, etc. Extremely amazing in terms of mechanics, infinite possibilities, and gameplay. It's best play with friends, although it is also worth playing it in solo mode. You will get to build vehicles, spaceships, machines, factories (I am not kidding), and every single thing physics and imagination can get you to conceive. You will mine asteroids or live in them. You will travel around huge solar systems, explore space, explore other planets, and build for any possible space exploration experience. However, the experience is more complex than what you may think.

Space Egineers is best described as a Minecraft for adults, young curious people, and [b]engineers[/b]. Yeah, I said it right, 'engineers'. As the game mainly includes all sorts of mechanics and systems you get to study in an engineering career. You get to see propulsion systems whose power you can measure in KN (kilonewtons), rotors, sensors, programming blocks, physics, and many other sorts of mechanics I am definitly not getting into detail, like chemistry involved in the refining of the minerals mined throghout the planets.

[h2]Who is this game for?[/h2]
[b]IF AND ONLY IF[/b] 
[list]
    [*]You are willing to learn about a complex but rewarding game in detail through videos and manuals, the challenge is for you. You don't need to be an engineer to play the game, but engineers will definitely feel familiar within the environment the game provides. You will get to catch on fast.

    [*]If you are a more casual player, but love studying how to solve problems and how things work, the game is also for you. You have to be a curious person.
[/list]

[h2]Who would I not recommend this game to?[/h2]
To people looking for a campaign, space FPS, RPG or a quick-to-learn game. For those who have no patience. 

[h2]My experiece with this game...[/h2]
This pretty much what you can expect.

Convo 1:
-"Dude, we need our first spaceship/vehicle to get minerals faster".
-"You know what? We should build an automatic drill for this instead of using spaceships to get minerals". 
-"Dude, that's easy. I mean, I don't know crap about it, but logic says we could use rotors and pistons to get it down this area".
-"Well, let's calculate the weight to hold it up and have engouh power".
-"I mean, we are poor rn, we can't use nuclear reactors to power it up".
-"Then, let's build it not as a mobile vehicle but as a some sort of static platform. Like an extension to our base using eolic and solar energy to power it up".
-"You know what would be cool? Let's use this same design but transformed into a spaceship to drill a whole asteroid. Then, let's build in it".
-"Yeah, and we could build a fleet of programmable drones to keep it safe from enemies".
-"Ok, I'll check on a basic algorithm and the documentation to program the drones".
-"Ok then, while you do that, I'll build the spaceship to get us up there".
-"Let me hop into building of the drill for the minerals from this planet then".


Convo 2:
-"Dude, you know what? We should build a satellite that could act like the Death Star from Star Wars!".
-"Let's build it on orbit then. That's easier than launching it to space".

Convo 3: 
-"Man, let's build flagships, like huge ships that can become our base, transport vehicles and allow us to move to other planets".
-"That sounds cool. Do you think the gravity to get out of the planet is the same in every planet?".
-"Don't think so. Let's calculate if we have enoguh power to get out of orbit. Are there in-game specifications of the gravity every planet?".

Howdy,

So, I've been playing Space Engineers for a while now, and I just had to share how awesome it is. If you're into creative and exploration games, this one's a gem.

The game keeps getting better with regular updates, adding cool stuff and making it even more fun to play. The range of features and items they keep throwing in is seriously impressive.

Building your own spaceships and stations is where it's at. You can get as creative as you want, and trust me, it's a blast. Plus, exploring the vastness of space with your creations is a feeling like no other.

The game's not just about building, though. There's this whole survival aspect too, and it's a real challenge. You'll need to gather resources, manage your energy, and fend off threats. It keeps you on your toes.

The best part? You can do all of this with friends. Teaming up to construct epic structures or going on wild space adventures together is a total blast.

In a nutshell, Space Engineers is hands down the best creative/exploration space game out there. It's always evolving, so you'll never run out of things to do. If you're into space and creativity, give it a shot.

Happy exploring!

Cheers, Kostas

I have a love/hate relationship with this game.  I've bought all the DLCs (except the last one) so far.
I'm going to modify my last review to do a more pros/cons approach.  We'll hit the cons first.
1.  This game is harder than most to get into, mostly because of the poorly arranged parts list and lacking starter tutorials (most games are the same control setup, this one has a few extra keys).
2.  The physics engine is questionable.  There's even a word for it - Klang (or Clang).  If you want to see the problem fastest, just put some pistons on a rotor and try to make a crane.  You'll soon see all kinds of wobble, then later it'll explode and parts will go everywhere (on the positive side for this...or negative if you're a server operator - you can make propulsion engines using the poor physics simulation - called Klang engines, that cost no fuel to propel your craft).
3.  There are a bunch of DLC that don't address the major bugs of the game, though they have made some forward progress to address some of the things consoles miss that PC versions of the game have.
4.  Encounters are solely based on chance / RNG and there is no persistence where AI moves across the universe with purpose (maybe there are mods that kind of grapple with this).
5.  The only NPCs in the game are ships.  Even the mods to add NPCs with character models are kind of blah.
6.  The AI that does exist that controls the NPC ships (or the blocks you can use) have trouble with pathfinding through anything more complex than empty space.
7.  The scripts rely too much on server side processing.  I'm not sure there's any client side at all.  This means most server owners will disallow scripts by the majority of players because it will lag the hell out of their servers, so no automated mining scripts.  Besides, the scripts don't work on the console version of the game.
8.  Most of my games work on Linux now.  This game has one of the worst Linux portabilities out of my entire collection (about $3K worth of games) out of the games that will run on Linux.  The fact that this game works on Linux at all is an accident of course (and it wasn't designed to do so by the devs), but it's a royal pain in the ass to get going.
8.  There are no defined asteroid positions or asteroid fields, they're just individual asteroids that are RNG'd into place as you explore.  There are no areas with more asteroid or less density and you can't create those zones as a server operator either, the asteroid RNG just is. The only way to address this as a server owner is to make different regions of space with different servers and use mods to change ore types on some of the servers.
9.  If you want water instead of just ice on planets, you'll need a mod for that.
10.  This last con is just informational, I know there's a reason for it and I wouldn't ever want to make a multiplayer game that had these considering how much processing and information transfer would have to take place:  there are no planetary orbits / any orbits of anything at all.  Everything is static in position.

Now for the positives.
1.  You can build very complex ships out of all the parts available.
2.  You can fly in space and on planets and it has amazing space to planet full transition.
3.  You do have to account for gravity and the gravity transition is gradual, from 0G to full.  The planets have varying G forces between different planets.
4.  You can mine different types of minerals on both planets (at varying depths) and in space on asteroids.
5.  There are 3 different thruster types, atmospheric, hydrogen, and ion, with somewhat realistic thrust for each.
6.  The game has one of the most active mod workshops on Steam with thousands of mods (none available for consoles of course - if you use the console version, you can only play on vanilla servers, sorry).

This is a recommendation for the game.  I hope the next engine has better physics, NPC character models, better pathfinding for the AI, and Linux support.

There are many games out there that involve voxels and mining. Techtonica comes to mind. So to enter a game that is 10 years old should be very interesting. And it kind of is. The company used a game called Mining Wars as the jump off point for this game. And, most impressive (I think) is that the game engine was written by the owner. (and probably others) It is impressive because you need a good head for graphics creation, server code, client code, mathematics and science, and where to grab modules that will aid in areas of your engine to jump forward. 

Now according to the company, this game supports Real Time Illumination. Well with my AMD card you could have fooled the hell out of me. If you dig a hole down and lateral to get ore, you can easily walk out of the hole. But if you go deep enough, the textures are all one thing and even near the light source it is easy to get lost since the textures are all identical. You get no 3D sense of space to know even what is up or down. (a sensation in SCUBA diving that gets some people killed) So I would say that they failed in that implementation.

The physics is pretty good...to a point. Everything is controlled by gravity on earthlike planets, and by the lack of gravity on some moons or in space.  The downside to the physics?  I have had to start my game at least 10 times in a row due to how my pod landed on the earthlike planet. Instead of a soft landing that sticks, landing in a tree or on an incline can mean rolling down the slope until your craft stops upside down. Many in the forums say this is a newer bug but it is a bug ignored by the developers.

There is no story after 10 years of existence so it is a little like being a kid and getting a huge box of erector toys and told - "Now give me a ship even though you have 100 items and no way how they combine for your ship." Fortunately, there is a plethora of tutorials to help you on your way. Yet the difficulty and learning curve is what my 40 hours represents. I finally landed in an interesting place (stone, ore, and ice are all in close proximity to my ship) and I was able to build a base and start a new ship without too many delays. My only delay now is learning how to know where to get ores and finding Cobalt.

Now the most general aspect -- game play. Construction of anything in any builder game (Techtonica, Satisfactory, etc) requires that the snapping system works flawlessly to be fun. This game fails in the flawlessness. Let's discuss my ship build for mining. So I laid down a small landing pad...it was laying on it's side but it was green and when I clicked it, it was right side up, and then 4 small blocks. The firrst to go down was my cockpit. So I positioned myself above the top block and ... the cockpit snapped on it's side. Now it is pressing a matrix of PgUp, PgDn, Del, Ins hoping to find the combination that puts it right side up. I finally get it but a move of my hand moves it off the stack. Oops. No problem I snap it back and....it is on it's side once again. Another mystery game of buttons and finally it gets put in place. Now comes the drill, which should be easy since the drill mates to a unit on the seat. Yup, it is up, but when I go higher and look down the drill was in the wrong place. Remove it, get 100% back (gratefully) and it finally snaps into the right place. This will coninues with everything I build. At least in other games if you get the position you want then move away, it retains that position when you return. (sigh)

The other things is just basics. For example, if there is a list of items you created there is no way to get them all out at once. Likewise with storage you cannot say "Move all my components into the storage" Flight is strange since you can go forward and back but cannot strafe.  Hit the typical strafe keys and you are rotated instead. And when you swing the mouse while flying you will also tilt instead of move. Aye what a time of it. So much of my fly time right now is straightening myself up. 

Now you might think I'm giving this a bad review. But I'm just setting expectations. This is a complex game which actually makes it fun for me. It is a mental challenge. And when you build a ship using a tutorial and see it coming together you can only stand and stare at it and say WOW. Research is strange because you "research" by building something to open up the next tier of goodies. And some critical things (like your atmosphere jets) require rare resources that may leave your ship on stilts longer than you want. But I image that first time you get into the ship and fly it you feel a great feeling of accomplishment! (I wouldn't know yet because I've not found Cobalt to finish my engines)

So if you like mental challenges and feelings of accomplishment then this game is definitely for you. The strangeness of the game is it's character. Buy it, it's cheap and a great time synch.

I highly recommend this game to anyone. It gets your creativity going and gets you thinking a lot. The game is perfect for people who love to figure things out and enjoy a soothing experience with a somewhat realistic physics engine.

One of the very few games i would buy DLC for. The devs try their best and are actively updating the game after so many years, and continue to add community made mods to the base game.

The main gamemode is free play survival on a planet, you build a small base, mine rocks, mine rocks, mine rocks, oh god do you have to mine rocks. Then after mining rocks, building a base, unlocking the tech tree, making a rover to find resource deposits, stocking up on every resource you can get on the planet, its then time to try to fly. It took me dozens of hours to get something off the ground and after 150 hours im still bad at it. Once you manage to get into space on a jalopy of a craft finding rare resources that can only be found in asteroids, building a massive mothership, several asteroid miners, finding more resources, and maxing out your mothership. From there mods are the only way forward to fight enemy npc's, installing automated defenses, shields, making fighter craft to engage in pve against npc space stations.

Or you can pvp on a server once you've reached that stage, there are a ton of rpg servers,

They also have several gamemodes. With wave hoard defense, missions, theres a gamemode where you start with a tiny jank rover and go on death stranding missions for locating packages to return for money to upgrade your rust bucket into something fun, dozens of hours of hard work struggling to keep the vehicle operational until you can save enough to buy something that can actually fly or fight.

Dozens of hours with friends watching them crash into asteriods, trying to salvage their wrecks, figuring out how to setup LCD screens to display the motherships inventory, ammo, battery percentage, going from powering your ship off of hydrogen to uranium, becoming harder and harder to kill while raising the timer on how long before you have too actually go collect fuel from an hour to actual days. Designing better drilling ships, fighters, remaking new motherships with star wars esk hangars.

Ya, i suppose if i had to, i'd recommend the game.
