If you like building & you like space, you'll enjoy this. The gameplay has the same issues most buildy games do (empty feeling world, NPC's are simplistic) but the joy is in making & this sandbox is amazing.

If you like nerdy, deeply intricate base and vehicle construction games, albeit where PVP is all you've got for actually using said vehicles and bases once you've built them, then you'll love this.  If you want something easier, shinier, and less lonely, get No Man's Sky.  If you want simpler, PvE focused ship and base building, get Empyrean Galactic Survival.  If you want a space themed, fun FPS, get Deep Rock Galactic.

This is a game which I will cautiously recommend, because I genuinely do have contented memories of solitary mining during the fourth watch of the night, while listening to a recent episode of the "Ukraine: The Latest" podcast in the background.  Emotionally, Space Engineers is the equivalent of Stardew Valley for the highly functioning autistic.  It's "comfy." It's a game that Spock might view as a security blanket.

At least until recently, the automation was a mixed bag.  The potential is less only than Factorio, but I consider C# a truly horrible programming language; although a recent update introduced a number of appliance items which make automation much easier for non-programmers.  That is very welcome, but I would truthfully also prefer that the developers replace the C# API with Lua, if that is possible.

Another detriment is that while the PvP seems quite good, in combat terms, PvE/single player content is almost completely non-existent.  Granted, I normally always play Factorio with the biters turned off, but it would be nice if the in-game environment here was a little less sterile.

Space Engineers is not a game that I would consider mainstream, or for absolutely everyone.  For its' target audience though, (of which, to a degree, I am a member) it is solid.  It's also cheap enough that I can recommend checking it out.  If you don't like it, the worst that you'll experience is a couple of hours of peaceful, cathartic Diggy Diggy Hole; and as someone who spent seven years in Minecraft, I can attest that that's not such a bad thing.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I really enjoy this game. The easiest way that I can describe it is Minecraft-like building with movable builds, in space. The attention to detail on the blocks can lead to sleek designs or hard industrial designs spewing smoke. DLCs aim to expand the current options for a base game player, and do not give an explicit advantage to those who have purchased it over those who have not.

[b] I have only played single player, or multiplayer with a small group of friends. [/b] As such, my points will be tailored toward this type of experience and will not address PVP servers or Servers with low PCU limits. (PCU is the way a block is counted to keep server strain lower. For example a armor block will be 1 PCU while a solar panel might be 45)

[h3] Things I like about the game: [/h3]
~Game is still being updated and refined for a better player experience
~Physics are well done and allow for full 360 fields of motion, both in atmosphere and in space
~Numerous options allow for a player to optimize the game to their PCs capabilities, or can be turned off entirely to push the game engine to its limits
~Active Workshop community - Want a new ship/rover/building for inspiration or you just can't get one built quite right? Head to workshop and find new designs each week. Want a new planet with unique locations, weather, or hazards? Go to the Workshop. Want new kinetic, energy or plasma weaponry? You guessed it, its on the Workshop. Want to tweak a behavior or look of a block (such as the color of thruster plumes)? Check the Workshop. Almost anything you want can be found there. 
~You can create your own experience by choosing how you want to play. You aren't forced into any style of play. For example, if you want to play survival but don't want to grind for resources, you can turn on creative mode tools and spawn some in, without having to worry about the game punishing you for it. Or you can create your own star system, add POI to it, and then swap over to survival without any repercussions.
~Or, if you want, the game has a list of Scenarios that you can play, ranging from an abandoned outpost that you have to piece together what happened there, to a PVP arena, to drone wave survival. The newest Scenario has a Workshop edition where you can create your own version of it, allowing for new experiences each time you play it.
~You can create ships in creative, save them by creating a blueprint and load it into a projector to build in your survival world. This creates an easy way to test your designs without wasting tons of time and resources.
~While the base game PVE is lacking (IMO), there are numerous mods that address this, with varying levels of difficulty. See Assertive Combat Systems for an easier experience and Reavers or Pravda Heavy Industries for harder encounters. 
~Survival can encourage building new ships for situations; they aren't completely necessary, but the game is much more enjoyable by building them
~Creativity is your limit (99% of the time, anyways)

[h3] Things I don't like: [/h3]
~The vanilla game lacks dynamic PVE drone encounters. Abandoned wrecks can be fun, but vanilla drones are lackluster, especially compared to modded ones
~Different planets don't have anything that encourages travel between them, besides different weather events. While a couple mods address this, it is very noticeably missing in the base game
~Creativity is needed to enjoy this game. (not a bad thing, but it can be annoying sometimes)
For example, while I could build a ship that has a refinery bay large enough to rival a industrial world from Warhammer 40k, enough cargo to haul a small moon's worth of resources, and have all the guns so that it could delete the irl sun in a 1v1, that would quickly make the game boring (for me, you might like this, and that's completely fine). Instead, I can build an industrial ship with exposed refineries and dangerous catwalks hanging over the void, leading to tense moments where I hope an enemy doesn't spot me. I could have cargo ships with bays for small shuttles to transfer resources throughout my fleets and bases, leading to potential supply chains and a need to watch my ammo usage and restock my warships. This could then lead me to having a warship with enough guns to win fights, but not so many that fights either become boring, or running the risk of running out of ammo in the middle of the fight, forcing me to pay attention to my battles so I don't make a mistake and lose the fight. 

[hr][/hr]

All of that is to say that you will need to be creative with the way you build and play, and you might run into a wall after a while. In this way, it is like Minecraft for me. I play hard for a few days, weeks, etc., but then I will have to take a break for a bit, to recharge my creativity in the game, or else I just stare at my screen not doing anything. Many problems you will find naturally through playing the game, and many you will have to create yourself, either through mods or by limiting yourself purposely to come up with new ways to design your worlds.

Totally a sandbox without any instructions.  The downside is that nothing is really explained.  The upside is you can build some really weird stuff.  Even better you can choose to stay just in space, just on the ground, or both.

Gameplay:
This has come a really long way from its noble beginnings.  There are scenarios to play, pirates to fight, or you can go totally oldschool and just focus on surviving.  The planetary play is much harder to figure out compared to the space play, so i suggest starting in space first.

Once you get a hang of how ships and all that work, then you can move to planetary building, which is a bit less forgiving in my opinion.

Game takes hours even days to get used to the controls and just learning what things do. You have to watch tons of tutorials just to learn how the game is played because there is no tutorials in the actual game itself. the building mechanics don't make any since, you can only place big blocks on big blocks and small blocks on small blocks so there is no way of making your ship anyway reasonably sized without putting hours into it,  and there are a million different things in the creative mode that just don't make any since or have no explanation or tutorial of how to use it. Don't even get me started on the Quote "survival" all that means is you go and look up a you tube video that's 4 years out of date and has none of the same mechanics to it and the only way for you to build a ship is to place landing gear down that you have to flip upside down to use and just to end up making a funny looking disaster of a ship that doesn't even fly correctly.

The game has a lot to offer, especially if you like actually engineering your vehicles from scratch instead of using premade components like most games do, if they allow customization at all. The survival mode's early game grind is satisfying, especially as you find ways to build more efficient mining infrastructure. I also like the direction the game's updates are heading.


But I think it leaves a lot to be desired. The updates it's getting now are just big enough to be considered new content, and they all have a paid DLC associated that contains the most fun stuff, even if technically the functionality is in the base game. 
The suggestion page is looked at once every decade by the looks of it, and the most fun ideas are getting rejected with no reason given. Even bugfixes! 
Every fan seems to have a "I love the game, but I wish they would add...", and as seen on the 
suggestions board, some of these are shared by more than a thousand players


That's why I can only recommend buying the game discounted and if you're fine with it as is. It's bordering on abandonware territory, and it won't take adding one new minor functionality per year to fix that. 
Even if the effort is going towards SE2, they shouldn't milk this game like that. Either perfect what's already there and leave it be, or accept the most wanted suggestions for fun new mechanics and keep growing the game and putting in effort. 

Instead, we are stuck with a game where your creation that took you a few days to complete can just shake itself into explosion for no reason, and the animals act like temporary placeholders, meanwhile the devs are busy making 2 paid retextures of a few existing blocks per year.


As a side note, another game with what I find to be similar treatment from the devs is GTA Online. Rockstar only barely focuses on it about twice a year, as long as it keeps bringing in money. But even these updates usually feature a new gun, at least a few new vehicles, some with new mechanics, tons of clothes, and even a short storyline of missions. 
And look at the hate Rockstar Games gets for this. 
I don't want a game as unique as Space Engineers to share the same fate before it even feels finished

Overall, while the review is marked as positive to honor what the game is, it barely changed for the past few years. I can't really say I recommend rewarding the devs with money because a lot of potential of a good game is being wasted like that.

After the recent Wastelands update and reaching 1900+ hours playing this game, it is finally time for me to write a review on it. TL;DR is at the bottom.

Basicly, SE is like a computer simulation of Lego Technic with realistic physics and a huge enviroment, with huge voxel planets in it. You can build lots of different contraptions, vehicles, spaceships and buildings; basicly you're limited only by your own imagination and the games' engine limits, which are also quite generous, if you have a good enough computer.

Some might say that there is no point in building stuff in SE, becouse the game has only basic AI enemies and no specific quests, but for me that's part of a sandbox game design. Basicly, you have to make your own goals, like building a space station or reaching and landing on Mars or any other planet (there's currently eight of them, with different gravity and weather). If you're up for a fight, you can also attack NPC ships and stations which randomly spawn in space and on planets.

If you need goals, you can also load the scenarios which come with the base game; those have scripted events, specific tasks to do and enemies which attack you.

Here is a list of the most obvious pros and cons:

PROS:
[list]
    [*]The game has one of the currently best and most realistic physics engines
    [*]A huge galaxy with equally huge and fully destructable voxel planets
    [*]Many technical options to play around with, like rotors, hinges and pistons
    [*]From what i've seen, multiplayer works well for up to 20 people
    [*]nice modding community in the workshop
    [*]It's basicly Lego Technic in space with somewhat realistic physics and weather
[/list]

CONS:
[list]
    [*]The game engine sometimes does weird stuff and breaks your complex creations, therefor you have to save your game often and tinker around with more complex blueprints to get them to work
    [*]While planets are huge, they're also very empty and some advanced physics like air drag are missing (except if you use mods)
    [*]The AI enemies are few and pretty dumb, mostly they just attack you without any strategy
    [*]There is no real water, only ice, which can kill the immersion for some people (except if you use mods)
    [*]Multiplayer working well depends on server settings and restrictions; if players build too big, there can be performance drops
[/list]

TL;DR: in my opinion, Space Engineers is one of the best space sandbox games currently on the gaming market. If you like realistic space games & hard sci-fi (like The Expanse), don't need set goals to have fun and are willing to play around and tinker with technicalities and physics, you'll probably enjoy it.
ive been flying to a planet for 5 hours now

Space Engineers is an excellent game if you're a YouTube content creator or looking to play with a group of friends online where you make your own objectives and scenarios, experience the fun and thrills of building and messing around on one of the several planet types available or in space among the asteroids, but if you're looking for a real challenge then you might want to invest in one of the many mods available on the Steam Workshop that give you a wider range of encounters and enemy NPC opponents to fight against.

Unfortunately the developers haven't really fleshed out either the economy or warfare expansion much since the initial release, so compared to a lot of other games out there the universe can feel a little empty and soulless.

For people playing solo, or small groups looking for something with a better gaming loop, missions and a background story, then I would definitely recommend either Empyrion: Galactic Survival or No Man's Sky over Space Engineers, as even though the way the grids are handled are extremely well done and the creative building side of things is second to none in Space Engineers, it still feels like more a creative sandbox than an actual game compared to many of the others out there even after all these years and you'll need to use your own imagination in order to keep yourself entertained.

Figure after over 1300 hours I'd give it a genuine review
I wish I could give this game a "neutral" review. In its base state, it's an okay sandbox game where you can build starships and explore planets. It's even got a cozy little survival mode. With mods, you can make the ship of your dreams with its exact specifications and weapons. But if you want an interior that looks good, have fun forking over another $90. Keen locks all of their decorative blocks behind paywalls that release every other month or so, and without them there's really nothing to put inside your ships. All I can say positively about them is that they don't put genuinely functional blocks behind the paywalls, so it's not a pay to win game, just extremely annoying if you want a fully filled out ship.

Negative review because of the DLC policy and lack of any actual content in the game besides building blocks. The game was originally made as a space sandbox and it really shows. The only reason to build anything is that you gave yourself a reason/goal. There's nothing in the game to push you to do anything, aside from basic oxygen and power requirements to keep you alive. 

It's a good-enough game, but it's absurd they think they can peddle "DLCs" worth 1/4 of the base game, and all the content that is added is reskins and decorative blocks. It's even more ridiculous when you consider that the Steam Workshop has thousands of entries of decorative blocks and reskins and they are ALL free.

I just wanted to compliment the projector. Not only does it make sense in space engineers setting, but it is without a doubt the best tool, the most balanced tool, the most creative, and the most seamless implementation of workshop content so players can share designs. 
It does exactly what it says. It projects the exact block placement for any build possible, and it will only show buildable blocks that are connected to already built ones, so the design of a complicated ship doesn't get in your way. 
It is SO SIMPLE. It turns a 4649 block, warp drive, auto aiming rail gun, auto opening doors, with ship docks, full 360° view death starship that has a fleet of AI powered auto mining drills, into a Lego set that a child could understand. 
It is an S tier workshop tool, bravo.

Introduction:
"Space Engineers," an opulent symphony of engineering ingenuity and cosmic exploration, presents an enthralling amalgamation of complexities within the vastness of a digital cosmos. This review undertakes a comprehensive deconstruction of the game, delving deep into its intricate gameplay mechanics, construction intricacies, spatial dynamics, and the dynamic interplay of creativity and survival instincts.

Gameplay Mechanics:
The fulcrum upon which "Space Engineers" oscillates is its intricate gameplay mechanics. An exquisite amalgam of physics simulation, resource management, and celestial navigation, it entices players into an elaborate dance with the laws of Newtonian motion. The nuanced control over the minutiae of spacecraft design and construction serves as both an intellectual pursuit and an artistic canvas for players to unleash their creativity.

Construction Intricacies:
The game unveils a mesmerizing expanse of engineering intricacies, demanding meticulous planning and design to manifest one's cosmic visions. From the micro to macro scale, the construction interface empowers players to craft highly intricate contrivances, from circuitry-driven automated systems to towering space stations. The resultant tapestry of structures weaves an aesthetic harmony within the vast emptiness of the cosmos.

Spatial Dynamics:
"Space Engineers" articulates a spaceborne symphony of spatial dynamics that challenges players to contend with the void's vacuous expanse. The microgravity environment defies terrestrial paradigms, necessitating inventive engineering solutions. The interplay of orbital mechanics, ship propulsion, and spatial maneuvering culminates in a cerebral ballet demanding precision and foresight.

Creativity and Survival:
The duality of "Space Engineers" is manifest in the interwoven threads of creativity and survival. Players are not only architects but also astronauts, tasked with the perpetual struggle for sustenance amidst the cosmic void. The equilibrium between ingenuity and resource management, juxtaposed against the relentless vacuum of space, affords a profoundly immersive experience.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, "Space Engineers" represents a multidimensional odyssey into the realms of imagination and technological prowess. Its multifaceted gameplay mechanics, construction intricacies, spatial dynamics, and the inextricable fusion of creativity and survival constitute a compelling symphony within the digital cosmos. The game is a testament to the indomitable spirit of human curiosity, both an intellectual crucible and an artistic tableau, inviting players to etch their sagas against the backdrop of the celestial tapestry. "Space Engineers" emerges as an enduring testament to the boundless horizons of interactive digital artistry.

Space Engineers is one of those games that has a lot of potential, but it doesn't quite hit the mark for me. Building stuff in space sounds cool, and the creative mode can be pretty fun if you're into designing and engineering your own structures. The physics and mechanics are decent, but sometimes they can feel a bit wonky and unpredictable, which can be frustrating.

The graphics are okay, nothing mind-blowing but not terrible either. The sound effects are functional, but they don't really stand out or add much to the experience. The gameplay loop of gathering resources, building ships or stations, and exploring can be engaging for a while, but it can also get repetitive after a bit.

I appreciate the multiplayer aspect, It's more enjoyable when you have a group to share the experience with. However, the learning curve can be a bit steep, and the lack of non-confusing tutorials can make it tough for newcomers to get into the swing of things.

Honestly, Space Engineers is alright if you're looking for a game to tinker around with and kill some time. It's not a bad game by any means, but it's also not something that has completely grabbed my attention.

Excellent game if you enjoy sandboxes. Unfortunately, like all sandboxes, you eventually hit the end of guided progression and have to start setting your own goals to keep having fun.

That being said, the game really makes it easy to find things to do. There's full Steam workshop support for both blueprints and mods, allowing you to share ships, explore other player's builds, and mod the game. Once you've mastered the base game, there are many well-developed mods allowing you to fully exploit one of the most impressive game engines ever made.

It's a shame that Keen doesn't have a better team of gameplay designers, because their Vrage game engine puts nearly every other studio to shame with its stable physics (praise clang), loading-screen free traversal, and immense flexibility for player creation that makes Minecraft look like a bucket of wooden blocks.

I enjoy the game very much, but I do think it has a decent amount of room for improvement. However, the core gameplay is by far one of the better sandbox-type experiences I've had. Ship/base building feels dynamic, exploration is realistic in a way that feels engaging to me (though I could recognize if/why someone would be bored by it), and a lot of the granular options (i.e. the ability to add in code and change very small things easily) are great. On the other hand, the existing AI is shallow, and some DLC feels like it's not worth its price.

Base building is interesting in how a lot of things are literally connected - you can dock/undock ships and other moving objects with relative ease, and they will incorporate themselves into the base pretty smoothly. You can connect inventories fairly inexpensively, allowing you to interact with anything in your base from anywhere once you have a good setup. Exploring the different moons/planets is slow, which I personally enjoy as it gives time to enjoy the view and make use of your ship's facilities. 

You have the option to set the ship to mostly autopilot (or fully autopilot, with the right equipment), so if you have a nice ship you can appreciate it more. Options for, ex. letting a drill mine at a certain pace, or having a turret automatically shoot in the right circumstances, allows for people to have more clever solutions to the standard problems you'll face. 

The controls are intuitive, which is impressive given the many different things you're able to do; however, at least for me, I was unable to change the controls for two very different settings (piloting a ship vs not) to use the same controls.

Engaging with the AI does not feel like a meaningful use of time. Enemy ships are interestingly designed, but there are no characters piloting them, and bases are completely empty. Wolves are comically bad; they all attack at once, in the same uninteresting attack pattern, then run at low health. If you kill them, they drop steel or solar panels or some other strange space-age items. I love exploring the bases, because they feel like they use the same tools as you're given, but I wish there were some sort of presence there, even if it were just computer monitors set up for dialogue or something.

I am a proponent of the idea that cosmetic DLC should have a lot more leeway than real content DLC, because it isn't as important for most games. However, this is the type of game where it feels more fundamentally related to the game - if you're not making a base for it to look good, what is it in service of? And so the fact that many paints and block-equivalents are paywalled, even if it doesn't give any advantage (though arguably some do, if only small), is a bit lamer than if another game were to do that.

I think if you enjoy sandbox games or automation games like Factorio, it's worth trying this out. I think there are a lot of improvements to be made, which I don't foresee happening, but I'd be happy to be proven wrong. I would recommend playing this game with friends if possible, as it definitely alleviates a lot of the issues.

I love this game except for one aspect. For some ungodly reason, the developers seem to not want you to do ship to ship combat in single player. It used to be' Step 1: Get a Ship, Step 2: Get a gun, Step 3 Attach gun to ship, Step 4: Fire gun at other ship. Now you have to spent 15 minutes programming your guns in order to fire anything at all. Even then, half your guns wont fire and the others won't reload after firing once, even in creative mode. Ramming is also so much less satisfying then it used to be. Before you could smash a large ship into another ship and they would scythe each other in half or get lodged within one another with debris flying in an extremely cathartic manner. Nowadays, even if you ram a ship at max velocity it will just bump off like you got into a fender bender. The destruction physics in this game is extraordinary and I just can't understand why with every update they make it harder and harder to destroy anything. I never got into this game for the building, I saw videos in 2015 of ships getting blown to pieces and I knew I had to get it. So do not get into this game if you are like me, you will only be disappointed.

Space Engineers is a captivating sandbox game that invites players to shape the universe to their whims, offering a canvas of infinite possibilities among the stars. My journey through this immersive realm has been a thrilling exploration of creativity, engineering, and the boundless expanse of space.

Limitless Creativity:

From the moment I set foot in the vastness of Space Engineers, the world felt like a playground of endless creativity. The game's building mechanics are a testament to its ingenuity, allowing players to construct intricate structures, vehicles, and even entire space stations from a diverse array of blocks. The process of bringing my ideas to life, block by block, was both satisfying and rewarding.

Engineering Mastery:

Space Engineers challenges players to think like engineers as they tackle complex problems, from resource management to the intricacies of propulsion and navigation. The intricacy of the game's systems adds a layer of realism that's as humbling as it is exhilarating. Crafting and fine-tuning intricate machinery feels like mastering a grand puzzle, where every piece plays a vital role in the larger picture.

Boundless Exploration:

The universe of Space Engineers is vast and ripe for exploration. From barren asteroids to lush alien planets, every celestial body presents unique challenges and opportunities. Scouting for resources, establishing outposts, and mapping out the cosmos provided me with an incredible sense of adventure, pushing me to venture into the unknown and uncover its secrets.

Cooperative Endeavors:

The multiplayer aspect of Space Engineers adds a dimension of cooperation and competition that's as thrilling as it is unpredictable. Teaming up with friends to construct colossal spacefaring vessels, wage interstellar wars, or collaborate on ambitious projects is a testament to the game's potential for shared adventures. It's a place where camaraderie and rivalry intersect in a symphony of innovation.

Visual Splendor and Realistic Physics:

The game's visual design is a marvel to behold, with attention to detail that brings celestial bodies and spacecraft to life. The realistic physics engine, which governs how objects interact and move in the environment, adds a layer of immersion that lends weight to every action. The feeling of piloting a ship through zero-gravity environments, or watching as structures crumble under the forces of physics, is both captivating and awe-inspiring.

Community and Modding:

Space Engineers' vibrant community is a testament to the game's enduring appeal. The modding scene breathes new life into the experience, adding new gameplay mechanics, ship designs, and even entire game modes. The dedication of players to expanding the universe through their creative endeavors enriches the game and ensures that every journey is unique.

Conclusion: Crafting Dreams in the Cosmos

Space Engineers is a playground where imagination takes flight among the stars. The fusion of creativity, engineering prowess, and boundless exploration makes for an unforgettable journey through the cosmos. As I continue to build, explore, and engineer my way through this captivating universe, I'm reminded that the final frontier is not just a destination – it's a canvas for dreams and a realm where the limits of imagination are shattered, one block at a time.

If you are wondering if after more than 740 hours, if I still keep this as negative review, the answer is yes.

It is just not polished enough, inconsistent and still has the same basic problems in being dependent on mods to perform any basic task.

The game mechanics are inconsistent, an example, you can move an action like turn a block on or off to a hotbar, great, and you also heave a toggle option, so it alternates between on and off. Everything you need right there. But other blocks that also have on off option don't have the toggle option. Why, why the fuc#. A simple example, take a tank, and look at the stock pile and auto fill. Just a toggle but inconsistent behavior.

Naming, daamm, after the new update for automatons, who the hack name the events on the event controller. No consistence what so ever, "Angle changed" quite a good name for an event, then we have "Hinge/Rotor Attached/Detached", wtf is that? Its like it was done by two complete different people. Just name it "Attached" or head attached.

Then you go for the actual functionality, again, seems like it was done by different people that never exchanged a single world about it with each other. Seems the initial idea was to have a single event to handle all similar blocks, which would be super good, like the "Angle changed", but then you have "Connector ready to lock", "Landing gear" locked and "Magnetic ready". Jesus just have "Ready to Lock" and "Locked". There also no event for hinge lock and rotor lock, they have lock but I think the dev that was going to develop the lock event for hinges and rotors got a day off.

See consistence, the game is not consistent and it is not polished. Simple naming and basic block info are note present in a technical game that expects you to calculate mass, weight and thrust, but it doesn't give you the info before hand. Its like going to a store, buying a super cool electric oven, installing it home and then realizing that it is 110v and you have a 220v house, "because you can only see the oven technical info after you install it", and now its fried. That is basically how the game expect you to handle energy, mass, thrust and weight. There is no info about it on the blocks, you have to build it first then you have the numbers. So calculate what you need after you build, which make the game heavily dependent on mods that give you those info before hand or keep googling info about how much thrust a Large or small Thruster has.

If you want to have cool and precise machines you can, but you can't have precise inputs because everything is done in chunks. The game allow you to manually enter specific values, like how far should a piston extend, but it completely prevents you from automating it, unless you want to learn C# just to set the distance that a piston should move, if you try to use it from a timer or something.

"Go make your creation, add connectors and rotors, hinges" well now you can't control anything as it is a separated grid and does not respond to directional inputs. But that is no issue, as you can always just get a mod to move your subgrid.

10 Years of the game, and still don't have consistence. That is it, just make it consistent. Fix the naming, add power override on Thrusters just like wheels and Gyros have.

If, you get pass all this, yes, the game still a creative game like minecraft, stationeers, factorio, and mods will keep you playing it for a good while.


==========Original==========

Damm, I really wish we have a neutral review on steam.

In summary, the game works, you can build whatever you want and go from ground to sun.

If you are only looking for some kind of space game where you can build the ship, mining some stuff and fight some npc or do some pvp, yes it will works fine.

The issue for me is that the game limit itself so damm hard. Almost anything you want to do you have to use a script for it. Even after the new release of the automatons, you still can't just set some very basic stuff. One very common thing is having way to much stone, so lets keep 30k and drop the rest, well only with scrips. You can't even tell which item you want to monitor.

Lets mine until 50% of the ship cargo, well unless you only have 1 cargo, you also can't. The automaton (event controller) doesn't do this basic. If you add 4 cargo to the event controller, and set it to trigger at 50%, it will behave in 2 ways.

1 - it will only fill up to 50% of any cargo and stops, even though the other 3 are empty
2 - it will fill up 3 cargos to 100%, and stop when the last one is at 50%.

So, for me, that wants to use the game to automate the game, which you should be able to, you can't really. Even the power reading from the cockpit about the battery life is wrong. Make a floor with 10 or 20 batteries, add a cockpit, it will say the time for 1 battery reading, not all battery.

And, you guess it, if you want to know if you total power is like 30% or less, you also can't.
Those small inconsistency only keeps adding up.

For a game of this genera, one would expect to at least be able to do those basic stuff.
PCU limitation, by default you can barely build a base and a ship, so you have to go manually change some hidden settings.

Which, by the way, every single game you start, you have to set everything again, from scratch. There is no option to save the settings, same for mods, so, every game you start, you have to do all the configuration again.

3º view camera from large ship, again, limits you zoon in for no reason. More annoying then fighting giant Dark Souls 3 or Elden ring bosses.

I wouldn't leave as negative review, as the game works, it does what it say it should do, but it limit it self and don't allow you to do what you want to do with the game, even though that is exactly why one would play the game. This for me is a deal breaker.

Not being able to input a specific value from a block, lets say you want to press a button and set the max speed to 257, you can't, it is either increase/decrease button which goes by chunks, or scripting. Come on, script should be used for people that want optimal performance, and do fancy calculations like having a crane with multiple joints that levels itself as you move all pistons and rotors at once. That is a nice place to have a script setting some values for each part of the crane.

But the simple ability from setting specific values from other blocks should be there by default.

The mods, like other games, are what keep the game going. But unlike factorio, where the base game does everything it should do and mods just add a ton of new things, in Space Engineers you need mods to even do basic things like reading total power or cargo, can't have filters.

The game bags you to add more blocks, like having more thrusts to be able to move a heavy ship, which will just go against the PCU limit, which makes you build small and basic.

The sensor for voxel is almost useless, even picking up thinks from the start drop pod is not reliable, you go to the container, grab some items, deposit some stone, go do some stuff, come back to deliver more stone, but for some random reason, it doesn't allow you to pick or add stuff to the inventory. This normally happens when the blocks are not connected with conveyors, which is not the case for the start drop pod.

That is the best way I can describe, the game limit itself and prevent you for doing what you want, which just go against the game play.
Very fun and in a way therapeutic, there's just something nice about being able to build your own ship and then cast off into space.

After bouncing off many times I finally sank my teeth into this THING, this CREATION.

AI enabled basically gives me colonists, (mostly) autonomous drones that repair, construct, and collect random debris for storage.  there's some jank and learning to be done but thats this whole game.  As a solo player, this is game changing.  Setting up orders/construction on one grid then bouncing to the next one to do the same, then seeing the welding lights from the other grid as the bots work.  Satisfying is an understatement.

MES basically gives me threat that I don't have to explicitly create myself.  Not that this isn't something I want to do in the future but its incredible having such well designed examples in MES to learn from.  Also, the AI doesn't suck.  The first two real dogfights I had against an MES fighter ended in MY dumbass crashing due to poor piloting, while they were making sick turns at high speeds.  I accidentally dodged some missiles that would have hit me had I not been moving the right way already.  Let me repeat that, this community made AI fighter can competently pilot a high speed craft AND accurately launch dumbfire missles at moving targets.  I adjusted the top speeds/missile speeds of things as well (250 small vessel 325 missle), so they seem to just be able to account for that with no issue.

The game ALREADY HAD the following
a grid based, individual part based damage system.  This means if a thruster gets hit, that thruster takes damage.  continue to get hit in that thruster, now its non-functional.  If that was one of your main directional thrusters, you are now in trouble.  containers with ammo will explode if destroyed, if an active cockpit is destroyed while you're in it guess what.  I can think of exactly 0 other games where you can construct a ship block by block in a 3D environment and have to consider directional based damage when placing components.

ballistics and projectile mechanics.  this distances in this game are vast, and its so crunchy watching assault cannon rounds travel their distance then strike a target.  Forces are calculated, small crafts will be MOVED by larger caliber rounds.  oh also, there's penetration mechanics.  rounded/sloped armor has the impact it should have vs taking a projectile head on.
also there's velocity based damage.  fly into a hanger too fast and fun things will happen.

The implications of these two systems are INSANE for ship design when compared to other games.  For example, my first large mobile grid is essentially a mobile mining base.  Lots of turrets/armor and a connector for my small grid mining vessel on top, light armor on the sides, and essentially nothing on the bottom but landing gears and a connector.  It would get shredded if anything ever fired at the underside, but by design nothing ever will.  It's designed to never be more than 100-150 m above any surface, and to land/lock while I mine in the small vessel.

Want to attack bases?  Better think about underside armor/armaments, or maybe even a rover tank.  Want to have a deep space worthy vessel?  Better make sure to think hard about your attack angles and where you want weapons, cause they'll be coming at you from everywhere.

I CAN'T THINK OF ANY OTHER GAME WHERE I'VE GIVEN THIS MUCH THOUGHT INTO DESIGN

it also has detailed shadow/light mechanics as well as orbits (sunrises/sets) which makes solar panels really cool to use/setup.  This makes sunrises not only visually striking but stupidly comforting as well as the panels start producing that sweet, sweet energy.

There are plenty of other reasons to love this game but for me its really just the insane attention to detail that was always there, and now the mods/scripting/progress the community has made that fill in the gaps.  Give it another 3-4 years and it will just be 3D rimworld in space with the best ship design systems in the business.

oh also there's multiplayer I guess.  I'll get there one day.

I've been playing Space Engineers for over 300 hours now, and I'm still not bored. That's because the game is endlessly creative and challenging.

With Space Engineers, you can build anything you can imagine. Want to build a massive spaceship? Go for it. Want to build a towering city on a planet? No problem. Want to build a giant robot? Why not?

The possibilities are endless. And the best part is, you can do it all in a beautiful and realistic world. The graphics in Space Engineers are top-notch.

If you're looking for a game that will challenge your creativity and ingenuity, then Space Engineers is for you. It's a game for the builders, the engineers, and the dreamers.

Pros:

Endlessly creative
Challenging
Beautiful graphics
Tons of mods and community content
Active development
Cons:

Can be buggy at times
Learning curve can be steep
Can be time-consuming
Overall:

Space Engineers is a great game for anyone who loves to be creative and build things. It's challenging, rewarding, and a lot of fun. I highly recommend it.

Would I recommend this game to others?

Absolutely! Space Engineers is a great game for anyone who loves to be creative and build things. It's challenging, rewarding, and a lot of fun. I highly recommend it.

Very fun game. Here are some pros and cons.

PROS:
-Creativity encouraged
-Multiplayer is fun
-Building is easy
-Survival is challenging
-Explosions
-Awesome community and lots of cool creations
-Some variety in the creative menu
-DLCs are reasonably priced
-Programmable blocks are somewhat easy to understand
-A good amount of planets to go to
-Lots of repeatability
-Customizing blocks and painting ships
-Really cool seeing what you worked on actually function like its supposed to
-Ability to copy and paste ships from save file to save file/server to server

CONS:
-3 Options for thrusters
-Max speed is set to 120
-Not a lot of weapons
-Crashes are unrealistic, instead of blowing up or slowly skidding while exploding, the ships sorta just bounce off the ground or whatever they crashed into
-Rotors and Hinges are extremely finicky
-Nothing to fight, there aren't many pirate bases and all that is there are drones
-Nothing to explore on the planets

Overall, this game is really great. The cons are more or less inconveniences and don't make the game repetitive or bad. Space Engineers is a really fun game with tons of freedom and content around every corner. Crafting the Cosmos, One Block at a Time!

Space Engineers catapults you into the cosmos with its intricate blend of construction, engineering, and space exploration. If you've ever dreamed of building colossal space stations, crafting complex machinery, and exploring the far reaches of the galaxy, this game is your ultimate playground.

The building mechanics in Space Engineers are nothing short of impressive. With an array of blocks, tools, and components at your disposal, you're free to construct everything from small shuttles to sprawling interstellar bases. The satisfaction of piecing together intricate structures is addictive and endlessly rewarding.

What truly sets Space Engineers apart is its attention to realism and physics. The game's realistic physics engine means that your creations need to be well-designed and balanced to function properly in a planets atmosphere or zero gravity environments. This adds an extra layer of challenge and depth to the building process, making every creation feel like a true engineering accomplishment.

The exploration aspect is equally enticing. Whether you're scouring asteroids for valuable resources, navigating the cosmos, or salvaging wrecked ships, there's always a sense of wonder and adventure. The vastness of space is beautifully captured, and the potential for discovery is boundless.

Multiplayer in Space Engineers elevates the experience to new heights. Collaborating with friends to construct massive projects or engage in intense space battles is an absolute blast. However, the complexity of the game's mechanics can lead to a steep learning curve, especially for newcomers, which might be a bit overwhelming.

While the visuals are adequate, they don't necessarily push the graphical envelope. Nonetheless, the attention to detail in ship design and the immersive sound effects help immerse you in the cosmic world you're creating.

In conclusion, Space Engineers is a space aficionado's dream come true, offering a deep and rewarding sandbox for engineering enthusiasts. The freedom to create, explore, and engineer your own space odyssey is a tantalizing prospect. Though the learning curve might be intimidating for some, the game's unique blend of construction and space exploration provides an experience that's out of this world!

An amazing game. The amount of dopamine this game causes to be created is extraordinary. Thank you so much to the developers for catering to people who enjoy complexity, calculation, and strategy, rather than the crowds that like to "come home and shut off their brain."

Please keep it up. My wallet will do it's best to support you going forward.

Build, Explore, Fight, Survive. Not like the typical though. This game's building has moving parts, a touch of physics, and is hugely complicated. You will not be throwing up 4 flat walls and a triangle roof. You will be building all manner of curves and components. The block list is huge, creations can be scripted using C#, there are AI blocks, AI waypoints, spawners, aiming configurations, lighting configurations for light blocks, ...there is just so much here, so much detail! You will indeed be engineering.

I did not buy this game for a long long time, because all my research told me it didn't have much combat. Well, things change over time. This game has combat. Lots of it. Especially with mods. There are at Gatling guns, rocket launchers, artillery shells, assault cannons, rail guns, etc, in vanilla. You can arrange the shooting angles in your build, throw on welders to keep them repaired. In a dog fight, you can target enemy power, thrust, weapons, cockpit, etc, for tactics, look for weak spots, take advantage of line of sight, etc. You can invade NPC structures, dismantle them and loot resources. You can even make your own weapons, using AI and warhead, by building a homing missile block by block, or perhaps crafting up your own bombs you'd drop from height. Mods add a plethora of options with hundreds of different weapons, shield systems, armor types, and the like. Combat can be very very involved in your build and in your fight. 

I'd compare the building to From The Depths, and of course Empyrion Survival Galactic. The latter was based off this game, but was built on Unity and has horrible performance compared. This game is on its own engine, so it's much better performing and multiplayer is much smoother. The building is much much better and detailed too.

This game is a blast with some friends. I would not expect good PvP with a bunch of randos though, as there are some cheesy tactics that can be employed. So, there has to be some honorable play and agreement. There are a number of multiplayer servers with enforced rules and supervising admin, that make for good fun. Of course, you could also start your own.

The single player is awesome and very challenging. There are a number of scenarios, each with some thinking required on how to get through it. I spent 100+ hours just on the tutorial scenarios. This is one of those games you will be dumping 1000s of hours into. You will build, test, edit, test again, and iterate. There are also sandbox starts with various conditions, resources, and maps. All of it can be modded to your heart's desire.

Speaking of mods. Holy crap! There are so many very very good mods. Custom weapons, shields, random encounters, various factions, NPCs, trade, new blocks, resources, all kinds of things to make your game as spicy as you want! The mod support is superb and some of them have been active for more than a decade and still see updates.

Again, the building is involved. If you are not someone who wants to be intricate to where you sit down and say to yourself, "Ok, I have 8 hours this weekend to build my explorer that's gonna carry my miner, complete with jump drive", then it might be a problem. This is NOT an arcade game. It is a thinking man's game. Tap into your creativity.

I love the level of detail. I bought all the DLCs even though they are all cosmetic. that's how much I love this game. If you are on my friends list, hit me up for some coop!

I've played this game off and on for many years (currently 1,100+ hrs) and think it's time for a simple review.

Review in brief:
BASE GAME: Thumbs up ('buy') - nice features, abilities, and over-all enjoyable (if sometimes buggy) game-play, as well as a lot of good community-created content.
DELUXE GAME: Thumbs down ('don't buy') - does not add content to the game other than skins and music, and REQUIRES THE BASE GAME to play! 
DLC (in their entirety): Thumbs down ('don't buy') - limited offerings and complete lack of original (not re-skinned) content.

Let me start this review with a cautionary note: the developer likes to nickle-n-dime the playerbase to death. The game currently has a "deluxe" version of the game (at $8, requires base game) and 11 DLC (at $5/each). The deluxe version is only an add-on to the base game, adding some new music and a couple skins into the game. Universally, the DLC's are small, adding only about a half dozen or so things; and none of them add new functionality to the game. The dlc items are entirely either re-skins of features already found in the base game (like off-road tires that drive exactly like regular tires or vending machines that have fewer functions than the store blocks already in the game), or purely cosmetic items with no functionality (like new block textures, dead bodies or kitchens that don't do anything). I believe that $20 (USD) is a fair price for the game, but the developer should offer a TRUE 'deluxe' version of the game (base game, deluxe add-on and all dlc's) for $40. Instead, this developer charges high cumulative prices for low content.

Now, on to the review of the game itself...
I first got this game about 8-9 years ago to play with my my (then) 12 yr old son. We both enjoyed it a lot and there has been  very slow, but steady, improvement over the years. This is a typical sandbox survival game - you run around collecting resources (ores and parts), in order to craft items (blocks/machines), which you use to build bigger items ...like bases, tanks and spaceships. Yes, the game can get very repetitive, but at least there is a "creative" mode which allows you to skip all of that and get right into building spaceships and stuff. To start the game, you choose between 3 gaming options: pre-loaded scenarios, 'custom game' (less structured game-play), and scenarios (mods) created by the player-community. (No, there's no 'character' to make, or anything like that... just pick up your drill and start digging!) Especially if you chose to start with a "space" scenario, getting used to a 6-degree of movement (up/down, left/right, forward/backwards) system that sometimes has no true "up" or "down" can take some time getting used to it... but that part of it's charm. I once built an entire "base" in an asteroid while floating upside down and didn't realize it until I turned on the artificial gravity....{!thump!}... I was on the floor and all the controls were on the ceiling!

The original version of the game was played entirely in space (hence the name, Space Engineers), but it has expanded to include surface world game play, as well. Depending on the specifics of the scenario/game-play you selected, you might be dodging asteroids, fighting space pirates, spiders, killer drones and other 'baddies' (the game AI is not very robust, so don't expect to much from it), or you might be playing in a peaceful universe all by yourself. Of course, if you're on a planet, there's always the weather to deal with.

Being a voxel-based game, there are endless possibilities of what you can build. Some of the building blocks include powered and remote-controlled items like rotors, pistons, industrial-sized hinges, etc... and don't forget the weapons, engines and other fun stuff any good spaceship needs! The game play itself is generally stable, but glitches and bugs are not uncommon, so be sure to backup your game often (there is an auto backup option). There is also a fairly useful re-color/texture system in the game as well. The downside is that many of the textures and block/part re-skins are only available via the DLC's. Speaking of the DLC's, they are quite small (typically only offering about a half dozen 'new' [re-skinned] items/functions to the game.)

The game can support multi-players, mods and scripts, which the player-community has put to good use by offering some truly interesting creations for your gaming pleasure.

6,174 hours played and it's still a crappy game.  Multiplayer is still broken. Laser Antennas don't work in Multiplayer past 15km.  Making a custom turret will likely do more damage to your own ship in the long run.  Automatons update will result in lost ships due to bugs in multiplayer.  Every update is broken upon release, like really broken, then you are at the mercy of QA'ing the software for them and hoping they decide to fix it.  Laser Antenna's have been broken for over 5 years now in Multiplayer.  

When you have 6,000 hours in a game the flaws are glaring.  You get to the point where you see other people trying to push the boundaries of the games with various things like rotors and or pistons and hinges and you laugh knowing they will die a horrible death.  The bug forums are a joke.  People report things with ways to recreate bugs and they are still told that the issues cannot be replicated.  Literally try to use a camera on another grid through a laser antenna over 30km away and watch it break connection after 1 second IF IT EVEN WORKS AT ALL.

The game is good, but you spend more time rebuilding things due to bug and learning about what you can't do in the game.  Frustrating for new players without a guide to say, "Yeah you can do that but then you'll die like this." to save them hours of frustration.

After playing for 420 hrs, I realized I still haven't even done all there is to do in space engineers. I really am enjoying this game, it has every thing a guy needs, space, guns, and the never ending yearning for the mines. The campaigns and challenges are fun and exiting and keep you involved, and curiosity pushes you to find out what happens next. I have yet to really feel out multiplayer, but the servers seem very stable, and the player base really is helpful when you need help or questions answered. Not to mention the mod support is amazing and the community is crazy creative. So all in all, great work to every one involved, I will keep coming back as long as the mines call my name. solid 9.5/10 one of my favorite games.

Just wanting to build an over the top space station through pure grit and determination to satisfy your inner child... So I just used the start in space option and got really lucky with Asteroids. I started playing this game in its beta stage. The game was a blast from the start, and I could see it going places. I have no complaints except for one; why isn't this on Xbox and PlayStation? The company could make some stupid money. All around, I LOVE IT!

When drilling, the resources that you're mining simply drop on the ground and then you gotta pick them up afterwards... now this would obviously be better if the resources simply went into your inventory like it does is many other games, but anyways... you gotta pick up these piles of resources and another issue is that the resources often roll away from you down hill so you lose lots of resources that way, but the worst and most illogical thing by far is the fact that the resources simply disappear... the resources literally get sent to the shadow realm after a while, which is the most idiotic thing ever. Why do you design a game where the resources drop on the ground, and then fxcking disappear? This idiotic design decision ALONE is enough for me to not recommend the game, and then we're not even getting into the fact that the singleplayer campaign is absolutely tortuous, or that slow-drilling gives resources but fast-drilling apparently gives zero resources (lol?) or that the entire process to start a new base on a map is shockingly obtuse because you need to mine AND grind down 50000+ stone which takes 4hours+ just to get your first assembler/refiner buildings. It's shocking. Other games like No Man's Lie, or Astroneer, or stuff like that are way way better.

For more reviews, visit my curator page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7851637/
For my full recommended list of games: https://steamcommunity.com/id/lfpg/recommended/

Space Engineers is an enigma wrapped in mystery, a masterwork of creativity and mechanics that indulges in its own artistry but leaves its audience in a state of wondrous confusion. For in this boundless expanse, one can soar to unimaginable heights, yet the guiding light of purpose remains obscured. It is a game that thrives on the journey but leaves the destination to the whims of the cosmos, and perhaps therein lies its profound brilliance and bewilderment.

Space Engineers claims to be a "game about engineering, construction, exploration and survival in space and on planets".

Engineering, by definition, is the branch of science and technology concerned with the design, building, and use of engines, machines, and structures.

The problem is that there are no problems to solve.

- There is no concept of aerodynamics, you can reach the max speed the game allows by slapping the same amount of thrusters to a literal cube as you would to a ship resembling a plane. 

- The max speed limit for any object is 100 m/s, that is way too low especially in space where you should be able to achieve much higher speeds. This means that no matter how fast-looking ship you build, it will still perform mostly the same as the first ship you have ever built.

- The controls for moving parts (i.e. hinges, rotors) are terrible, there is no easy and precise way to control them. I felt discouraged when trying to create more complex designs because they ended up being uncontrollable.

- The simulation of thrust is very simple, it doesn't care about thruster placement. You can make a ship with a thruster completely offset from the center and it will still hapilly climb up in a straight line because the thrust is applied to the whole vessel.

With that, there are no real engineering challenges offered by this game as everything is overly simplified. You have to make arbitrary challenges for yourself, but they will end up not really being challenges but just tedious tasks.

Another important issue is that the building in this game is simply not enjoyable. Building even a single block more often than not requires way too much time and materials. No one wants to spend 4 seconds holding LMB on building each small little block of a big ship. Material costs are fine, but your inventory allows you to realistically hold materials for maybe 8 simple blocks or 1-4 complex ones which results in constant trips back to your assembler or storage that only further worsen the problem of the game being tedious.

UI is one of the most terrible things I saw in a game - it is overly complicated and requires too much user input to perform what should be a simple action. Inventory management is also terrible, your items will end up in random parts of your conveyor system - alhtough to be fair you could solve it by using sorters, but a new player will have to suffer a long time before they discover it 10-20 hours in. 

I understand that many of those problems could be solved by mods, and thats fine, but this game simply has way too many issues in its vanilla state that should have been addressed long time ago by developers.

1/5 rating for the onboarding. I'm giving it a 1 because the initial investment that you need to make. If you can't save progress, without 3 hours of watching youtube videos and learning, there is no game. (it was actually more like 7 hours, because I've made 3 attempts)

Very hard to get into. Took about 3 hours to learn the ropes and actually get setup with a survival kit but didn't have time to power it before a server reset. Third time trying to get situated and still haven't been able to swing a permanent respawn. I know how, now, after a ton of BS.

Anyone reading this and wanting to play the game: a couple of tips; first, you need to build a Survival Kit, the ship you spawn in with disappears when you log off and you will lose all progress as soon as you're disconnected for ANY reason; after building that, you need to power it. If you don't, you're screwed and if you log out, die, or there's a server reset, you will lose all progress. Which is hours when you're first learning. 

I usually love games like this, but not this one. This was my third attempt. 

I will amend my rating if they add a basic respawn point at your initial landing site. There are just too many ways to lose all your progress. You log out: restart the game. You die: restart the game. Your internet is interrupted: restart the game...

Came back after like 5 years to see how things were now. Runs MUCH better. However, its still a boringly grindy and unexplained game. I assume most reviews are based from the scenarios and creative play

[b]Quite easily my favourite game of all time. [/b]
[h1]Space Engineers is a Sci-Fi, Survival-Craft, Open World where you build and maintain Space Ships, Rovers and Stations of your own design. [/h1]

Yes, at face value, It does sound like a typical Survival game. But where it really stands out is the building your own vessels. People like to point out that SE is "Minecraft in Space" because your ships must be built [b]By scratch, block by block. [/b] So. to get anywhere in the game, you're gonna have to learn how to do just that, and it can be a tough process to build something good (which would be my only complaint). 
Other than that though. You have free will over what you want to do in the game, there are very few limitations.
Space engineers also makes a great time with friends. Whether it's surviving together, battling eachother or having a build-battle, it's worth picking it up for you and a friend.

Try it out, learn to play (Though give it at least 50 hours, the learning curve can be steep), I can guarantee if you like space games like Elite Dangerous or Star Citizen,  Space Engineers is the Survival version.

[h1]10 / 10[/h1]

This game is a prime example of why I don't trust steam reviews.

The controls are comically difficult.  Indescribably difficult.  There is an hour of Youtube videos trying to explain how to play this steaming pile of crap.  Also, who uses Youtube videos to explain how to play their game?

The physics are incredibly off, so bad that your "rover" vehicles will immediately start to spin and roll along the ground and destroy themselves the moment you let off the gas.

Resource collection and management is laughably tedious and slow, so much so that it seems like it's baiting you into playing out your refund time so it can rob you.

I thoroughly suggest you avoid this game.  It's clear a lot of work and good intentions went into this game, but it is so poorly executed that it is inexcusable.

Where do I even start! this game has been with me since the world went into quarantine. and as you can see from how many hours i have racked up, it is something that is special to me!


[h1]Core Game[/h1]

Space engineers is a game for quite a few different types of people! I myself am not the most creative person, which would probably surprise you considering that i have so many hours in a creative building game. but for me the thing i spent the most time doing in this game was, just simply downloading things from the workshop, changing them to my liking, then just messing around with them in creative mode. like making a halo fleet and a covenant fleet using ships from the workshop and then batting them out! Also keep in mind that i don't have any friends that play the game very much, so most of  the stuff i did was basically like playing monopoly with yourself.

but the game is just as fun for people who have tons of creativity and can build amazing ships themselves as much as it is fun for people who like games like Rust. You can play on countless community servers, modded or not and have a blast! Space Engineers is not just a game for people who want to build fantastic ships or create the world of their dreams, it is also a game for people who love space combat and just blowing up someone else's stuff!


[h1]Developers[/h1]

As much as people say that the DLCs are a plague on the game, I don't really mind them that much. Even know i am the type to normally hate when games overly monetize updates via DLC. But space engineers is different in the way that they don't make the DLCs each 15 dollars, each one is always $3.99 which when you look at the average price of DLC on steam, is dirt cheap! And without these DLC the developers wouldn't be able to develop the game any further. The DLC is how the developers fund the games continued Development. If we didn't have DLC, we would still be stuck with 2017 Space Engineers! 

On top of that you can tell from the Devs live streams that they are very passionate about the game, something that you don't find very often nowadays. You can tell that they love and work directly with the community! They a while back released a completely free community update that added a LOT of community requested blocks and features. I think that the more Developers should take notes from Keen!


[h1]Final Summary[/h1]

This game is not just for people who want something to vent their creativity but also for people who want to blow up stuff and fight other players and for people who don't have much creativity, but who want to mess around with cool ships others have made in a sandbox experience.

This Game has passionate and dedicated developers that want to see the game and community flourish! Even know some people say that the DLCs divided the community (Which it very well might have), The game wouldn't be where it is now if it weren't for the DLCs.

Ok, so, here's the thing, this game is really fun, I like it a lot and I think it has a lot of potential, but there are some issues. The major one, is the grid mechanic. Trying to build a large ship is almost impossible (or at least I haven't figured it out yet) because the blocks don't always snap together, especially at 90 degrees angles, so whenever i try to fly a big ship that i built, it just falls apart and i can't put it together. I'd say that's the biggest issue of the gam, however there are a few smaller ones. One of those is the fact that you can't move while falling. I get that it's more realistic, but it,s really annoying when you fall to your death and can't do anything about it by aiming for a platform or such. Another problem is that the gameplay is not very intuitive. Of course there are tutorials, but the messages on screen aren't very helpful. I know thereare youtube tutorials, but I'd rather learn while playing the game, not watching videos about it. Still, the game is really fun but the building is incredibly annoying and I hope it gets fixed by, for example, being able to use a welder or some other tool to weld two blocks together as if they were snapped. Please fix.

Great game until they started to de-spawn asteroids, now the game is basically flying around 50% of the time looking for ore on asteroids because the one you found before is now gone.

Turns out that when you leave your massive mining vehicle with the internal batteries switched off it will disappear once you are 500m distance apart? Why? Because the devs thought its a great idea to improve performance by removing clutter? Reading forums it turns out that this has been an issue for many years now and there is no fix introduced by the devs. There is no way for me to recover my vehicle (back up files are automatically deleted and only the 5 most recent auto saves are preserved - which happens to be about 15 minutes of gameplay. This wasn't enough to notice that my vehicle was deleted (without any warning).

So the massive mining vehicle, that took me 3 HOURS to build was gone within an hour of completion because i happened to be 500m apart from it while having the batteries switched off. The big vehicle was right next to my base - and all of the sudden gone! Great job devs!

Well I have to say this is a tough one. Theirs a lot of game here for the dedicated. There is one steep learning curve here. Be prepared to spend hours watching you tube videos on learning how to do the simplest tasks. I have to say this is one of the worst UI's  ever designed. You have to wonder what they were thinking! I could imagine asking the programmers why in God's name  they designed it this way? I would guess the answer would be, to paraphrase Pink Floyd, "I don't know I was drunk at the time."
If you have the patience to make it through the UI  the game is quite enjoyable, lots to build and explore. Its very satisfying to build a simple spaceship and start exploring the universe.
But should I by this game? I hear you ask, and my answer is it depends on you.  Do you have the patience of a Saint? Are you prepared for fits of swearing and cussing ready to throw you computer out the window?  If you can handle that, Then I say go for it. If the tiniest thing sets you off, you better not buy this game!

So, after nearly 5 years and 3.5k hours on this game, I finally decided to take some time to give this game the review it deserved. Implicitly, the evidence is there for some types of people (looking at you, Lego fanatics and Minecraft nuts!), but if you have an attention span that has allowed you to get this far, BUY THIS GAME! 

I can not remember a game I am so eager to starting up like SE, every time. Fair warning, the learning curve can be quite daunting (as many hours as I have logged, I'm STILL learning stuff!) and the build time, depending on settings, may take hours to months to build. However, when you hear that "woosh" sound from your Gyros kicking in, and the hum of those engines when your ship leaves the station for the first time, its all worth it. Everytime. There will be your fair share of "WTF?! moments" but they are character building experiences at this point relatively for me because this game runs amazingly well now compared to earlier versions of the product. Also, the SE groups I have come to know makes me think that SE is one of the least toxic environments I have ever played in for any length of time. 11/10 recommend

Oh yeah, and watch for Klang...

Lastly, Keen, Marek, and our amazing modding community: Thank you for all of your hard work This is the game I have waited my entire life to play! YOU ROCK!!!

UPDATE 7/3/2022:

This game just keeps getting better like a fine wine! The love never goes away and the features keep improving! This game looks like it would incredibly fun if you know what to do and when I first opened it it gave me the feeling of opening up factorio for the first time, so it pains me to give it a negative review. I'm 23 hours in yet I still cant find cobalt to make metal grids to make thrusters for my first ship or a god forsaken small storage container. I'm certain it's something I'm doing wrong, but that's the thing, I've been trawling through forum posts and other google searches and I cant find what i'm doing wrong. I will probably go on to watch a playthrough on youtube to get my bearings and get into what seems to be a very fun game. This sadly is why I must give a negative review. 23 hours is what most people my age have as time to game in a week. It's been a while since I wrote my original review but my original statement still stands. The updates don't add as much new stuff as often as they used too as they are working on optimisations and bug fixes a lot more than they were before but that's still good anyways.

They've always done updates on thursday every week and as of yet I don't think they've missed a single week...in years... thats a lot of dedicated to the game and I can't wait to see it get better. If you like sandbox games but you want something a little more realistic which also features some badass destruction then this game is most likely for you.

One thing to keep note of for Space Engineers is as much as they have optimised it, for me at least, large worlds or planets can still lag a lot or just lag after a long session without any breaks. If you can put up with less than 60 a lot of the time the game is great though.

Of course there is one more important factor to consider when buying Space Engineers, the main game may have lots of content and being constantly added too but the mod community ensures you will never run out of content and I can see the mods keep coming for years to come.

[b]Title: Space Engineers: A Stellar Sandbox Adventure[/b]

Stars: ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5)

Space Engineers offers an immersive and captivating sandbox adventure that combines creative building mechanics with expansive exploration. Players can construct intricate space stations, vehicles, and spacecraft, showcasing their ingenuity and attention to detail. The game's realistic physics and dynamic environments add depth to the experience, whether it's mining resources, salvaging wrecks, or engaging in epic space battles.

Multiplayer functionality enhances the gameplay, allowing for collaborative projects or competitive gameplay. The community-driven mods and workshop support provide endless possibilities for customization and variety. Although the learning curve can be steep, mastering the complex controls and interface is rewarding.

Overall, Space Engineers fuels the imagination and provides hours of captivating gameplay. With its robust building mechanics, immersive exploration, and multiplayer features, it's a must-play for space enthusiasts and creative minds seeking an intergalactic journey.

Been playing it for 3 years now and yeah, I can tell you for sure that it's a sandbox. While possibilities might not be endless, they're more than enough to have fun, the most important part in all of that is to try invent new things through unusual ways.

Long story short:
1. Survival is interesting and fun, especially in multiplayer, but sometimes you need to set goals yourself

2. Creative is fun, but again, sometimes you may get stuck in thoughts, building meaningless stuff that won't make you happy or interested again and again

3. DLCs are.. Quite op in terms of combat and construction. It's not like they're P2W, but some blocks have properties which give a slight advantage over players without a particular DLC

In general, despite all the flaws, this game is fabulous! Possibilities are unusual, and if you dig a little bit deeper you might discover even more. So, average sandbox enjoyer would love it too!! UwU

I have done nothing but play space engineers for the last 4 days and have racked up about 40 hours. Its survival mode is quite similar to a game like Factorio but with a little less micromanaging. However for me personally, its still highly addictive and is like a digital Methamphetamine. Creative is quite good if you just like designing stuff, from small fighters to huge mobile bases the game engine can do it all. I'm not sure about multiplayer or larger servers but for me personally, it doesn't seem like a huge amount of fun if someone comes over to the base you've been designing and building for days on end. and just bombards it with some abomination that he printed out from the steam workshop.

Overall I give it a 8/10, Its still an extremely fun game if you spend the time to learn and if you go onto a server with some friends you can do such a vast amount of work in a couple hours that would take a solo player days on end. If you don't have any friends who can play then you could go searching around some of the community servers and see if any of the groups there want another member.
