Been a while since I updated my review, so here goes...
TL;DR: BUY THIS GAME!!!

General Overview:
Space Engineers is a semi-procedurally-generated building and exploration sandbox game using a cubic grid system for building spaceships, rovers, aircraft, structures, and even naval craft (if you use the water mod), kinda like Legos on steroids. The land masses are comprised of volume pixels (voxels) much like Minecraft, but a lot more realistic looking.

Basic Gameplay:
There are two major game modes, the first being what beginners use, Creative Mode, where the player can copy/paste in their blueprints, build blocks instantly, and don't have to manage resources (power, fuel, ammo, etc.). The second game mode is where the real game begins; Survival Mode. In survival mode, the player must mine/collect/buy and manage resources to survive. The player is dropped into the game world in either a deep space pod (if they choose to start in space), or an escape pod deployed high above one of the many planets. Space pods must locate resources on asteroids, and escape pods must search the planet for resources. Both space and planet starts have their pros and cons.

Highly recommended tutorials:
New players should really, really, REALLY watch Splitsie's tutorials on YouTube. Do it. Trust me, he makes the steep learning curve much easier. When you get more advanced, I highly recommend BlackArmor's videos, as he has some bangin'-good tips/tricks to improve your builds. I also recommend new players run the "Learning to Survive" scenario, which is basically a tutorial, will really improve your skills, and even unlock a special space suit.

Scenarios:
Space Engineers has some interesting stuff that can either add to your sandbox experience, or, experience really fun PvP and PvE/co-op multiplayer modes, as well as story-driven gameply complete with scripted events, objectives, etc. These special modes are called "scenarios," and they are absolutely worth playing if you want a challenge. One of my favorites is where the players are broken up into teams, are each given a garage and a short time to build a rover. When the time is up, the rovers approach the start line, and a death race ensues, where the other racers and the environment will fight you as you try to reach the finish line. Players can create their own scenarios, too. Try out Splitsie's "Scrapyard" scenario, once you get more familiar with the game, and want a real challenge.

Mods:
Space Engineers has one of the best modding communities I've ever seen, and modders are typically quite friendly, willing to listen to feedback, and even collaborate with other modders. The developers also highly support their modding community to the point where awesome mods have actually become vanilla features, and some modders have even been hired as full-time developers. There are so many mods, it can be overwhelming. I recommend you start with some of the must-haves, like Build Info, Build Hints, and Build Vision. You can even get more realistic skyboxes/lighting, like the mod "Space Just Got Real." There's even a cool mod called "Star System Generator" that can make you star systems using vanilla and/or modded planets, generating them in a configuration that can change things up if the vanilla star system gets too boring. There are also great survival mods such as "Eat. Drink. Sleep. Repeat!" and "Plant and Cook," which will give your character basic needs, and the ability to grow crops (and even use the bathroom for its real purpose!). There's so much you can do, and I haven't even touched on the somewhat controversial plug-ins.

Updates and DLC business model:
KSH has been pretty good about keeping core gameplay mechanics free when introducing new updates, and limiting paid DLC to purely cosmetic items as a way for you to help support the studio. Children complain that the DLCs are "too expensive." Each DLC is about $4, or the price of a cup of coffee, so if you're an adult with a job, the price of COSMETIC DLC is totally reasonable. I really like this model of "pay to support," rather than "pay to win." KSH has been stellar in their devotion to their community/customers, and compared to many big game studios, they put out highly polished content. We waited so, so long for the Automatons update (added A.I. blocks, and the coveted Event Controller block), but KSH's policy is to not release anything until it passes their high standards. Yes, occasionally a bug gets introduced, but they patch those right quick when they seldom happen, and they have an excellent bug-reporting system. I myself reported a bug, demonstrating how to repeat it, and within 72 hours, the ticket was read, and the problem fixed. KSH, as I said, are stellar, as long as you speak to them like an adult instead of a rabid, autistic child.

Ease of picking back up after a long hiatus:
Unlike Arma 3 (a game I wish I could play more), Space Engineers is pretty easy to pick up again if you haven't played in a while. The game allows for some crazy complex stuff (if you can code, there's a block that lets you write custom script, ffs), but the over all gameplay is easy to get back into. Space Engineers is one of those games where you get really into it for a few weeks, then you may not play for a few months, but then come back to it when other games just aren't fulfilling your need to create.

Conclusion:
I highly recommend this game. It's so good, and still very much alive after what? 10-ish years? It's a good looking game, too, and just so unique. You're sure to make some friends along the way, and maybe some enemies, too, haha! I've been gaming since 1989, and this game is way up there in my favorites. Probably not in my top 10, but probably in my top 15. I have played thousands of games across nearly every genre. Gotta recommend Space Engineers!

Figured it was finally time to leave a review on this game after nearly 300 hours.

The game definitely has its fun moments and the modding capability is excellent. It's a game with nothing like it that rewards creativity.

However, even after several years of relatively minimal content additions, the game is so poorly optimized that this creativity is punished at any sort of large scale. Running on a Ryzen 9 5900x, RTX 3090, 64GB of 3600MHz, I get about 30 fps on minimum settings when near any large scale structure like shown in the game description videos. 

Overall the game is fun and unique, but don't be too hopeful about huge bases, capital ships, and even moderately large battles.

This game is great. 210hrs in. Building insane colossal ships and planetary bases/rigs is too much fun. 
Jump entire canyons in a hover ship or a rover. Create self-constructing structures. 
All the workshop content for this game just adds to the fun. 
Pipe in your friends to help survive or build in tandem- dramatically lower work time. 
This game is so technical that it doesn't really have a ceiling.

This game runs like dog poop though. I have a 1070Ti +7700K + 16gb of RAM and Space Engis abuses my hardware, even on low settings. After a good bit of building, I find myself in the console manually removing free-floating objects so my friends don't lag out of my world or fail to connect. Often times the game client will crash or the physics in the game will just break- sometimes even corrupting my save files. How? I don't get it, but it's still a good game and probably worth every bit of $20

-----UPDATED REVIEW: June 24, 2023----
The game engine is still the biggest flaw of this game for me. I'm now on a RTX 2080, 32gb RAM, liquid cooled i7- all overclocked. The game engine cannot handle destruction, debris, collision and constructed objects all at once. When I get the industry needed to mine and craft in place, I become very limited in what I can build, and how creative I can get. I like to build mobile drilling platforms, and larger ships. It's very difficult to have both, keep them, and go off into combat or exploration without dropping frames or crashing the game. And if it were not for all the mods from the community, this game would feel completely empty. The modding community is the only thing that floats this game- keeping it alive for all the past years.

Space Engineers is a great game, especially for the price. You can build some amazing vehicles and bases, exploring planets and getting into fights or moving cargo. It's best experienced with friends in my opinion, but the majority of my time has been spent solo and the experience of designing and slowly welding up a massive ship is a relaxing loop. The biggest turnoff for most people will be the learning curve, as almost none of the game is tutorialised, so you have to invest a lot of time and effort to figure out how to best do things. Once you get over that hill then you'll start to notice things that feel missing: survival comes with no real natural challenges or even goals, the lack of small and large grid interaction is unfortunate, and at its core the game is relatively simple requiring few true engineering solutions. There are, however, plenty of mods to change these things and I feel they flesh out the experience well, and Keen has done their best not to change systems too much and break them, an impressive feat for a game with mods that still work from five years ago.

You should definitely get this game if it interests you, though be sure to watch some actual gameplay and tutorials first to see if the pace is right for you.

EDIT: having put considerably more hours into this game since my initial review, I've decided to change my recommendation to a lukewarm "thumbs up". Yes, it's a technical gong show with a list of "known + WNF" bugs a mile long which still has the nerve to pester you for DLC purchases, but there are community fixes for most of the really ruinous ones (except for the "players's vision adapts to light / darkness the literal opposite of how human eyes work IRL" one; no help for that), and once you've got it patched and modded up almost to the level of a Bethesda game, you eventually end up with a pretty decent "keep your hands busy while your brain chills out with a podcast" activity.

When building in this game, it is important to make your ships and space bases airtight, so that your character doesn't suffocate. However, when Keen decided to add a 'weather feature' to the game, all of this became a little less relevant. Because of poor design choice, the snow and fog from the new weather system found its way into every part of the game, INCLUDING every 'airtight' section. This was brought to Keen's attention. Hundreds of players reported the same issue via the bug report thread on Keen's website. 

Over the course of three years, the requests to fix the issue continued to pile on, with no response from Keen. After three years, Keen posted that the fix was declined (without any further comment or explanation). They simply placed a tag on the post in the bug report forum, effectively closing the issue. 

This company couldn't care less about their player base and will always take the easy/lazy way out when an issue arises. Steer clear.

A Bumpy Ride Through the Cosmos: Space Engineers Review

Space Engineers is a game that boasts a long and impressive history of delivering highly satisfying gameplay experiences. However, amidst its triumphs, there have been significant disappointments stemming from bad ownership choices and poorly implemented development decisions, resulting in a lack of clear direction for the game's future.

One of the standout features of Space Engineers is its intricate and detailed construction mechanics. The game provides players with a vast sandbox of possibilities, allowing them to build and engineer their own spaceships, space stations, and planetary outposts. The level of creative freedom is astounding, and the sense of accomplishment when your creations come to life is unmatched.

Throughout its journey, Space Engineers has managed to cultivate a dedicated community of players who thrive on collaboration and innovation. The game's multiplayer mode enables exciting cooperative projects, encouraging teamwork and fostering a sense of camaraderie among players. Exploring the vastness of space together, conquering challenges, and sharing experiences have undoubtedly been some of the game's highlights.

However, despite its strong foundation, the ownership choices surrounding Space Engineers have left many players feeling let down. Poor communication, questionable monetization practices, and a lack of transparency have eroded trust in the development team. Promised updates and bug fixes have been delayed or neglected, leaving players frustrated and disillusioned.

Moreover, some of the development choices have been poorly executed, hampering the game's overall experience. New features and updates have been implemented without proper testing, resulting in game-breaking bugs and performance issues. The lack of attention to fixing these issues in a timely manner has been disheartening, leaving players to contend with a game that feels unfinished and unpolished.

Additionally, the game has suffered from a lack of clear direction for its future. The development team's vision for Space Engineers seems scattered, with frequent shifts in focus and priorities. This lack of consistency has left players uncertain about the game's long-term prospects and has contributed to a sense of stagnation within the community.

In conclusion, Space Engineers offers a gameplay experience that can be incredibly satisfying and captivating. The freedom to construct and explore the cosmos alongside fellow players is a remarkable feat. However, the game's journey has been marred by bad ownership choices, poorly implemented development decisions, and a lack of clear direction. These issues have caused significant disappointment among the player base, tarnishing what could have been a truly outstanding game.

I've enjoyed the game itself, but unfortunately I can't recommend it.

Part of it stems from the lack of purpose. There is no campaign, and there is no variation or particular challenge in sandbox mode. The online mode can be engaging but is very dependent on who you're with; if you don't have friends playing then it's quite boring or hard to get in on.

The second problem I have is the developers greed. The multiple DLC packages for components that should've been in the base game is ridiculous. Additionally they have occasionally used updates to remove components that previously existed, only for them to be reintroduced later in a DLC packet. It feels like a bait and switch when they do it.

Overall, it's not a bad game, but there just is no way to justify how they're managing it.

If you understand the game, than it is perfect for building. If you want to build a giant mothership, with a thousand railguns, you can do it. If you want to go hyperspeed and jump 500km away, you can do it. The possibilities are endless. The creators really did think of everything. However, I would reccomened watching other peoples playthroughs to understand the games mechanics. And finally, this game is about trial and error. There will be a lot of mistakes.

I was so obsessed with this game when I jumped back in a couple weeks back that it messed up my sleep cycle for days, but for every high there is an unstoppable tumble down a hill of annoyances.

It started simple enough, my cargo truck / ore detector that I'd spent a lot of time working on and tuning just ran out of power before it could get back to base. No problem I happen to have just enough parts for a small reactor.. oh also need a small battery to get it working, hmm wow that sure took a lot of rock mining just to get the materials for that, I'm REALLY sick of rock mining at this point but I've yet to find a single iron patch in like 10 hours.. but okay, back on the road again, great.

Of course visibility on the way back is reduced to maybe 10 feet by weather effects so I find myself rolling into rocky, craggy terrain. Goes fine at first but quickly super stuck. Okay fine, this is awful but I can just spend the next 45 minutes smoothing out the terrain under the truck so it can get traction again and then carve out a canyon off to the side that's the closest way back to flat driveable terrain.

So here's the part where this turns from a recommend to a do not recommend. I get stuck. Not on a huge boulder or a canyon wall, no, it's a fist-sized rock that is floating in mid air. It's absolutely untouchable with my drill, no angle, no amount of wriggling changes this, it's just too dang small, but it's also absolutely impervious to my vehicle ramming into it, and it's perfectly positioned to stop me from getting this vehicle where it needs to go, or anywhere really.

Since I'm playing single player I can just enable admin commands, great... only to discover that the clean up function will not handle tiny fist-sized rocks floating in mid air, and my truck is too close to it for the voxel hands function to help either. It feels gross to even have to use 'cheat' tools to get out of this after all the hard work I put in to get where I am in the game now, and it feels even worse to realize that even if I throw every function at the book at this, it will do me no good.

If I were further into the game I could probably make some giant cargo ship to just clamp onto the truck and pull it out of there, but actually I'm not so sure because that tiny voxel is so perfectly positioned it would probably stop even that.. not to mention since I still haven't found an iron vein (that's the whole reason I was out there), I'd have to spend like five hours just mindlessly drilling rocks to get enough motors to get a sufficiently large air vehicle put together. 

So much obsession, just to have none of it matter either because the game lacks any meaningful mid/lategame content (my first playthrough), or because even with mods to make things more interesting, a bug present in the base game since forever (tiny floating invincible voxels that you can't get rid of) will present you with a challenge that no amount of engineering can actually feasibly mix. All you can fall back on is absolute miserable drudgery and I am completely spent. Don't go down this rabbit hole. It is not worth it.

In shorts, why negative review?
Because game advertises itself as something that it is not. In this game, you will basically be building, and building ONLY. The way that game is designed makes it virtually impossible to do anything else. On some promo materials there are big space battles with ships getting destroyed in a lot of funny ways including crashing into each other. But unless you deliberately build ships to see them getting destroyed in fake battle (or space station to crash your ship into) - this is not gonna happen. Every single ship needs to be built by hand. As well as it needs to be fixed by hand after said battle. And this can take a lot of time. So no - no survival, no battles, no actuall gameplay. Just building.

And if you're fine with that - the game is really good. Building and physics are top level, and super fun. You can save your blueprints and spawn them in creative - and then crash in super fun way. And that's what I've been doing mostly.

8/10 is my rating, especially for the base game. 

TLDR: Amazing game if you like a sandbox game that can go insanely deep. Your limitation in this game is your own brain. Don't expect the game (survival) to give you a lot of goals or quests, the opposite is true. Slightly overwhelming start and learning curve with minimal tutorials and explanation. Youtube will be your friend. The game is way more fun with friends and/or multiplayer servers. The community and players are not your average toxic teens. The people i've met online were all open minded creative players. Mods and other player made things on the workshop add quality of life and a lot of content in my opinion.

After +-600 hours on multiple accounts, my conclusion is really simple: this 10 year old game is thriving and  would have died without our beautifull community. The developers actually integrate some player made workshop things. Talking about the workshop: one of the most active ones on steam.

Bought this a few years ago and recently started again. It only gets better. With their new engine in development, SE2 is still 3-4 years away at least, but that's okay since it is a quality game.

Some say that there are to much DLC's and i understand that. However its a 10 year old game, and i completely understand that 1 DLC per year (4€/DLC) is needed to keep the game up to date. I own them all, and must say: some were maybe not worth it, some defenately are. But for me personally, this was worth it. Battle passes or skins of other games cost way more.

One last thing i must mention: PC version is way more worth it. I respect the launch for consoles and like that there is cross play. I got a Playstation. But it's unfortunate that accounts can't be linked (you have to buy everything again). Also the workshop, mods and community is a big part of the game experiencein my opinion and this is not the same for console players. 

Overall opinion: base game price is absolutely worth the money and fun. at 434 hours on this account now, i expect that to be 2000 in 2 years, but we'll see.

Thanks for reading!

At one point, I had a lengthy and detailed review here that followed the game from pre-launch, through launch, and even through the first few DLC.  Now that we're all done that I've just got one thing to say...

EFF THIS GAME!

The game jokingly uses the term "Engineers" but don't let that name fool you.  There's nothing even remotely correct about the physics in this game.  This game is nothing more than a "build something and blow it up" simulator, because even if you DON'T want them to blow up, and take extreme care to treat your builds like they're made of glass, they're gonna blow up.  Especially rovers.

Hours and hours of work will go down the drain just because you decide to slightly adjust a rotor, or hit a small bump with a tire, or touch down slightly too hard.  I'm not talking about breaking a landing gear, which would be realistic on the latter example.  I mean a huge chunk of your build will just go boom.

So yes... EFF THIS GAME!

If I could go back in time, I'd avoid buying it at all costs... If you have any notion to buy this game, go get Empyrion instead.

This game is nuts.

Minecraft on steroids is a good way to put it. I picked it up a while back when I was feeling creative and it hasnt let me down since. Multiplayer is definitely recommended, as survival is both difficult and... lonely. Gathering resources is a pain and this game is a grind, but all in all, I have gotten out everything that I put into this game.

Storage menus and component inventory within a grid's assembler access could use some work or change to become simpler or more user friendly. Accessibility to the onhand toolbar could use work or change as well.
Besides the glitch that happens when I loose internet and my game disconnects due to steam cloud sync requirement (please take note of this) I have never had a problem with any ingame issues. Mining is good, voxels are good, and the feel u get from using vehicles is surprisingly realistic. ESPECIALLY THE PANIC YOU GET WHEN YOU DAMAGE ONE.

Space Engineers is a remarkable sandbox game that caters to the creative minds of space enthusiasts, engineering enthusiasts, and those who enjoy open-ended game play experiences. Developed by Keen Software House, this space exploration and construction game offers players an expansive and immersive world to build, engineer, and explore.

One of the standout features of Space Engineers is its remarkable attention to detail when it comes to physics and engineering mechanics. The game places a heavy emphasis on realism, providing players with a vast array of tools, resources, and components to construct and design complex space structures, vehicles, and machinery. From building colossal space stations to constructing intricate ships, players have limitless possibilities to showcase their engineering prowess.

It's Minecraft in space. There's more to it than that but if you like space and you like Minecraft, you'll probably like Space Engineers.

The major difference between Minecraft and Space Engineers is automation. In Minecraft, there is none. You have to do everything manually. In Space Engineers, you don't need to wire your gun turret to the control station you want it to use. You just have to attach a gun turret to the same structure as a control station and that station will be able to control that turret.

Building things is very straightforward and pretty intuitive. There's even a "symmetry mode" that lets you slap together HUGE starships very quickly, as well as a blueprint system that lets you stamp down a previously-designed ship for easy construction.

UPDATE:
After three and a half years, I still haven't gotten bored of Space Engineers, and apparently neither has the developer. They have continuously added fresh, new content to the game that keeps making it better and better. Any year in which Space Engineers doesn't win the "Labor of Love" Steam Award, the awards are a lie; the voters were hypnotized by Mickey Mouse and Elon Musk (Cyberpunk? really?).

I think this is the only game for which I immediately buy every DLC, as soon as I see it. For a game about physics. You know, a space sim. It's actually a joke how bad they are. 3 Thrusters on the back of a vehicle should 100% send the vehicle spinning. Instead the vehicle magically floats. It's just not possible for something like to happen in reality so I have to say this game fails completely as a sim. Also sometimes my vehicles just get stuck in some gravity defying state when using pistons. until I add another item and them all the sudden gravity effects them again. Stuff like this ruins my immersion and frustrates me because; that's not how gravity is supposed to work.

You can build a lot of interesting stuff with the tools provided. It's sad that the engine itself has a lot of limitations. Basically don't expect to actually design spaceships based upon the physics of our reality because this game does not actually replicate them well. It's fun if you want to style something, but actually flying and engaging in combat is just pretty jank overall.  

There's a ton of customization available due to the included scripting functionality. If you really want to build something, you probably can. I definitely applaud the game for this unique form of creativity. Not many games allow you this much control over things. 

Overall, it's a really cool idea but it's held back by gravity feeling broken. I really hope the next engine improves upon all the issues with gravity. Actually having aerodynamics would be amazing. I'm hopeful for the future of this franchise.

I set this review to not recommended only for the general public. However, if you're prepared to deal with the myriad of glitches and "personality" of this game, then you'll really get into it. Be prepared to rebuild things, reload your save, turn things on and off again, etc etc. Just a few minutes ago I had to rebuild a battery on my ship because it suddenly couldn't recharge. No explanation, no reason, the game just glitched and suddenly the battery was useless. Had another ship I built from a workshop blueprint. Every last block of it was built and operational, but the hydrogen tank *refused* to fill despite all systems working. Built a bypass, suddenly worked. You will become utterly confused at many points in this game, and the worst part is you could do *everything* right...but you need to restart the game to make it work, or turn a system off and on again for it to work, or rebuild a block so it suddenly knows what it's doing. It's absolutely infuriating.

But if you can deal with that, it's extremely addicting.

Honestly, this is a great game. When it originally came out it had frequent, large updates, fan base and great workshop. Recently though, Keen Software House has made this game into a massive cash grab. As of writing this, there are 11 DLC's. Which is an absolutely ridiculous amount, especially for the tiny amount of content they each add. I don't think 4-5 new items and a few skins is worth $5. I will say however that the modding community is still strong and probably the only thing keeping this game good since Keen won't do anything. Maybe buy this game when it goes on sale? But as someone with over 700 hours in this game, I wouldn't really recommend it nowadays unless you really like the genre.

Unleash your creativity. Build beautiful, elaborate spaceships, only to crash spectacularly into a voxel-based planet to make the most amazing custom-made, unique crater, created based on the impact speed, angle and durability of objects that collided. Wander around the twisted steel and burning modules and contemplate how you gave your behemoth enough engines to lift itself, but forgot to account for the massive weight of the ore in your cargo hold that you just mined a short while ago.

Rebuild, improve on your design, and try it again until you achieve perfection. Then tear it down and build it even better. 

Can be enjoyed both while playing solo or with friends, playing in creative mode, surival mode or in between with custom difficulty settings. Plenty of mods, super cheap DLC that are mostly just cometic variations of free blocks and modules, and constantly improving for a decade. 

If you like to build stuff, this is the game for you. 

Has even different weapons and an option to turn on the hostile AI. Carve out your name in the enemy armor using a minigun, or blow them up a new hole with rockets, artillery or a rail gun. Fire the guns yourself or let the AI assist you in recreating massive battleship battles. Finish off any straggler with your trusty rifle or fire a rocket in their face from your portable rocket launcher. And when the battle is over, use a scavenger ship to grind down the valuable scrap from your enemies and melt it down in your refinery into valuable resources for you next battle. Throw their wrecks inside a grinder pit and watch it get consumed in sparks while your ship is sitting in a welder pit you built earlier, fixing it for you, using the blueprint you created.

Space Engineers is an extraordinary game that takes creativity and exploration to new heights, or rather, depths of space! As an avid player, I am thrilled to share my positive experience with this gem of a game.

First and foremost, the level of freedom and customization offered in Space Engineers is simply unmatched. From constructing enormous spaceships to crafting intricate planetary bases, the possibilities are virtually endless. The game provides an extensive array of building blocks and tools, allowing players to bring their wildest engineering dreams to life. Whether you're designing a sleek interstellar cruiser or a rugged mining rig, the satisfaction of seeing your creations materialize in the vastness of space is unparalleled.

The attention to detail in Space Engineers is truly commendable. The physics-based mechanics add a layer of realism that enhances the overall immersion. Watching massive structures come to life as you assemble each component, meticulously placing thrusters and gyroscopes, creates a sense of accomplishment that few games can deliver. The attention to realistic physics and engineering principles adds an extra level of challenge and reward, making every successful construction feel like a true engineering feat.

Furthermore, Space Engineers offers a diverse and dynamic universe to explore. Whether you prefer exploring alien planets, asteroid fields, or engaging in epic space battles, there's never a shortage of excitement. The game allows for both solo and multiplayer experiences, opening up a whole new dimension of collaboration and cooperation with friends or fellow engineers. The multiplayer mode especially shines, as the cooperative efforts and shared achievements create an exhilarating and social gaming environment.

The developers of Space Engineers have also done an exceptional job of supporting the game post-release. Regular updates and the active involvement of the community showcase their commitment to delivering an outstanding gaming experience. The addition of new features, bug fixes, and optimizations have kept the game fresh and engaging, ensuring that players are constantly discovering new content and enjoying a seamless gameplay experience.

In conclusion, Space Engineers is a stellar game that combines limitless creativity, realistic engineering mechanics, and captivating exploration. The freedom to build, explore, and conquer the vastness of space is an exhilarating experience. Whether you're a seasoned engineer or new to the genre, this game offers an immersive journey that will keep you hooked for countless hours. I wholeheartedly recommend Space Engineers to any player seeking a unique and rewarding gaming experience.

Fun interesting and a childhood favorite getting friends to play with makes this game 1000X better.

Fun to play with friends in survival. 

Otherwise, this game is bit dull if played solo, not much content other than building whatever you wish untile you get bored or get mods to make space/planets with some kind of "life"/challenging. 

If your plays style is solo, and if you are undecided between Space Engineers or Empyrion, then the later gives you a lot more of content and paths, than SE.  

Bugs, well the game some core issues beyond of the lack of content (plus lack of blocks),  but if you can look beyond those issues that will not be addressed by devs then you might return and replay the game be entertained building something else that you have not done before. 

As mods go, there are awesome mod community keen on give the game some content and resolve some of the core issues like lack of blocks that should had been part of the game from beginning. So kudos to all of them that contribute with their time and expertise enhancing the game experience and giving it some credibility.

The UI/UX is not user-friendly, making it uncomfortable to navigate and detracting from the overall experience. The gameplay lacks depth and meaningful content, resulting in a lack of engaging activities to discover and enjoy. The inability to build rotor and piston blocks from projectors in survival mode limits creative possibilities and adds frustration. The game world feels empty and lacks immersive elements, further diminishing the overall experience. The optimization is notably poor, resulting in performance issues and making it one of the worst-optimized games. Furthermore, attempting to address these issues with mods requires knowledge of the C# programming language instead of more common options like Lua or Python. This limitation is highly disappointing and contributes to the overall negative experience. Another frustrating aspect is the collision system, which often leads to half blocks occupying the space of a full block. This issue not only affects the aesthetics but also makes building ships and structures more challenging and less satisfying.

Updated review after more hours in multi with friends: 

- The UX is absolutely terrible. That is the main reason why things are complicated when you first start playing it. It's not that things are complicated to do, it's that the interface is so bad it can sometimes be challenging to understand how to do things. 
- Physics and numbers are not nearly as predictable as they should be for some things such as thrust, power and piston behavior (at least with a chain of them).
- The game, in particular in multiplayer, is filled to the brim with bugs, and has a massive GPU memory leak which causes it to instantly take up ~90% of a 3080 Ti 's memory. 

To compound on the above, the game's been out for a decade now so none of these problems should exist. 

Stop adding cosmetics and fix things.

Over the years this game has continually added content and sought to address the issues the community brings.

Keen isn't perfect, but I've enjoyed the evolution of this game and am excited to see what they have in store for the future.

Unfortunately I just cant get into it.

My biggest gripe is that moving my mouse left or right also rolls my character.  You cant just turn. As in, there is no 'yaw' in this game.  There is only 'yaw+roll', but there is also 'roll'.  If you want to yaw left, you yaw+roll left, then have to roll right after that.  Made worse that yaw+roll is analog (mouse), but roll is digital (keyboard) that is only 0m/s or 110m/s, so tap gently.  And yes, if you are not fully measuring your button press it can slam your head into things killing you.  This is for basic looking around in the game.

Second biggest gripe is your Survival meter.  Think Fallout 76 but more aggressive.  If you have to get up to take a shit, better recharge to 100% and make your break quick, because your energy level will be beeping on your return.  So you have a 10min leash on you, all while you are trying to learn the game. Which is complicated.  

But it's complicated in a good way.  I want to learn this, but it's just not fun.  

TL:DR
SE is like trying to rebuild a car outside in 50kt winds, and your 'significant other' keeps texting heavy drama every 10min.
I just want to try to build a f*ing car.


Note; I did try to use a Controller so I could try to adjust my roll as I turn with two analog inputs, but trying Xbox, PS4, PS5, and a steam controller....The game doesnt see any of them.  Game settings Specify Xbox One...I'm not buying a controller just because the developers are lazy.  xinput is xinput, and direct input has been around since the 90's.  And this game had 10years to get it right.  Hell it's coming out for PSN, so we know they understand directinput....

EDIT:
The devs have since fixed some issues, (to a certain extent) regarding collision, clang, and autopilot, in recent updates. In addition to this, they have added some mission type things, but the game is still hindered by high latency and lag in multiplayer, as well as player movement on ground.

_______________________________________________________________________
I bought this game way back when it was a beta, and I was very very excited to be playing a game that allowed for so much creativity and freedom. 

Let’s talk about some of the best parts about this game: 

-Unlimited creativity 
-Sandbox survival 

And that’s about it. That’s really all this game has to offer. There is zero exploration really because the planet and asteroid generation is procedural and has no wildlife, unique structures or cool finds, and no end game. There are no NPCs to interact with, although the economy update was a huge step in the right direction, the game still simply feels empty. Ships randomly spawn and you can either ignore them or destroy them for resources but it’s not really worth it. There were some game modes introduced that allowed you to build a base and survive waves of drones etc, but it’s not that great. Multiplayer would be amazing if only they could fix de sync issues and lag, these limitations make the game very unplayable in some cases. The devs have continued to add dlc that has done very little to advance the game. The DLC in most cases has been cosmetic and added absolutely nothing besides cool looking blocks. However, they did add a few blocks that fundamentally changed some ship designs and rovers, but you still had to pay for it!! The lack of important ship building blocks (more shapes) and convenient blocks (different cockpits, weapons, shields, etc) has only been made possible by mods. 

There’s a few problems IMO that still plague the game that have been here since day one. 

1) Collision 
The devs can’t figure out how to make proper collision physics to save their lives. It’s actually terrible. Clang plagues the game, and actually though this can be a good thing in some cases because it can be used to make some pretty powerful weapons, but it’s still a bug. 

2) Hit boxes
Each block has a hit box that takes up waaaay more space than necessary. This causes small and compact builds to become unnecessarily large. 

3) Wheels
Rovers are heavily advertised, but their inability to perform simple tasks like turning at higher speeds makes them only usable at slow speeds and proceeding ever so carefully over terrain. The wheels do not grip properly and if they are off camber slightly it will cause the river to flip while turning. 

4) Autopilot 
 It simply doesn’t work. Scripts and mods have helped to fix this, but the devs seem to have said f*ck it and just ignored it since it’s inception. 


At this point, you’re probably wondering why I have over 1,000 hours in this game. The ability to create on this scale hasn’t been accomplished by many other games that I’ve played, a d honestly that’s what brings me back. But the devs failure to remedy problems that have existed since day 1 and their addition of cosmetic DLC has made me furious. Imagine if Minecraft made you pay a premium for every new set of blocks they came out with. 

Overall, save your money until the devs get their heads out of their butts and fix the fundamental problems with the game and add content that will progress the game.

Space Engineers is an incredible game that has captivated me since I first started playing it. The game is a sandbox-style space exploration and construction simulator that allows players to design, build, and pilot their own spaceships and space stations. With its stunning graphics, realistic physics engine, and deep game play mechanics, this game has become one of my all-time favourites.

The level of creativity and customization available in Space Engineers is truly impressive. The game features a vast array of different parts and components that can be used to build almost anything you can imagine. From small, nimble fighter craft to massive, sprawling space stations, the possibilities are almost endless.

One of the things that set Space Engineers apart from other space sims is its focus on realism. The game's physics engine is incredibly accurate, allowing for realistic movement and maneuvering in space. This means that designing and building your ships and stations requires careful consideration of factors like mass, thrust, and fuel consumption.

Despite its complexity, the game is surprisingly accessible. The tutorials and help menus are well-designed and easy to follow, and the game's community is incredibly helpful and welcoming. I've had a lot of fun learning the ropes and exploring the game's many features.

In terms of graphics and presentation, Space Engineers is a real standout. The game features stunning visuals and an immersive audio experience that really draws you into the game's world. Whether you're flying through space or exploring the interior of a space station, the attention to detail is impressive.

Overall, I would highly recommend Space Engineers to anyone who loves space sims or construction games. The game is deep, engaging, and incredibly rewarding, and I can't wait to see what new adventures await me in the depths of space.

An amazing game that challenges your creativity and design skills. 

Solve problems such as, what vehicle design best tunnels through 5m of stone to get the iron vein I want? How do I transport that iron back to the refinery at my home base as quickly and efficiently as possible? How do I power my vehicles? What's the best way to strip a planet of its ice, so I can fuel rockets to get to space?

There's a good 80 hours of natural problems in the survival world that will keep you invested and building, frantically improving on old designs, slowly getting new power sources that allow for bigger and better things, trying to get space bound for the juicy uranium ore.

The only problem is the end goal - there isn't one. Sure you end up with overflowing resources pulled through automated refinery lines and assemblers, automatically welding up your advanced ships and massive station blueprints, but... why? The main loop of collecting more resources in better ways leaves the world feeling a bit empty.

What can I say about a game in which I'm nearing 1500 hours of playtime. I would rank it among the best sandbox games and there is hardly anything to complain about. The game lets you do pretty much everything you can imagine. Do you want to build a spaceship that only consists of railguns? You can build it! You want to build an automated shipyard? You can build it! You want to build a rover that can only move by the recoil of artillery? You can build it!
You can build all of this without mods. But with mods, there are no more limits. This ranges from airlocks as a singular block or a few new Clang Cola propaganda posters to thermonuclear weapons and a Death Star laser. 
And after a friend of mine rammed my ship and shot it in two with around 20 railguns, I have to say that Space Engineers is my favourite game.

They put a lot of heart and soul into it. I would rate it 7.5/10 personally.
However in my experience playing this game on various bits of hardware. This is has to be most poorly optimized game I have played. I kid you not. This has been the only game, out of my entire library of 200+ games to BLUESCREEN my computer. I have met the system requirements, even the recommended requirements. Yet this game manage to somehow crash not only the GPU (multiple times) but straight up crash the entire computer. Considering others on here have reported performance issues which seems to be on the low of the priority scale. I'd say get an upgrade and keep the settings not on high.

But what about the game itself? I'll say that is probably just a 'skill issue' with the bugs I've experienced or whatever and I'll talk about the game.

It's good but not great.

Really though I find it relaxing to build and fly the ships but their is not much to do. I find it misleading how you see sprawling battles and vehicles battling each other on the store page and in the game on the title screen while that's really 2% of what you're doing, unless of course you're playing multiplayer, but unless you have a ton of friends willing to duke it out there isn't much in terms of combat, even in MP it's hard to find people on servers since the map could theoretically be infinite. Sure, if you willing to you can install mods but that's a band-aid solution to the problem. I hate to say it, but singleplayer and multiplayer is very empty just like space. You're lucky to see a ship sure, but the AI is barely anything to walk home about. I think the passive mobs in minecraft are more of a threat than most ships in Space engineers (Mods/Scripts not included of course).

I have noticed another thing though. The community seems to be split by the game design decisions the developers have been making. You get two people here. The ones that are like me and seem concerned about the future of the game and want it to be better or the people that are oblivious to the games direction and seem to think it's fine without fault. Sure the content is nice, and it help the developers get their paycheck but if the design isn't that much intuitive without an actual gameplay loop then what's the point of giving any criticism about it if the community doesn't care? Like sure, there's no endgoal, but there isn't much to shoot or to fight without installing mods.
T
he threats that are on the ground are broken janky AI dogs and spiders that barely effect the gameplay when you have a game about... space... and ships that can fly. In a game about building, flying and fighting space ships. It's very odd and it's super basic and there isn't much expansion on it. You can fight other ships if you get lucky and they spawn but most of the time you're flying around and gathering resources, and if you find a trade depot they are very empty and offer basic supplies, but are more of a time sink than anything. The battles are great in space when they happen, you have to consider fighting them but if you're caught without weapons you're screwed and have to start all over.

From what I understand people have been wanting to have AI in the game that actually is a threat and a mechanic. Again we go back to the split community, most of everyone wants it but the people who think the game is okay don't realize it would be for the better due to adding somewhat of a challenge to the very minimal gameplay loop. 

Rimworld, Astroneer, Minecraft, Terraria, Starbound all have some sort of gameplay loop in it that at least makes it somewhat meaningful to get to the endgame with challenging obstacles to get their that make people explain their stories. Space Engineers doesn't and that's what is holding it back from being an alright game to a great game.

I'd rather keep this descriptive of what I think is the problem. Which is probably not, and I don't want to just say 'fix ur darn gam' and get angry. I can see potential. Just... they seem to have priorities elsewhere. Time will tell though.

I don't recommend this game to anyone until the developers address this serious issue.

It's really difficult to describe this game properly without writing an essay, so here are a few reasons why I love this game.

1.) The learning curve is only steep in single player...remember that. Some servers (depending where you are in the world) have amazing communities full of active and very helpful players. Say hello, ask some questions...even if 90% of people ignore you, the other 10% are usually just what you need.

2.) The sheer amount of possibilities is difficult to comprehend. You think there's probably a ton of things to do, but a ton is just a drop in the cosmic bucket, my friend.

3.) Stone Industries. This server is everything to me, I don't play solo, I don't play on non-dedicated, or even other servers. On average, there's about 75 players, with 90-120 on a good day, and maybe 40-60 on a bad one. There is a proper discord channel, the admins are very active, and some of them are legendary *cough* FreedomStar.

4.) “Space is big...really big. You just won't believe how vastly, hugely, mind-bogglingly big it is. I mean, you may think it's a long way down the road to the chemist's, but that's just peanuts to space.”

― Douglas Adams, The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy

I love the building in this game but the Survival needs a major overhaul.

 - Health is far too low 

 - Energy needs to be constantly replenished and there isn't a way to increase it like bottles for Hydrogen and Oxygen

 - There's no way to get armor to negate damage on person

 - Your Jetpack alerts for getting too low on Hydrogen don't trigger until you have 3 seconds remaining of fuel

 - The PVE is really lacking in content in the base game, which thankfully can be subsided with mods from the community

 - Speaking of the community, for a game so heavily based on Community Creations (they are the 4th largest Workshop on Steam) their Workshop integration is so poor, it's an absolute headache to upload and edit a creation.
Even the thumbnails don't load properly if you take a screenshot at the wrong angle and the image is over sized. Which you then have to navigate to the files, find the thumbnail, open it in paint and crop it down to the right mb size.

 - Weather would be fun however it is poorly implemented and goes through buildings and ships

 - Now for my biggest complaint. The UI is utterly abysmal, the mere fact that this sentiment is  apparently popular and raised often in the community and has yet to be addressed in years astounds me. There is no reason the "Inventory" should be split between 3 keys. Equipping a welder should be easy, but no, instead of the usual open your inventory and drag to hotbar, they chose to not have a hotbar on that screen. You have to open the blueprint screen, search for the specific version of the welder you have in your actual inventory, and equip that to your hotbar instead. 

 - and lastly the wiki and any info on this game is incredibly difficult to find and takes going into the Discord just to get a simple answer.

With all that said I do enjoy this game, the community is great, and the Devs are truly passionate about their game and it's future. They deliver cool updates, talk to the community through streams, and are not greedy like other Devs in the Survival Genre.

After playing this game for a week getting frustrated unistalling waiting a year and repeating this cycle for a decade i can surelly tell tat this is creative only sandbox. this isnt a full game but a indev demo marketed as game.
Why so critical?
-survival experience is laking at the least. To survive you need only o2 which is created by 2 block solution,
     Mining is hell, firch try to find asteroid in space  with needed ore (can take literal hours with vanilla speed limit on 100m/s) then spend hours mining hauling and processing it. And aster getting every of ~8 ores you are done/ no need to mine more because you are set with ingoth for life.
     Building is as slow as it can be, why is building so freaking slow?! keen?! firstly you need to place carcass then haul components then weld it (can be simplified with welder ship) add to this redining ore and component prodiction and you are looking at hours of time to build basic box ship.
     Ship parts are dumb. Quite literrally dumb, you cant setprodition quotas for components to have stockpile, thrusters cant do vector thrust (so you need to place thruster facing all 6 directions) and to control of their thrust , either 100% or 0% power (yes you can set hotbar groups to set overrides, but this isnt maneuvering controll) , etc.
     UI makes me bleed from eyes. after changing it multiple times Keen got it to usable state, but still painfull to use. no hotbar binding to hotkeys (outside of preprogrammed ones like depower and switch lock to all things) aswell no ability to unbind those actions from buttons (ie to switch thruster controll to script, or make "P" contoll single connector).
Inventory management is annoing with all scrolling you neen to do, with to ability to presort inventories in terminal (so you would always see forst on the list cargo with components and h2 tanks with bottles). Prodiction ui is a nightmare which only get worse and worse with mods adding more prodiction machinery.
     Flight ... shouldnt it be core design of this game? it is slow and annoing, either you biuld small ship with abundant thrust (0-100m/s in 2s) or it will be painfully slow and unresponsive with no way to set cruise speed and autorotate to camera direction. Docking...... just why??? with all stated above it's so annoing to allign connectors to lock, even worse when you need to rotate camera basckwards but controls remain not rotated. so many connectors blasted bocause i hadnt switched off magnetic force on them so ship would get fliget and rotated upon contact. Collisons are the WORST. Either you place wheels/blastdoors on every contant surface or get random breakages because only wuth speed less than ~3m/s there are safe zone any more and hello damage. Why there is no way to switch controls to match camera direction from which you are looking?

TLDR. I do NOT recomment this game becouse it hasnt progressed since first publishing in 2014. The only updates it is getting latest years is a cashgrab for s reskin of a dosen blocks and hopefully a single new feature that doest have affect on gameplay.

I *really* don't want to give this game a negative review, but it needs a pinch more features and polish in order to warrant a recommendation. Unless you are a hardcore player and don't mind a meh ROI on engagement, I'd stave away.

TLDR: As a game, it needs work. As a physics sandbox, it's phenomenal, bar a few scuffs. Survival mode feels grindy and creative mode feels hollow.

Let's start with survival. Some of these issues are remedied with mods, but that's not a good fix.

Firstly, the grind; There are little early game options other than dropping on the deck and smacking your drill against some dirt until you have enough rocks to turn into a base/vehicle, provided you don't start with one. You could artificially crank up the efficiency of blocks and tools or start with a prefab base, but takes the heart and soul out of it. It's even worse when you don't start close enough to resources either. Here are a few suggestions that might just help:
 - Adding cheaper blocks for smaller grids (like fabricators/refineries) may help.
 - Adding a slow but accessible way to get hydrogen, like vaporators.
 - Introducing tools like those mini-drills from satisfactory. Means less drilling and more ship building on your part.

Secondly, there are a lot of quirks and weird restrictions to survival building that make it unfun:
 - Small ships require a connector or have power-gen on board, there is no in between. Allowing ships to be powered off bottles would be nice, or being able to hot-swap batteries you can charge at base.
 - Connectors are static. You can't just connect the two with a tube, you're stuck with having to tediously docking properly.
 - Lifting vehicles on planets is more difficult than it should be. Being able to jack it up without a piston would be nice.
 - There is no terrain editing or terrain block (ie, concrete), it's all metal. Anything not connected by block shares no power, and as mentioned earlier there is no way to connect grids with a tube or wire.
 - Wheels are awkwardly separated into left and right. This could be set in a control panel instead, reducing on UI bloat.
 - You will often find yourself missing few a parts when building something; You can't just make rudimentary items in your suit on the fly, so get ready to do a lot of back and forth.
 - The UI is a tad tiring to use--icons sometimes too look similar. You will frequently find yourself looking at it just to find how many parts you need.
 - Tools take up slots for building rather than having their own dedicated keybind/slot in your inventory. The same applies for weapons.

Thirdly, there's a lot of nuance lost that could be fun to work around. For example, being able to pick up water from planets would be another good way to get hydrogen, or temperature of running machines having more of an effect on your ship. Having tangible NPCs would improve combat (and would give the guns actual use), add new gameplay options (like transporting passengers), being able to recruit NPCs to run your base, etc. Being able to repair ships by looking at a blueprint/hologram to find the damage would be cool as well.

Creative mode is a different beast; it doesn't have these issues because they are completely removed. That being said though, it makes the game feel rather hollow as a result. You don't have to manage your electricity use, you don't have to work around power generation, you don't need to worry about fuel, pressurization, temperature (not that it really was that important), etc. A lot of the fun of engineering a ship to survive the elements is effectively deleted, with most of the fun design going to building a fancy hull. That being said though, this carries over for most game's creative modes.

I should state I do enjoy this game, especially with mods patching up the missing spots, but I can't exactly recommend it.

Exceptional game concept, Single player runs buttery smooth.  The mods options are endless and integrate well.  If your a fan of sandbox games and space excites you, then this is your game.  the UI is a bit clunky at first, but after a while you will slip smoothly into its' use.  the 6 degrees of freedom of motion can be disorienting to the new player, you'll either hate it or love it.
Pros: Fantastic mix of physics simulation and fun play style, in a sandbox world of endless exploration and creativity.  Single Player is solid and seems to rarely have issues even though the game is still in development

Cons:  Multiplayer is flimsy.  The playing together is excellent, but there is no tools to prevent hacking, the server is quite limited in capability.  Servers are typically limited to small groups and often suffer frequent issues, crashes and wipes.   UPDATE: Multiplayer has improved drastically, however servers are often overloaded with mods and laggy or under populated.  However the situation is still improving.  

Conclusion:
Great game, I recommend it to anyone.  but don't buy if you have your heart set on a rich multiplayer experience that will run smooth and long..  a lot of work to be done in the arena yet, but I believe it will get there eventually.  Multiplayer has improved, now server admins just have to start balancing thier mods and making use of better tools being developed for management.

I really wanted to like this game. I have many friends who play and enjoy it a great deal, so I finally thought I'd give it a try. I loaded up the first scenario and it was a great deal of fun. 

I decided to play a regular survival mode on Earthlike and after 10 launches I finally landed my pod on flat ground, upright. (1)

I spent a lot of time digging out stone so that I could manufacture enough raw goods to make my first assembler and smelter. The default keybindings for the game are absurd, and whenever I'd remap the keys to something sensible the game would just revert. 

I landed on some silver and gold but after retrieving some ore I found out that my smelter couldn't do anything with them. I converted the pod into a mining ship and have a nice little wind powered base going.
 
I took the mining ship out to find ores and just wasn't able to adequately clear enough ground to get down to rock, without having to land and dump the rocks out or return to base and offload. No matter what I tried, I wasn't able to RMB click or toggle it in a way to "just destroy stone" so I could clear out enough to get to ores, much like you can do with the hand drill (2)

I decided in an effort to save on energy I would build a Rover that would be able to transport the drill back and forth, with enough cargo to make the trips worthwhile. After hand drilling out the cobalt and iron I found and hauling them back to base while my drill charged, I then planned out and built a rover. 
I managed to get it set up, though it was a bit of a bulky beast, but I was able to dock the mining drill to it and set out. The center of gravity was a bit too high and seeing as "parking brake" undocks the mining ship, while parking at the ore pit the mining ship shot off and exploded both vehicles. (3)

It was somewhat hilarious, though I didn't have blueprints for the ships. I decided, let's go check out the workshop. I've heard good things about items in the workshop.
... in order to use the items in the Steam Workshop for a game loaded in Steam I have to connect to a third party site mod.io and create a separate account? That was what caused me to uninstall the game. 

Good luck engineers, I'm sure there's plenty of people who enjoy this game. I'm just glad I had the foresight to just buy the base game and not go full hog and buy all of the DLCs.
If you want to build space ships, I recommend.

I've fell in and out of love with this game for pretty much it's whole decade old journey, back before I could even play it.
It has given me and my friends so much joy over the years from personal to public servers working for and against each other, waging wars against players and clang alike.

Every time the game get's stale someone in our friend group finds some interesting take or mod that changes the gameplay and rejuvenates the love.

Space engineers is easily my favourite game of all time, the joy of creating stuff for aesthetics, ergonomics, purpose, and overall cool factor is something I've not seen any other game come close to competing with.
In my eyes it's the most immersive sandbox game ever. Every server has it's own charm, whether they run their own scenarios, place forward their own rules, add in orbital mechanics, go full mad max mode or have their own political and governing systems, the list goes on. 

Ty for reading, I hope other people find the same joy I have had (and still am having).

Great sandbox/create game that allows the player to walk, fly, or drive around on planets, and fly into space seamless. The planet and asteroid terrain can be altered by digging or exploding bombs and you can built on either, or just built stuff in space. And has multiplayer.

The main issue with this game, is it still feels like Early Access and has major performance issues that never seem to go away and trend toward getting worse over time, which makes no sense as it started out years ago and computers keep getting better. There are various reports of the way it does weird crap to your hardware and mess up your Windows or whatever. So, check this out at your own risk.

You can build vehicles or planes or spaceships with a huge assortment of parts and pieces, contraptions, components that all work together in different creative ways. Your mind is the limit, or the problematic game engine and the broken mods are the limit (more on that last one later). People get extremely creative and build things not possible by taking advantage of the mechanics of the "blocks" that are available. Somebody made a train that goes into space to a moon utilizing the "rotor" pieces in an outside-the-box way. Another made a giant space cannon that can fire rocks using the gravity generators and again, some creative thinking. It's areas like this where the game really shines. 

The DLCs are spare in what they offer but it's not bad, usually on sale.

There is a massive community and number of mods that expand the gameplay extensively.
You can add new environment lighting effects, beam weapons, custom blocks and components, add shields to your ship, new armor or coloring types, new planets, moons, it's crazy.

On that note, the game updates tend to break mods on a regular basis.
So anyone that makes a mod should understand they should be prepared to commit to supporting their mod for as long as the game exists, and to update as soon as the game updates.
Since most mod developers don't think ahead like this or about such things these days, they just post something thatworks at first, and then breaks later, and never fix it, and messes everyone's saved games, sometimes corrupting them permanently and they're unrecoverable - so you lose everything you built. Forever...unless you saved the blueprints...for all of them. There's a bazilion mods out there and by my experience, probably less than 10% of them are up-to-date and still work and the rest are trash or broken.

If you want to play the game without mods, you can, but it gets boring extremely fast, especially since most of the default items (weapons for example) are limited and choices bare as heck. When un-modded, if feels more like a "proof of concept" program. That said, that this game can even do what it does is worth a HUGE kudos to the developers for what they accomplished that no one else has done. While yeah, there's other space-sandboxes, you can totally deform the celestial bodies in this game, for example, I drilled giant kilometers-wide-holes in planets and moons in this game. However, the enjoyment at some point gets marred by new functionality issues or mod issues, and going back to un-modded version feels like a soulless dance. 

It would probably be way better for this game if they:

1) Fixed the performance issues
2) Regulate the mod community the way Bethesda did with Skyrim SE, so the modders get their stuff together, this will help modders that actually put in their hard work shine better and get the credit they're due; or some process where they vett the mods.
3) Make more DLC that adds in what people want, the current DLC tends to be more on the cosmetic side, but you'd think they'd be cool with making more money by adding shields or beam weapons, custom celestial objects, or FX themselves. (for example, someone made a water mod that puts oceans on planets with water physics, and then others made boat mods - why don't the developers cash in on this using their expertise of the game engine to ensure it's stable? Instead, we get these mods that keep getting broken. It's tiresome).

That's my take. I no longer play this game because of the constant instability issues it suffers from.
One season it will work just fine, it's totally awesome, no issues.
The next season, the developer releases an update that messes up the game, or, breaks mods that in turn, messes up the game, OR somebody updates their mods, and THAT messes up or break the game.
And everyone shrugs and goes "I don't know what happened!".
No one takes ownership.

I have 499 hours and I probably spent 10% of that doing my own research and problem-solving every-blooming-time this kinda of antics occurred. As a casual gamer, there's no time for this kind of bull in my book. But I gave it a fair shake because I want games like this to succeed as they set a standard for other developers and put to shame those who just wanna license a cheap game engine and put out trash rip-offs. SE deserves a lot of good attention, because of what it has to offer, INCLUDING, what the modders have to offer, it's utterly phenomenal when its works. In the meantime: Get it sorted!

That is all.

I was looking for a game that would give me some of the feels I got from playing Factorio. I picked Space Engineers up, and spent a hundred hours on it in a couple of weeks. It's a deeply engaging experience.

I recommend playing the "Star System" mode, and to start with the planetary lander. You start in a ship, flying in the atmosphere of a planet, which you can't leave (because the ship only has atmospheric thrusters, which only work when an atmosphere exists), but you can fly around until you find the perfect landing spot. Once you get there, start scraping your ship to collect material to establish your first base. From there, the world's your oyster. Expand the base, make mining vehicles, explore the planet, set up outposts, ... And when you feel ready, make a rocket, and take off for the stars. If you're lucky, your rocket will be powerful enough for you to leave the planet's gravity well, and you'll be ready to make your first space station! Then of course, you will need a new space mining ship, a shuttle to get back and forth from planets and moons, a mothership to store your stuff and your ships, something to defend against pirates, ... And I haven't talked about the multiplayer yet.

This game runs worse than it did years ago, especially with autosave enabled. Be prepared to close and restart the game every 30-45 minutes as each time the game is saved the amount of lag increases. Although I recommend the game after a fairly short tenure playing this particular title I do so with some suggestions. Let me start  by saying I've been playing survival games for quite a long time. That said, I think the UI and task bars in the ships and vehicles need to be reworked. They are over convoluted for no reason. I know you are trying to simulate the complexity of piloting such "advanced" ships. However, stuffing all the functions of the individual components on the task bars meant for an entire crew is confusing and not needed at best. This game is set far into the future hence the interface should be more streamlined and once components are installed in a vessel it should work in conjunction for the bigger whole not require individual attention by the pilot of all people. My real car interface is more advanced than your pilot interface. Why would anyone other then an engineer in engineering need individual control of a gyroscope for example? I mean other then getting a land vehicle to turn upright that is - which is another whole story all together. The center of balance on your land vehicles is way off as well and on a normal gravity planets (EARTHLY). Flipping is WAY too easy on wide multi-wheeled armed vehicles. Just tidbits of "do it just to do it" are all over. There is more but you get the idea.

After playing on it for about 10 hours, messing around and trying to actually do the 'survival' version of the game on various planets, stations, etc, it's really a boring 'nothing is there game'.  If it wasn't incorrectly reporting a whopping 30 hours played on it, I'd actually ask for my money back and I got it on sale too.  Seriously there is nothing to do in this game and unless you start on a mission that has a premade ship it's neigh impossible to build a working/stable one.  Even then the game is only fun in creative mode because the survival and 'find your resources' is impossible due to lack of scanners, etc.  I've had more fun in Genital Jousting then this bore fest.

Dear Reader,

I would absolutely give this game a 10/10. The amount of possibility in SE is unmatched by any other game I have played in my 16 years of gaming. The base game is filled with all of the resources required to sate your creative/destructive needs. Without space engineers, I would have nothing to sink my endless creativity into. I would rather play this game than something like Mine Craft or Terra Tech (No offense to them of course). I played over 2500 hours on Space Engineers, 5000+ hours on MineCraft, and a little over 600 hours on Terra Tech and I just prefer to play this game.

Let's talk about DLCs. I know some people definitely didn't like the DLCs because the decorative blocks were really cool but not free, or because they didn't offer enough. I would argue that they aren't required to play the game or design good grids. They merely act as a creative supplement to enhance your design. I have found dozens of ways to work around not having certain DLC items, It is important to think outside the box. Even though I only have half of them purchased, I am slowly getting them one by one either when they go on sale or when I have an extra 5 bucks to drop. Compared to most games, 5 dollars is nothing when it comes to skins, especially because the DLC addons for space engineers contain more than just a fancy skin. For the price alone, the DLCs are unmatched.

What about this game makes it interesting? Well, it offers a wide array of tools for building things from rotors, hinges, and turret controllers that can help make turrets, tool arms, automated excavators, you name it. I've made replaceable elevator cabins using wheels and pistons, gravity-based ship accelerators for carriers, huge shipyards with automated construction platforms, and plenty of other crazy stuff. The interesting thing is that I get better at making certain machines as one would in real life, and I am able to make them more compact, more efficient, or more powerful than I did before. So if you don't mind a little manual labor, and you love making crazy contraptions, this is perfect.

As far as the co-op goes, it has a system I would say is similar to Rust, which a few people aren't a fan of. There are dedicated servers that run vanilla only with around 10+ people and there are player managed servers that can include mods and sometimes more people. The only downside is that making a personal server is sometimes difficult. I personally have played a small amount of multiplayer, but I enjoyed every bit of it. Playing with friends is the best. In an online co-op, you can join forces with others (I'm sure they would enjoy having an extra hand), or stay solo and play it covertly. If you don't have a ton of friends to play space engineers, it is not as bad as you might think. I almost exclusively play solo or with one friend and I have had the most fun doing so. I love chilling out, drinking a cup of hot cocoa and annihilating space pirates or mining entire asteroids or building thousands of drones and letting them go crazy... you get the point. It all depends on play style.

If nothing so far has you convinced, let's take a little detour down to the workshop. The workshop is absolutely FILLED with stuff, which comes at no extra cost to you. It has everything from intricate ship re-creations to mods that add bubble shields, giant laser weapons, and tons of functional/decorative blocks to mess around with (I personally love the weapon mods from Aryx). I use 20+ mods from various authors that make the experience unbelievable. Huge fleets of pirate ships battle my strongholds, battleships, and drones using rail guns, homing missiles, and defense shields. The workshop is really something to behold, and it stands as a symbol of the community and the sheer amount of heart that goes into this game.

Last, but definitely not least, I really want to give keen proper credit for having a robust support system. I have had my share of dilemmas, from corrupt worlds to broken mechanics (many of them being a problem I most likely caused). I turned to Keen's support team and they pulled through every time. Their support page is full of issues they either fixed, or are currently fixing. All you need to do is ask or just take a look at support tickets from people who have had a similar issue (it is very likely that someone had an issue and got it resolved). If you need help and you can't seem to figure out what is going on, submit a ticket and they will be there to help. From the many problems I have had, they put in hours of problem solving to help.

Overall, this game is one of a kind. I have been playing this game so long I can't even remember (That, or I have short-term memory loss). I started when SE was still in its testing phases. I did an early test of the game and fell completely in love. The more I played, the more I wanted to keep playing. Hopefully, if you were on the fence about getting this game, you will take this review into heavy consideration, because I 110% recommend it. Keen and the community deserve every bit of the credit given, if not more.

Happy Building :),
