So to Start this review is the 3rd Rewrite Each Time i Rewrite it , a good amount of stuff has changed.
This review like all the ones before it where writen without the aid of a writing Program like Grammerly.

So Last Time We learned that i Love this game for good reasons but still my opinion is biased so take what i say with some salt

Now then i will start with the bit that seems to make gamers go {uuuuu that the next ea} DLC or for the Normie Downloadable Content.

1.DLC
To start No Matter What at the time of Writing This Review 4/18/2023,April/18/2023 All the DLC's are Cosmetic in Nature, 
I can Not Stress This Enough All the DLC's are Cosmetic in Nature. To Explain further There are No Gameplay Features Locked Behind Paywalls
as such i can not Blame them For it or Falt them For it . Now to Explain some more i Hate DLC's like What Paradox Games does Where they lock Stuff behind Paywalls.
However Stuff Like Loot Boxes & Cosmetic Stuff i can and will Tolerate as that is the Players Choice to Buy, Let Me Repeat Players Choice To Buy . 
The Former is Gambling There is no way to hide it, i do not like Gambling but it is a lesser Evil Compared To Paywalling, Like wise the latter are also a Lesser Evil Compared to Paywalling.
Why Do i call them Lesser Evils simple They Keep The Developers Payed to keep content rolling out of there dungeons .

I feel that covers DLC Quite well Moving on the Next Mods

2.Mods
ah Mods the Spice of the Gaming Community, no matter where you go you will always find some in some form or Another, Whether its in the form of a steam workshop , other websights or Backally Deals
There will always be some . Space Engineers Has two Official Mod Sights. The Steam Workshop & Mod.io , {i have no Real Experience with Mod.io so i will not comment on it} 
The Steam Workshop has been as far as i can tell been supported sense Space Engineers's launch onto the store . The way it is Implemented Should really Be the Industry standered as far as i am concerned ,
Over the Years there have been some Plagiarism problems but as far as i can tell they are not there anymore or it is way more low key than before, Either way not much to complain about.

That should cover every thing i feel you should know for now on the Mods. Next Gameplay

3.Gameplay
The Gameplay. There is not a lot i can say about it , it is there . There is Creative Mode build shite, do stupid shite or do Crazy Shite. Survival Mode is more my speed, here is how that song and dance goes.
Mine Rock, put rock in mechine, Get shiney Bricks, Put Shiney Bricks into mechine, Make Shiny Bricks into Components, take Components and make Blocks, Blocks make Ships & Stations to Do stuff Like Mine more Rock or Fight.
That is it as far as i can tell after playing 2,130.1 Hours of The Game. Granted there is a Very Very Steep Learning Curve, if there was no info out there, but the info is easy enough to find that it does not really matter.
Getting skilled at the game. That is the trick and not a easy one. Getting Good at Flying is also a good idea, Remember Strafing and Spinning is a good Trick, 
and if for some reason you find the life of a pirate is more your speed. When engaging a ship always have 3 movement keys held down while trying to find a blind spot make sure to change what keys every Second,
then use that blind spot to Infiltrate the ship, unless you have an easy Hacking mod the pirate life is a very hard life not one i would Recommend.
Overall i Recommend Getting a Easy Hacking Mod & Some Ships Spawner Mods and Trying the Pirate Life at least once it is very fun, I would Recommend that you have at least two players for this life style though,
one to stay home and do stuff with the ships, either melting them down for scrap or Making Multi ship abominations and one player to get the ships. This Play style is very fun 10/10 would recommend.

if you are going to Post something to fix something i would recommend being very careful about what you say,
again Cautionary tails are out there as someone who is mostly a ghost on the forms it seems chill enough.

overall i would recommend this game but again take what i have said with a grain of salt as i am Biased

Well I guess after 2,500+ hours of game time I should probably give my two cents.
If that huge game time wasn't an indicator on its own what I think of the game, allow me to spell it out.
- Sandbox in the truest sense. The only limitations really are your imagination (and what the Klang Gods allow).
- New content added regularly, opening up new inspiration and aesthetics to play with.
- A huge workshop library of amazing mods to toy with.
- Scenarios to choose from (both baked in to the game or off the workshop) if you want something with a more pre-defined story or theme to play with.
- Build spaceships, bases, and whatever else any way you like and/or find blueprints on the workshop to add to your game.
- Customize your character at any time, change as often as you like. Find new skins for suits and tools in game (or buy the ones you realllllly want on the market if you can't wait to get them in game).
- Very reasonably priced DLCs.
- DLCs don't give advantages; so no pay to win.
- Creative and Survival modes.
- Multiple planets/moons with different challenges to overcome.

This is a fun game, but the ships need a speed boost, salvaging needs to be better, and a star map needs to be added.

For YEARS this game was kept alive not by the developers but by the players and modders who added more content and variety to the game than the actual devs, hell so much of what the devs are now trying to cash in on with DLC has already been accomplished with mods and creativity of the players themselves. 

With that said, the base game is still worth playing, but not if you intend to buy out the extras offered; do yourself a favour and rely on mods instead, like we all have for years. No thanks to keen.

This game is hard to recommend. I thoroughly enjoyed it a few years back during it's early early-access days.
It had it's quirks - quite lots of them -, but you paid for the full game and got everything it had to offer.

So previously i had more or less a cinemasins list for space engineers that i dared call a review. the game has actually improved a lot since then and i would like to change the verdict to a positive one this time.
will still keep a sins list below anyways.

Space engineers as it stands, is a solid sandbox game allowing a lot of creativity in designing vehicles. global parameters like resource gain can be adjusted to make the game experience suit your needs.

Physics are solid. and the collision physics and deformation are still a very nice feature of the game, and it was the one feature that drew in a lot of customers early on.
Not much has been done to the deformation physics since then feature wise. but it has been optimized and bugfixed pretty nicely.

The real strength of the game lies in it's survival mode. you do not actually need to eat, drink, sleep or relieve yourself, but you do need to ensure you have a supply of power and oxygen. leaving you more time to focus on gathering resources and designing ships or structures.
You start off with a survival pod which allows you to convert rock into materials. you then get a smelter to use high concentration ores of minerals. and later large automated refinery complexes that can process massive amounts of ore at a time. it's a very natural and satisfying progression curve.

Currently the game is stagnant the developers are not adding much needed features like weapons and progression. you can find all the resources in the game on your starter planet. there is no advanced tech or mk2 equipment. the game ends progression very early.

Verdict: Fun experience. making and using ships is interesting and enjoyable. physics are in a good place and have little jank. solid building game. 7 / 10.

I don't recommend this game for anyone who is looking for a survival experince as it massively too grindy.
I also don't recommend it for those who want to build massive ships using lots of mods due to how unstable the game is already and that sometimes using mods or just playing vanilla can have your worlds and ships you were working on completely unloadable, Which has happened several times.

The DLC is also paid mods but they end up also being inferior to the mods they copy, See warfare 1 DLC and the passage intersections mod it "borrowed" from. Alternatively you could use mods but keen always seem to completely render mods unusable for awhile with every update. There are also features that are said to be completely impossible such as projecting the subgrids using the projector block which more involved mods have been able to make possible.

Oh and totally not pay to win DLCs... that add versions of blocks that have unique purposes and functionality, Also just flat out look better have better attachment points, etc,

Going through all afew examples:

-Bed- Functionally cheaper cryo-chamber alternative with better mounting points,
-Industrial Cockpit- Different conveyor layout with a much better view and 2600 more hitpoints than the normal cockpit, 175 more than the fighter cockpit... You know... one intended for combat that is a much larger target.
-Vending Machine- A standalone compact cheap version of the shop block that you could easily stick in any hallway anywhere without taking up a whole block of space.
-ATM- Standalone cheap version of the withdrawal and deposit of the main shop block, Handy for letting you deposit credits that you find at a moments notice so that you don't lose them to death or other players.
-Dispenser- A functional vending machine that while technically just dispenses beverages... they do heal a small amount of health.
-Jukebox- Something that would require scripts (disabled on almost every server anyways) a button and a sound block all wrapped up into one item you can use anywhere... Not pay to win but pay to avoid needing a programmable block.
-Window Wall- Has only afew more hitpoints than normal windows, But also does not need girders.
-Transparent LCD- You want a HUD on your bridge? Display info without blocking sight? Want better attachment points? Its yours... oh wait you thought that the mod still worked? Ha no...
-Grated Catwalks- What catwalks SHOULD HAVE BEEN... Also with much more variety than the vanilla ones.
-Railing- More variety than the vanilla low walls, Less durable but it's literally a block to save you from walking off a ledge and experience a drop from low orbit.
-Rotating Light- Something that would require a rotor and two spotlights... the rotor being disabled alongside pistons in multiplayer normally. So essentially pay here for something that other people on the server probably cannot recreate outside of singleplayer.
-Gates- Less ugly than hangar doors and comes with an integrated button making it more compact and sleek.
-Offset door- a door that lines up and looks much nicer than the vanilla alternative.
-Sci-Fi Control Panel- Larger easier to access quickly with an LCD. Straight upgrade from the tiny panel.
-Sci-Fi 1 button panel/4 button panel- Straight upgrade if you are using scripts which can output statuses and indicators to them, Also handy for displaying labels directly on the buttons without scripts.
-Buggy Cockpit- The rover cockpit has the LCDs too low to be easily seen with more reasonable FOVs.
-Offset spotlights/lights- Physically smaller more compact spotlights that sit almost flush on the fronts and rears of small vehicles reducing the likely hood that the catch and get damaged.
-Weapon Rack Block- Exists on a small grid, Meaning you can stash a weapon onto a vehicle, Spare ammo possibly In places like inside small grid transport craft or trucks, Or even just spares.
-More Passage Blocks- Mentioned above it's basically a vanilla alternative to mod except you can use it on servers, It also has all sides sealed allowing you to make hallways that are less vulnerable to depressurization in combat.
-Embrasure Block- Not pay to win... Assuming you completely ignore any potential PVP happening on foot or inside of a ship using these.
-Industrial Refinery and Assemblers- Easier to access and move around when placed inside a ship likely making repairs easier.
-Warfare Hangars- Nowhere as ugly versions of the hangar doors even come with windowed versions. For a fee.
-Searchlights- You can make a knockoff clunkier more fragile version that may not even be able to be built on a server using the custom turret block and rotors and hinges... which are probably disabled on the server anyways.
-Helm- A control station that does not take up aton of space... Has alot of useful applications since you don't get ejected afew meters away when getting out possibly.
-Access Panels- seem to be armored access panels.
-Automaton Programmable block- Appears to be a programmable large grid block... WITH MORE THAN 1 ATTACHMENT POINT... You thought gyros were bad when they come loose? Have you had a single floor tile go and then suddenly you lose all your control. Want an alternative? Wanted it to be free? Too bad.
-Automaton Sensor/Camera- Both claim to be just reskins that look like they have some armor... but considering the industrial cockpit has 2600 more hitpoints and it's just a reskinned cockpit.

Part of this game is just making cool looking ships and sharing them on the workshop... I also still unfortunately am stuck with duplicate DLC skins due to a bugfix mean't to ensure people obtained their DLC items. Space Engineers is one of the best sandbox-style block-style do what you want-style game that has kept me hooked for over 400 hours of gameplay. The game has an insane and extensive modding community that adds endless possibilities to an already fantastic experience. I have downloaded many mods and many player created space stations, realistic spacecraft, and even functional trains.I highly recommended for space enthusiasts and creative minds alike!
I have been playing SE since it came to Xbox and have loved the updates Since then. I would definitely recommend Space Engineers even after all the DLC and updates.

Very fun (and frustrating when clang happens) I play this way too much sometimes. Lots of mods available on the workshop to add new ways to to play the game. Much better with friends and mods. 

Personally, I mod the game to make it insanely difficult in single player. A metric TON of hostile NPC ships including many that actively hunt you or send a non stop flood of drones after you in space. On planets i use similar hostile ship mods plus Raiders, Zombies, Animals and Robots are constant threat. 

The Daily needs mod make it so you have grow food and have water. Plus as an added Bonus I Add the Grind to learn Mod that forces me to to hunt the NPCs to learn the tech I need to survive. 

Oh, and During all this I use the permanent death and Armageddon settings just so I don't feel tempted to stay in one place for too long. too much Voxel damage will eventually cause killer lag.  

My preferred play style is a bit too much for a dedicated server sadly, as the clean up tools are either not aggressive enough (which will soon cause an overload of lag) or they just wind up deleting grids before they can be fully captured (that causes people to complain LOL) 

TL/DR: Fun game that I Mod till is broken, then mod till its fixed again!

Space Engineers is an incredibly immersive and addictive sandbox game that offers players unparalleled freedom and creativity. The game's focus on engineering and construction allows players to design and build their own spaceships, space stations, and planetary bases, using a vast array of blocks and components. With a variety of gameplay modes, including survival mode, players can spend countless hours exploring, building, and defending against hostile forces. The game's physics engine and realistic simulation of space environments add to the immersion and challenge.

Overall, Space Engineers is a game that is easy to lose hours in, thanks to its deep gameplay mechanics, stunning visuals, and near-limitless possibilities for creative expression. Whether you're a fan of space exploration, engineering, or just looking for a fun and engaging sandbox game, Space Engineers is an excellent choice that is sure to satisfy.

[b]In short[/b]
Building is amazing, possibilities are limited by wonky unfixed physics engine for a very long time now. It's a meme for years now but not a very funny one if it never gets fixed.
There should be WAY more PvE content as right now the only thing adding this is mods. In my opinion this should really have be a part of the base game and not something you have to go looking for in the steam workshop. If I didn't love building and designing ships and stations so much I would have been done with this game in 50 hours tops which is very little for a sandbox game in my opinion.
I also think the developers should look at a game like Minecraft and see how they make you work for meaningful progression and with that make it feel a lot more rewarding to do basic things.

[b]The long way[/b]
I have really enjoyed all the hours and years of playing this game while waiting for content that never came and have come to the point where I'm sick of waiting. I rarely write reviews but I want this game to improve and hope that this gets my point across and maybe for others who agree with me as well.

Here's a pros and cons list of my experience playing this game for 500+ hours, maybe it's not as much as many other people have but I think it's safe to say that I've seen a lot of what this game has to offer.

[b] PROS [/b]
- Creativity in building is amazing but limited
- Scripting adds a lot of depth to what you can create in the game and the new Ai update looks very promising!
- Dedicated community 
- An endless supply of mods
- I find performance to be pretty alright for the amount of things you can put into and do in a game like this

[b] CONS [/b]
- It's an amazing sandbox as you can destroy everything and shape in the way you like but you can't terraform to shape things exactly the way you want them to be which is kinda sad
- Collision/physics system is bad, clang is a nice meme but the reality is that it's ruining amazing building possibilities left right and center for years now
- The modding community is fixing and adding things to the game that the developers should make and/or fix themselves
- After your first couple hours in the game you stop unlocking new things in survival to create new things with so there's no real sense of progression after that besides creating your own engineering problems to overcome
- [b] The PvE content in this game is basically non existent [/b] and I'm gonna split this up in multiple points because it bothers me the most out of all
- There are rarely any hostile ships and stations spawning randomly in your world and they're not worth any of the trouble of repairing your ships/stations etc. The resources you gain from these fights are not worth your time at all.
- The real PvE scenarios (not counting the survive waves scenario) are really well made but very short and feel like only a teaser compared to the endless possibilities they have at their disposal 
- The wave survival scenario is fun once or twice at best and is a poor way of implementing PvE content
- NPCs are basically non existent besides the new ones they added with the economy update which also add VERY little content to the game
- [b] Exploration is meaningless. [/b] Besides wanting to build an even bigger ship to explore more meaningless places, there is no point to exploring at all. The only things you can discover are very rare crash sites on planets or in space both of which you have very little resources to gain from and thus no real reason to do something with. You can get it all faster and easier by mining/refining/constructing said resources yourself.

To sum it all up, my biggest problem with this game is the fact that there is nothing to do at all other than build ships in creative or make it a little bit harder by making them in survival instead. There is not a lot of sense of progression in the game besides understanding how something new you try to build works and the few progression things you get done in about 5 hours once you understand how the basics of the game work. This will kill your motivation to do anything eventually and leave you feeling empty as you built the things you made just to make something and there is zero purpose for them in the game.

I bought SE many years ago, And have played it on and off over time. (This includes on military deployments which due to this game being able to launch without having to go through steam at the time i spent more time on)

What i like about the game, 

  You can build some pretty cool ships if you have the patience for it, and it's not terribly obtuse with the built system like some other games can be (From the Depths i'm looking at you!) 

The whole pressurization mechanic is wonderful i love it. 

I'm struggling to find other things that are positive... 

What I don't like about the game. 

The massive amount of instability, Even in single player the game is terrifyingly unstable with it's physics and mechanics. 
This is only multiplied in servers with friends.

The complete lack of anything resembling an objective, 
There is a money and trade system in the game, but it is like a ghost. 

Back when the game first released into early access the whole collision mechanic was a huge novelty. But it really wore off. 


Overall i can't honestly recommend this game. If it has some kind of goal in development it's vague and scattered. 
Try some other space sim/rpg   Avorion or Empyrion are good examples. StarMade is also a Niche title that i really enjoyed,

I love the game, it allows for a great deal of creativity.  I always have to remind though, it is not a finished product.  Even after 10 years there is much to be desired in the way of physics and options.  But much like playing with Legos, you don't let the limitations limit your creativity.  An engineer solves problems with what he has or can build.  That is what this game really is, a toolset for creativity.

That said, I am VERY MUCH looking forward to the next released version of the game that is rumored for Space Engineers 2, with water physics and hopefully less restrictions on building.  Hint Keen, blocks should be able to be triangles with attachment points on all sides, not just on the cube sides.  But I support the effort and game, have all the DLCs and have bought the game for friends because it is sandbox and creative.

Space Engineers has a lot of potential, but unfortunately, it falls short in many aspects. One major issue with the game is the lack of content within the game itself. While there are some basic objectives and missions to complete, they are often repetitive and lack depth, leaving players with little incentive to continue playing beyond the initial stages of the game.

The game is heavily reliant on player-created content, which is often created through servers, but this content is not supported by the developer team and is even sometimes actively discouraged. This over-reliance on player-created content puts the burden on the players to create their own enjoyable experiences, which can be hit or miss depending on the quality of the servers and the creativity of the player base.

In addition, Space Engineers is incredibly buggy and glitchy, which makes it frustrating to play. The physics engine is unreliable, and objects tend to clip through each other, causing unexpected collisions and crashes. The audio design is also unimpressive, with generic sound effects and uninspired music that quickly become repetitive and grating. The objectives are often unclear, and the overall game progression feels slow and unsatisfying. The controls are also clunky and unintuitive, making it difficult to execute even the simplest actions.

Finally, the multiplayer experience in Space Engineers is frustrating and buggy. The game's netcode is unreliable, and players often experience lag and disconnects, making it nearly impossible to play with friends or strangers online.

Overall, the lack of content within Space Engineers, aside from the player-created content on servers, is a major drawback for the game. This places a heavy burden on the players to create their own experiences, which can be hit or miss, and the lack of quality control can lead to a lot of frustrating and unenjoyable experiences.

TL;DR Space Engineers a disappointing choice for players looking for a more structured and cohesive space-based gaming experience.

Space Engineers is an excellent game that offers a unique combination of survival, building, and space combat gameplay. The game's mechanics are well-designed, and the attention to detail in both the space and planetary environments is impressive. The freedom to build your own spacecraft and explore the galaxy is exhilarating, and the addition of combat and the ability to crash into planets adds an extra layer of excitement.

The game's multiplayer mode is also noteworthy, allowing players to collaborate on building massive space stations and engage in epic battles with other players. Overall, if you enjoy survival building games and have a fascination with space, then Space Engineers is definitely a game worth checking out.

You'll see a lot of praise for this game. But hear me out - you should not buy it.

Why? I tell you why.



- Most of community suggestions/ requests are ignored, only those that are comfortable for devs to make considered

- [b] PAID DLCs in early access [/b] No kidding. I have dropped the game at this point already. But, judging by other players' feedback, it seems DLC went from "mostly cosmetic" to "must-have gameplay features" (but I'd recommend to doule check me on that one). I understand why they did this - they were not able to finish game, jusmping from idea to Idea (AI research, Medieval Engineers, scenarios...), so they could not attract more fund by selling a raw unpolished game itself to new players. Instead, Keen started to milk dedicated fans with DLCs.

- 7 years - and game... is still not a game. It's just "entertain yourself" constructor. Engineer is a people-servant, a problem-solver. But devs do not know that. Outside of some scenarios, you have no goal to work with

- The engine is terrible. After several years of not playing this game, I got back to check what people were saying... and found that nothing changed. Every mobile part of your construction has the tendency to shake and, eventually, explode randomly. Large ships? Forget about it! Engine still cannot handle it. This problem was raised and pointed years ago. And what was devs' reaction? They've updated to DX12!!! Amazing. Expect it's not.



This is especially sad for those who paid full-price during beta 5-6 years ago.



I won't go further. Just check other negative reviews - most of them are true.

If you buy this... constructor (this cannot be called a game), you won't get decent product - you'll just sponsor another "i'm an artist, I don't care about your needs" lazy developer, with Bethesda-style monetization.

Space Engineers is a sandbox-style game that is set in space and offers a wide range of tools and resources to build and explore your own universe. The game has received positive reviews for its immersive game play and open-world possibilities. In Space Engineers, players can explore, build and survive in a vast, open-world environment. The game features both single-player and multiplayer modes, where players can work together to explore the universe or compete against each other. The game is set in space, with players able to visit planets, moons, and asteroids, each with their own unique features and resources. One of the most impressive aspects of Space Engineers is the level of freedom it provides. Players can construct their own spaceships, stations, and bases using a variety of building tools and materials. This allows players to create unique structures that fit their individual play styles. The game also features a robust physics engine, making building structures and vehicles a challenging and rewarding experience. The survival aspect of the game is also well-implemented, adding an extra layer of depth to the game play. Players must gather resources, manage their oxygen and energy levels, and avoid hazards like meteor showers and radiation. This adds a sense of urgency and tension to the game play, making each decision and action crucial to survival. Space Engineers is an engaging and immersive game that offers endless possibilities for players. Its open-world design, building tools, and physics engine create a fun and challenging experience that will keep players engaged for hours on end. If you are a fan of sandbox-style games, space exploration, and building games, then Space Engineers is definitely worth checking out.

I played the game for years, surly it's a good game for creating, but this only happened in early years of the game. 
The developers show no desire to improve the engine or game mechanism, they always sell DLCs without actually new things, and at the same time old bugs are never planed to fixed, what make me really upset is that they always change things or setting as their own view, for example the change of collision size without considering the players' creation, as a result the ships or vehicles you made in last version may come to ruin after a big update, especially the API for script or MOD, you will never know when your script or MOD you coded and shared on workshop failed because the sudden change of APIs.
What's more, I never know what the developer actually had done in these years, as what I had said above almost ALL the new DLCs' functional blocks came from the steam workshop made by players (except skins or textures), we old players are always confused which part of those jobs were done by KEEN themselves? I don't know, but even thought the DLCs are almost made by players and can't see what KEEN had optimized for the game, but new bugs are more and more with their update, which is a really puzzle to us.
Those circumstances made me impossible to play the game normally, since the Warfare1 update, at that time in 2021 some of the menu buttons and texts are always missing during my playing, and after the Warfare2 update in 2022, all the texture, skins or toolbar icons in game are missing, these only happen after their update, I post the problems to them, but they never consider these troubles as their own problems, the bugs I report on their website even does not receive any reply yet.
If you take a look at the announcement KEEN published these years, they seem to put a lot of time to optimize the multi-playing or the XBOX version of SE, but multi-playing performance is still very poor, you must have a very very high-end server or PC if you plan to hold an online party with other SE players.
Some programmers and I guess, most of the problems above are due to the engine of the game, VRage, it is an engine coded by KEEN itself in 2000s and nobody else uses it, more important, it is tooooooooooo old for programmers to optimize in 2020s, it's so out of date that you may find many strange behaviors in SE, for example the max speed of ships is limited to 100m/s only, ships with movable parts linked with rotors or hinges are evidently unstable, and the land vehicles with wheels would suddenly get crazy and fly to the sky while you are driving it on the surface of a planet...etc, the physical system here is somehow a disaster in 2020s, but think of that it coded in 2000s, you may learn why.
So if you are a new player looking for free-building games, try anther one first please please please, SE only suit for old ones like me. :)

It is alright, but not in a great state. The game doesn't run particularly well, the controls, interface and such are pretty bad from an usability standpoint. 

There's also not that much machinery, which is a bit weird for a game like this. It doesn't satisfy anyone who is into making complex supply chains or factories. 

Survival wise, the game is also a bit sparse, with strange roadblocks which don't make much realistic sense, which is never really fun. There's also basically no one to interact with in a solo game. It's not like, say, CDDA, rimworld, factorio, or so on, where there are some NPC's, clear objectives or ones you can set for yourself. I've often found myself thinking "Now what ?"

Given there's a slew of DLC's coming out too, I think the game is going to get a fair bit more expensive too. 

If you are good at making your own fun, I can clearly see yourself having fun making bases, rovers, shuttles and so on, but if you like an experience with a little more guidance, if you like fluff or charm, or you don't have patience for bad UI/UX, you may want to try something else. 

I also really encourage you to ALWAYS check both positive AND negative reviews on games. There's really often some insights once you scroll past the meme reviews. If you don't find any well written negative thing, you can probably go ahead. This time? You'll find some by much better writers than me.

You can certainly feel the sandbox more clearly, even more clearly than in Minecraft which says something.
But overall - It's fun again in a weird way.

Update - 2017/01/28:
Beta is way better, at least it doesn't crash as often. Basically, they've changed to model in how they deploy changes, stable and beta. Now at least it's worth playing since you can save and load and expect it to work. Haven't tried the pistons and rotors but no high hopes there.

Update - 2016/09/20:
The game crashed the whole playthrough after another patch - I'm never playing this game again.
There is no hope for this as they can't manage saves in any meaningful way at all. Just don't even bother with testing by the things I've seen. You wanted planets - you got a ruined game.

Update 2016-09-18:
Speed is back, sort of, still lagging at times so not sorted completely. The new thing is not exploding pistons or rotors when patched. This time it was every single turret firing at everything else. Still not a positive - It's not like Minecraft in the sense that every release was better and more - this is more plodding and aimless.

Update 2016-01-04:
Reinstalling sorted out the instant crashes on launch it seems.
Now however the ugliness of the planets appeared. A system that runs Fallout 4 on Ultra should not feel sluggish in this game when on medium/low settings. Optimising the code a whole lot would be required. Even when starting on a quickstart the loadtime is closing on the minute.
Just not worth the effort...

Update: Due to the collision detection on load of saved games and the absolute garantee that any build that you try where save and load is necessary will blow up in your face I strongly discourage you from buying this game unless you like concepts over actual products.
Keen is adding features while this game is slowly losing stability. Simply put, the secondary crew is learning to program on this game. You can't reliably save and return to point hence it's unreliable at best.

Cheap description is minecraft in space. But that's describing a symphony by beethoven as a rather nice tune to enjoy.
And considering I have more or less 3 years in minecraft and a 400h+ on Engineers I can say that.

This has lacked a goal to work towards if you like, like minecraft, with a lot of different blocks, like minecraft, in a rather sandboxy world, like minecraft, with some basic rules on how they fit together with few exceptions, like minecraft. But that's the base of it.
This game allows you to build just about any odd thing you like. Now you can also program inside the game as well to really script your own things with the components. And this is where it goes far away from minecraft. It's not just simple programs but rather advanced things. Add then the workshop items which has the same base as the rest. Special thrusters, guns, decorations and so on. And the modmanager works directly with the workshop so what you got enabled is always up to date. And the modding community is active and friendly - and their work end up in the base game if it's good enough.
This game is extremely well made so far, weekly updates and a dev team that really communicate, not listen, with the actual players to make a game that really works for everyone. I usually have a balanced view to the game so here it is:
The weekly updates - You rarely have time to try things out before the next cool thing arrives. And this is going more and more for dedicated servers and multiplayer than single player.
It's not boring as single player, it's a solid experience, but unlike minecraft this is really gearing towards multiplayer.

If you like sandboxes and space, you'll probably like SE. Creativity can really go nuts. Minecraft, KSP etc fans will probably love it.Under constant development with regular DLC releases. Before you whine about paid DLC, none of it is P2W, and if you want games to be maintained for a decade, the company has to pay its developers.Like many games modding is where it really shines. Virtually all the limitations of vanilla can be loosened, or made hardcore, with mods and scripts. Brutal NPCs? Fully reworked combat system? Autocrafting and inventory management? Solar arrays that follow the sun? Radar? All that and more.A great community of modders and server admins have created a very deep ecosystem. Want a casual, PVE survival server? Hardcore PVP? A whole cluster of servers recreating the Sol system of The Expanse? It's all there.One of the best multiplayer sandboxes out there.

Original review below ::::

I really want to love this game, but after not playing for awhile, I forgot how to do most of what I did know, and now there's new stuff that I can't seem to get to work for me, and just generally, the game is far more complicated than it needs to be so the most mundane tasks can become frustrating because the game refuses to cooperate. The concept is great, and when things work the way I want them to its great, but when oxygen generators refuse to put out oxygen and things refuse to connect to said oxygen generator for no other reason to annoy me (my favorite is when I have something connected, I destroy it while adjusting things, and then I can't get the same exact item to attatch again) I just want to blow everything up and erase the game from my hard drive.

Some things could really use some stream lining and simplification, rather than being complicated for the sake of being complicated. But I'm sure some people like the pointless complication in some aspects of the game, so whatever I guess.

For me though, after leaving it for awhile and returning, I've realize just how pointlessly over complicated some of the game is, and while you can escape most of it by simply ignoring it and playing creative mode, that IMO, doesn't make it ok. Especially since going to creative mode eliminates about 80% of the gameplay (mining isn't relevant, you can't die so battles are pointless, etc etc) the rest is just floating around in space doing nothing.

Its a fun game, if you have pateince for broken game mechanics and completely unnecessary complication, I'd say pick it up - Especially if you're the type to only play one game for awhile. But if you don't, or like me, you play a lot of different games, then save your frustration and play something else til they get it all sorted out.

Due to the sheer amount of bugs, and random over complication, and the lack of really anything to do, I can't reccomend this game at this point. There's ton of potential here, but they need to clean up the controls a bit, and make the game more user friendly if they want to market this game beyong a super tiny niche.

I'll try again in a few months or so and see if it's any more user friendly.

Probably about time I actually write one of these. 

Space Engineers has always been the type of game where you need to make your own fun. It's a sandbox game, and it says that right on the tin. If you're looking at this game and hoping for a compelling survival experience out of the box (ie, looking for the game to give you direction on how to enjoy it), then you'll probably be disappointed once you've completed an initial run of the main survival game loop.

However, if you are the type of person that gets the most fun out of creating your own goals and your own fun, then this game offers nearly limitless possibilities.

A good amount of the time I've spent in this game has been in Creative Mode. Just building ships and stations scratches the "Lego" itch for me quite nicely. While I'm no where near as skilled at building as some others in the community, it's been an enjoyable experience slowly honing my craft and style. I do hop onto Survival every once in a while as well, though my preference is to play with a variety of mods to make things more challenging.

The developers of this game have a good relationship with their creative community, which has allowed the modding side of this game to flourish. This further adds to what I mentioned above about "making your own fun", since you have a massive selection of additional features (via mods) you can use to curate your experience. These are mainly handled by the steam workshop, which takes a lot of the hassle out of loading/unloading extra content. While mods do sometimes break, the developers do make an effort to limit the damage that game updates can often cause to mods.

While on the topic of mods, this is the first game where I got serious about learning how to develop mods in general. For me, building mods has become just as fun as actually playing the game - and I've picked up some real programming skills as a nice side effect from this!

On it's own, it could be said that Space Engineers might have a finite level of enjoyment. But when you factor in the creative community the game has built over nearly a decade, the ways you can enjoy this game become nearly endless.

Keen Software House does [i]not[/i] care about this game anymore. They abuse the community's willingness to try 'new things', as proven by the recent AI Ship Generator. Keen only uses this game to gather data for their primary company, Good.ai. 

This game features a complete disregard for people with disabilities of any sort (compulsive counting, eye sensitivities, motion sensitivities, misophonia, etc). 

Examples include:

- a huge focus on the numbers 3 and 5, zero blocks that focus on 2 (there are 1x1 wheels, 3x3 wheels, and 5x5 wheels, but no 2x2 or 4x4 wheels)

- the welder and grinder have bright flashing

- camera isn't horizon locked ever, leading to strong disorientation on non-horizontal terrain

- Lots of blocks feature extremely repetitive and sometimes jarring ambient sounds (beeping/humming/etc) which can hinder people with ADD or ADHD

[i]Fundamentally[/i], it is a good game. However, the fundamentals is where it stops.

There are TONS of issues with this game, none of which have been addressed in 5+ years, only some of which I will list here:

- Multi-GPU rendering, for example, uses the NVIDIA SLI profiles from when the game used a completely different engine.

- Tons of gameplay bugs, such as limited resources in Creative Mode

- Normal bugs and glitches, such as stuck/glitched air vents draining H2O2 generators

- And more severely, a focus on adding things *nobody asked for*.

- Railguns are limited to 2km. Like, what? Seriously?

- Large ships are difficult to make and manage simply because of how performance intensive they are

- Small grid to Large grid adapters take up a 5x5x5 small grid space

- Severe lack of various block sizes for small grid (only 2 oxy tanks, only 2 hydro tanks, no variations, 2x2xN blocks simply don't exist)

Again, fundamentally, the game is there. But that's where it stops.

- The game has random encounters, yet rarely do you stumble upon them

- Mods are required to view cameras on displays

- There are no NPCs unless you use mods

- Survival has no endgame, unlike Minecraft. There's no final boss battle.

- One of the reasons this game exists is to develop and study AI, yet such a thing is nonpresent in the game. Ship autopilot sucks and is very limited.

- Complete and utter lack of a radar system or dynamic map

- Weather exists, but is a repetitive hinderance

- Complete disregard for people with disabilities of any sort (compulsive counting, eye sensitivities, motion sensitivities, misophonia, etc)

Genuinely, don't buy this game unless it's on sale. Keen doesn't deserve any more money until they start listening to the community.

So another game thats been alive for many years. Had to work with reshade to inject SMAA to play without my eyes bleeding from the sharp pixels dancing around borders or blurrfesting them out with FXAA.

Then the game offers you to play around on endgame scenarios where you can taste ships, land tanks etc. Understand the objective but loading is slow and ocasional hangs prevent it from shining on that point. Still missions are polished and keeps you busy.

After 3 customs starts i was able to play the way i wanted, you land on a drop pod with minimal functionalities and start your way up the tech tree and materials providing. Its nice that you just mine rock and you get basic metals and all the basics will work from there even if there is plenty of rock to mine. But the automation is easy to use and there is a easy yet powerful build planner.

Also for its age you can drill terrain which is amazing for a craft-survival game since most make you play on fixed geometry which is boredom guaranteed. Being able to modify landscape to your needs is amazing, frankly i dont know if you can landfill, but procedural drilling is good in my book, being on foot or land vehicle or even a friggin drilling flying ship.

So i got what i wanted, lonely at space without overpopulated scenario and where displacement will make sense to look for things.

PD: My pod landed on steep terrain and tumbled upside down, yet im able to interact properly with the basic stations it comes with.

played it for several hundred hours and always come back to it as a palette cleanser when I'm waiting for new games to come out or just to float in space for a while. its a great game to build and experiment.

Disclaimer: While my time as of this review says ~47 hours, it actually only reflects about 10-15 hours in game, as I have a tendency to leave the game running in a menu while I'm sleeping.

Most of my time has been spent with creative tools on, as I'm learning the mechanics of the game. The best way I can describe this game is as if Empyrion and Scrap Mechanic had a baby. The building system in Space Engineers will be familiar to those who have played either of the aforementioned games.

There's a lot to do, and the emphasis is on building, not survival (though I have seen videos of people using mods to make the game more about survival). I've had a lot of fun with the building mechanics, and plan on restarting my play through soon in order to play without the creative tools once I get the hang of things.

If you're a fan of resource collection and building, I highly recommend this game.

Space Engineers is an excellent game for space exploration and construction players. The game's physics engine is impressive, allowing you to experience space's realistic gravity and inertia. Its flexibility and customization options provide a wealth of opportunities for creative gameplay. While the game may have a steep learning curve, those who invest the time and effort will find a truly rewarding experience. 

Additionally, mods, scripts and the game's workshop feature a vast array of user-generated content, allowing you to build great things from the community and providing a great way to get to grips with some of the building concepts available to be used.

No game is bug-free, but the development team have been great at responding to reports and fixing bugs through their regular updates.

Im honestly extremely mixed on this review, however I think it comes at a yes for now until I have a chance to check the game out in the future. Go to the bottom to see the conclusion.

[h1] Game description [/h1]
Space engineers is an open world sandbox game set in near future, where space travel is a normal way of life. There is no "end game" or goals besides the personal ones set by the players. However expect space ships, rovers, bases and resource gathering to be almost guaranteed to be part of a normal play through.

Everything in the game is destructible, so in theory yes you could mine an entire planet. The player usually mines and collects resources in order to assemble parts and then make structures. These structures are also destructible.

As mentioned the game has no set goals or end game. So the player must decide a goal themselves. This could be reaching a specific planet or building something, you can also spend your time simply building things like bases or ships in creative mode. It is not uncommon for players to download mods and play with other people on servers or with friends, where you can work together or compete.


[h1] How is this executed? [/h1]

The game is honestly mixed in how well executed its concept is. Some areas are pretty fun, including the process of building and assembling ships, bases and rovers. I prefer Survival as it offers more of a reason to build these things and forces me to develop things according to my environment. However creative also has its positives.

The game can be and in my opinion is the most fun with multiplayer, whether on a public server or just with friends. You can work together, share knowledge, or you can create opposing factions and fight each other using the games range of hand held weapons and weapons that can be put on vehicles/bases. Unfortunately I find that the multiplayer is not very well optimized when you have larger bases, more vehicles etc and can cause lag, however that was when hosting with 1 friend on my computer. Dedicated servers appear to do better.

Despite multiplayer being fun, singleplayer has its downsides. You dont really have anything to do once you have built a base and have a space fairing ship. Sure you can repeat the process on other planets besides the "earth like one" that are more hostile, but the game play is pretty much the same. There is also a lack of enemies to defend from, although it may be possible this is changing in the future.

Finally, the game expresses a lack of proper tutorials. The game offers a lot of stuff but its confusing and in some cases impossible to find out that some of the features exist without seeing someone else do it/teach it to you. This can be extremely infuriating sometimes.


[h1] The biggest issues [/h1]

Ok here is why my review is so mixed: its Keen software house, the devs of Space engineers. The devs appear to care less for the actual game play and fun of the game and more about profits, and as such they have released almost every recent major update with a DLC that puts a lot of content behind a pay wall, and even doing this whilst the game was in Early access some time ago. This has meant updates feel small and meaningless and the player base is extremely unhappy with this.

Furthermore there are many MANY bugs that have been simply ignored in the game, and whilst the game is not unplayable it does make things difficult sometimes. There is actually one issue called "Klang" that is kinda treated like a god in a joking manner in the community, with the DEVS of all people actually naming some of their items after it. (like "Klang Cola" Personally Id say that's pretty disgusting behavior from the devs to not only ignore a bug but then treat it like a joke.

There is a silver lining, what the devs miss completely out in the game modders have taken up and out done the devs in so many ways, making the game a lot more enjoyable to play and challenging, so after mastering the games basics I would 100% recommend getting some mods.


[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Despite the bad neglectful devs who honestly don't listen to the players enough, as well as some other issues, I would say I have got my moneys worth, although without being in a multiplayer server I don't think id have put even 50 hours into the game.

Singleplayer can be fun for some, whether that be creative or survival, especially with mods. Although I DLC's also add a little to the game and make up for whats missing in the main game, I would suggest buying them all whilst on sale.

Overall: 7/10
Edit: Here's a link to a guide made by some1 who reviews the different DLC's.

Going to be updating my review - as for if I recommend it or not: it's the same (not recommending this game whatsoever).

The last time I reviewed the game was at 600 hours, it's now been around a year or so since then and I basically have 800 hours - I discussed previously how there is a lack of content and that mods are required; this still holds up true. In the current state of the game, there's no incentive to 'survive' on their survival gamemode or even build anything on creative because you're only building for the "fun of it" - note that I quoted this because it's not really all that fun anymore. Every time I recently try to play the game as an attempt to find some enjoyment out of it, I just end up quitting because there's nothing fun to do - even with mods it's now insanely boring.

I don't see the game recovering unless the developers stick their heads out of their asses and stop releasing low quality 'DLC' because that's the issue - people try to defend them saying that "it's only $3" or "game additions are free" however when it's been going on for so long, it feels more like a smack in the face for the older fanbase than aesthetic content and sub-par free content at the side of it - these individuals miss the point that they've been doing this for years without any significant update; I'd go as far to say that the warfare updates weren't really all that impressive since they didn't add anything to supplement the new weapon system and all the additional content.

Honestly; save your money (even if there's a sale) and look into something that has enough content to satisfy you long term because with the current state of the company and the game, there's no passion it seems or any incentive to give people what they want for content. From this point on I won't be playing this game again unless someone else takes over or I find a better game that is a derivative of what this was supposed to be.

Down the road this could be super cool game, but I have to say the learning curve is insane. Trying to start an of new game mode make it feels like I am learning a new game each time. If you ready to put in some hours to figure out how this game works then by all means spend the 20 dollars. But If you something more causal and wont take 10 hours to figure out to how to build a wind turbine or spend hours trying to figure out how to find your friends in multiplayer don't spend the money.

I love this game. I think it's the best sandbox game. However, there are a few things I want to be changed and added though.

1. Fix the hand drills.
To drill for ores without a ship, you use a hand drill. To pick up drilled ores, you need to press F repeatedly. Ores sometimes don't spawn on your crosshair and roll around, requiring you to chase them. This is annoying, and ship drills simply put the ore into your inventory automatically. 

2. Add explosions to damaged blocks.
This is a feature I want added. Say your reactor is damaged, and you have to repair it or evacuate before it explodes. This could happen for other blocks such as batteries, and This would add a fun gameplay experience that you could easily disable in settings.

Overall, an amazing game that keeps getting better over time.

OLD REVIEW BELOW: 

You may look at the thumbs down and think I don't like this game but in reality I love this game, I often lose hours of the day designing, building and testing space ships but it so hard to recommend this game.


First off the bugs: this game has more bugs than a spider web over a pile rotten meat... I'm looking at you pistons...

Second: Currupt save files, I lost a large space station and moon base because of this and going through some other reviews this isn't unique to me

Third: There is this weird issue with connectors where if you leave you ship connected to a station or larger ship it will have a seisure and won't stop unless you somehow get inside and disconnect (which by the way will more often than not cause damage to one, if not both ships) or reload the save

Forth: Planets eat proformance, you spawn a planet and goodbye framerate and that brings me to...

Fifth: Random Framerate drops and freezing, you can understand why this would make me mad.

Sixth: Crashes... no need to explain why this make me mad.

There is more but you get the picture and now let me tell you why I love this game

One: SPACESHIPS! I CAN BUILD SPACESHIPS OF MY OWN DESIGN

Two: The modding community of this game is amazing, more often than not I will find exactly what I need to build that oh so perfect ship

Three: Creative mode offers a lot of options for building your perfect ship and you can take that design and make it in survival using a projector

In summary I would give this game a 6/10 It's good and has potential but with the garbage multiplayer and the before mention bugs I can't recommend this game until those issues are fixed

I did not realise that i had not left a space engineers review, wowza. I honestly can't begin to describe the value I get out of this game. If you have a bunch of friends who like tinkering, building and trolling then you really don't have much chance of finding a better game to play together. I have well over 2000 hours i believe and I am itching to get my hands on the next major update. Most of this time was solo or closed server 2-4 player co-op with carefully selected mods and AI enemies added from the workshop, but the vanilla game can be so good now that i have started hopping on the public servers and that is getting so much better with the incoming Automotons DLC.

There is just something about the core gameplay loop here that is immensely satisfying. Building stuff that works together and relays information, items or services between everything... Bases, outposts, vehicles, industrial rigs, mines, satellites, ships of all types and sizes and roles. It's all here and if you can imagine a way they should work together, you can probably do it.

It has its quirks, but the community and the modding scene is excellent and I will continue to come back to play this excellent game again and again... and again... and again.

My only problem with this game can be summed up with one word, "Empty." To be fair this is a massive game and is basically Minecraft, in space. You can build some amazing things. If you decide to play this game alone, however, it just turns into an art program. You can make stuff but that's pretty much it. There is minimal life on planets and it's pretty much just vegetation that has no purpose aside from aesthetics.  This game has a lot of potential and is very beautiful, but it needs some non-player life added to it in a major way. Multiplayer is great, but if I want to set off on my own in single player it gets dull really quickly. I think if I had alien races to talk to, wildlife to kill, and some settlements to explore this would turn into a very awesome game.

Hello, gamers, look at my hours played, now back to the game, now back to the screenshots. Sadly, you may not own this game yet, but if you stopped playing that other game and started playing Space Engineers, you could have screenshots like that too. Look down at your starting planet, back up, where are you? You're on an asteroid in a rocket you built by hand and can now build in zero-g. What's in your hand, back at me. I have it, it's a blueprint from the workshop to build that ship from that scifi show you love. Look again, that blueprint is now reality from your home-made welder array using resources from your massive space mining operation. Anything is possible when you place Space Engineers. I'm on a planet.

Space Engineers is an exceptional game that offers a unique and captivating experience that combines elements of survival, crafting, and space exploration. The game is set in a vast, open universe, where players can build and customize their own spaceships, space stations, and even entire planets.

The graphics in Space Engineers are absolutely stunning, with incredible attention to detail and realism. The game features a vast range of environments, from the vast emptiness of space to the barren landscapes of alien planets, all of which are beautifully rendered.

One of the most impressive aspects of Space Engineers is the sheer scale of the game. The universe is massive, and there is an incredible amount of freedom and flexibility in how you choose to explore and build within it. The game encourages creativity, and the possibilities for building and designing are virtually limitless.

Another standout feature of Space Engineers is its attention to detail. The game's physics engine is incredibly realistic, allowing players to build and operate their spaceships and stations with a high degree of accuracy and precision. This level of realism adds to the overall sense of immersion and makes the game incredibly rewarding to play.

Finally, the game has a thriving community of players, modders, and developers, which ensures that there is always new content and features being added to the game. Whether you are a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the game, there is always something new to discover and explore.

Overall, Space Engineers is an outstanding game that offers a unique and engaging experience for players who are interested in space exploration, engineering, and creativity. With its breathtaking graphics, attention to detail, and vast scope, it is a game that is sure to capture the imagination and provide hours of entertainment.

I really like space engineers. It’s a great sandbox and survival game! I really like the base game, but I just have a couple issues about the game's dlc and updates. In the past, Keen would release dlcs as their updates which I don't really agree with but it seems like with the past few dlc AND updates, Keen is really turning it around where now they release both free updates and dlc which I think is a good model. An example would be the free update called 'Most Wanted'. But anyway I WOULD recommend this game to everyone who enjoys creativity!

Where do I even start?

The game is probably my favorite game of all time. It may really only be about building space ships with not much else to do, but the shear amount of possibilities when it comes to designing ships and functioning systems really outmatches the depth of any other sandbox game. Some of you reading this review might have already tried space engineers and maybe you played with a friend or you built a simple brick with some thrusters. I would highly encourage you to look closer at what this game can offer. Go to the workshop and download some cool builds... you will soon be inspired as you realize how many options there really are. You can build replica ships and vehicles from other franchises like Star Wars or Star Citizen, you can design an entire fleet or faction of ships, you can build an effective PvP ship, and you can build the dream exploration vehicle that you've always wanted to live on. 

The gameplay loop is so satisfying when you finally complete a project that you put time and effort into and can fully enjoy your work by showing it off to your friends or building it on a multiplayer server. You do need to be creative and to enjoy the game to its fullest you have to build things like they would be built in real life. This means that while you might not necessarily need airlocks, crew accommodations, or exposed windows in the game, building them will make you feel more immersed in the world and your ship will come to life. This also means designing ships with a specific function. Don't design the end-all-be-all ship that does everything. Specialization is key to immersion. If you're playing survival, challenge yourself with some mods that add hunger or thirst, more dangerous PvE encounters, or limit your abilities such as jetpack move speed or no atmospheric thrusters. 

TLDR: If you've put 10-25 hours in this game and found yourself not sure what to do next, go check out the workshop and get some inspiration for a build. Don't get discouraged when your ship isn't workshop standard, and don't compare your progress to other people's. Build more and more and you will get better!

After putting nearly 600 hours into this game, its pretty safe to say that I really enjoy it. It has an amazing modding community that have made some seriously good mods, but the game is good fun in a completely vanilla state as well. (If you're looking for mods to add, I would recommend Build Vision, Sneaky Sounds, and AQD's quality of life mods to start)

The DLC's add a good amount to the game, but any blocks added with the DLC's that added some new functionality are included in the base game without the need to purchase additional content. With that said, I do find it rather difficult to complete a build without any DLC blocks.

Space Engineers is an incredible survival/space experience. It's scale make it life-like, with giant planets and a totally destructible environment. It's like a giant build-your-own adventure puzzle. Space Engineers doesn't overwhelm you with thousands of different blocks, instead giving you just enough tools to concoct your very own warship, space station, or Mars rover. My first week playing this game, I ended up with a 47-hour playtime. This is a survival game that allows you the freedom to focus on what YOU want to make, rather than forcing you to chop trees, plant crops, drink water, etc before doing anything.

Pros:
+You can do anything you want, so long as you can build it.
+Scale makes multiplayer a treat, with enough room/time to prepare yourself before the bad guys show up
+The cheapest way to get a space ship from Star Citizen
+Shockingly stable for a game with endless voxels
+Incredibly useful tutorial that's ends up being pretty damn fun
+Awesome workshop asset/mod support. KEEN Discord is SUPER helpful

Cons:
-Occasional rendering issue on first login (Dude Where's my Cave?)
-Give us more decorative blocks!
-Can become a little bit of a menu-sim bouncing between ship inventories and builds
-Not a fan of the UI for Comms/GPS/Inventory
-The Space Engineers universe is ready for an optimized sequel
Could use more survival systems like food or water, otherwise gud

A game about building stuff, in space and on planets. stuff that moves, stuff that blows up, and stuff that seems to be blessed by some kind of malicious spiritual entity. An at times buggy, Clangy mess of a game, but a game well worth its price tag.

You can go the survival route and strip-mine planets and asteroids for their resources, or maybe you just wanna build stuff with creative mode/tools. Challenge yourself (and the aging physics engine); build bigger, more complex things. Exploit the physics to make Clang drives that move your ship with otherworldly forces, or just make the biggest gun you can to blow stuff up with. However you like to build, you can do so in single or multiplayer, and the modding community and downloadable Workshop content are fantastic. 

It does have a bit of a learning curve, but mostly just about advanced controls and such. The in-game tutorials and helper should give you a good start, and there are some good Youtubers like Splitsie to fill in the rest with their tutorial videos.

As of writing this review (pre-Automaton update) there is very little to this game except for the building system itself. There are no other engineers floating around space with you on singleplayer, just empty ships and desolate space stations. The most you'll interact with AI opponents is the occasional tiny Space Pirate drone, but that can be fixed with mods that add oponents.

This plus the lack of any endgame goals, the lack of a solid progression system, and no actual characters to interact with means this is little more than a glorified 3D modelling software. However, it is indeed a very good glorified 3D modelling software.

Game is very good at what it's attempting to do. It can be demanding on the PC specs, but that's understandable considering what the game is capable of rendering. I love the seemingly infinite possibilities for ship design, the potential for world building, and the incredible variety of blocks and tools. The Steam workshop integration is seamless, the blueprint system (for saving designs) works extremely well, and the DLC policy of the devs sets the gold standard of ethical monetization. My only wish would be for more opportunities in multiplayer to collaborate against NPC enemies (and more NPC enemies in general). 

An aside for new players; the learning curve can be a little steep, but the systems are actually very intuitive. Once you learn a few basics on how the grid system, inventory management, and power works, everything else falls into place quite nicely. Also, find Iron ASAP by using an ore detector or holding out your personal drill: relying on rocks is quite painful.

Have [i]you[/i] ever wanted to see a fight between the USS Enterprise (NCC-1701) and a Venator-class Star Destroyer?

Have [i]you[/i] ever wanted to build your very own space battleship, and set out on a epic journey among the stars, fighting space pirates in epic battles?

Have [i]you[/i] ever desired to relive your childhood days of playing with lego, but with the inner workings of your very own starship?

Do [i]you[/i] like fun?

If the answer is yes to any of these questions, then Space Engineers is the game for you. Despite there being a pretty steep learning curve, the end result of your experimentation and discovery is a game where the goal is creativity, and the reward is your very own starship. 

10/10, recommended.

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This is one of my top ten games. It does have some flaws but overall a great game. Highly recommend anyone to give this game a shot but for those who need more reason then read on. 

Space Engineers is a sandbox type game somewhat like Minecraft and other big sandbox games. However for this game you will be building vehicles like space ships, planes, and ground vehicles (either tanks or mechs). Even with one thousand hours I still find my self building what ever is stuck in my head. For some, it is a way to build cool ships to battle each other and some just like to build. For me and my friends we are the latter, building some of the dumbest things and smashing them into each other with nuclear bombs (side note Nukes are modded not base game, workshop has a lot of cool stuff for this game.) With friends this game is truly a fever dream, expectantly when you play survival. Now for most, when they play survival they usually just have them and their friends get together and build stuff but... For me and my friends it is ALL, OUT, WAR. We do some rp (very surface level stuff just to give reasons to blow sh!t up) and wage wars against each other in factions. Some of the most fun I have had are in these moments where unique moments happen so often that I simple can't forget them. For example one moment I remember well was when I was at war with a bunch of my other friends, I was out numbered, hard, however I had easily the best warship in the server to a point where I was undefeated in space combat. At the time I had another friend that was interested in the server so I let him join my faction till he got used to the game. little did I know that the friends I was at war with had come up with a plan. They would do a two way assault, two of them that where suck on Mars would go to attack my planetary base there. The Other two would assault my orbital fortress over Mars. Since I had only one War ship and the friend on my side was very new at the game so I couldn't give him what was my Flag ship, I was forced to think of something. In my panic of trying to find out what to do after a hand full of minutes trying to think of what to do. There was an attack heading for my planetary base with no defenses but I had my Flag ship stationed on site to protect it. However they where already laying siege to my orbital fortress and it would take to long to get to it in time to defend the fortress and my planetary base at the same time. In a panic I sent my noob friend to use his first ship he had built to stall the ground attack. I would break for orbit and fight up there. My friend would engage with the ground force and do damage but not stop them and would get shot down. I was at the half way point to the fortress and had to stop and think of what to do. However It was to late, for the orbital attack had not only had the enemies taken the fortress but they where moving it (mindful it had not thrusters) They didn't run away with it, the fortress was actually falling. Now I had a different problem I had to deal with a Fortress as big if not bigger then my flag ship falling and crushing my planet base. Meanwhile I whole time was saying "FUCK,FUCK,FUCK,FUCK,FUCK" hoping that it would miss the base. I would fly my ship to intercept it in hopes of destroying it before it crushes anything important. It would miss all on it's own and the enemy ground force retreated since they had nothing good enough to destroy my flag ship. In this moment I was no longer the big bad of the server. 

Truly this Game thrives off of creativity and I could never have imaged such a moment like that happening between my and my friends. 9/10 game pls fix host connection advantage and improve engine if possibly.
