EPIC GAME SPACE BUILDING

After over 800 hours, I am still very divided on this game.

TLDR: Yes, I recommend the purchase, but beware if you are going to play dedicated multiplayer.

Pros:
====
1. The ability to goof around building cool stuff is endless and I've spent a good amount of time just trying to create interesting devices, ships, etc. - and for this alone it is worth the purchase. A little imagination goes a long way with this game.

2. They're a little slow with providing shapes for niche uses to meld older blocks together nicely, but they've been getting there with new updates.

3. Mod support is incredible and the mod community has made some awesome stuff for this game.

Cons:
=====
1. Sometimes the physics simulation just goes insane and something that should in theory be within the constraints of the engine goes berserk and destroys everything - this physics behaviour is kind of embraced by the community jokingly, but it genuinely is a shame it's so unpredictable. Some consider it a charm of the game, but I don't.

2. Dedicated multiplayer needs reworking. Optimization is awful when playing multiplayer and the server software is fairly unstable. The hardware requirements are a little odd and out of date with current hardware you're likely to be serving it from - which causes annoying things like focusing your server around a single hyper fast core, not multiple.
De-sync, grid glitching, slowdown, wonky physics, etc. are all usually prevalent whenever anything meaningful is occurring on a dedicated server (ship battles, large crashes, large mining operations, complicated conveyor networks, etc.).
Mods, 3rd party server apps and addons go a long way to helping to solve some of the issues, but they shouldn't be a go to after all this time.
We always end up hitting some kind of weird performance issue or cap after a certain amount of building with friends - and it's a real let down.

I could go on at more length with more points, but I consider these the mains do buy / don't buy points of interest.

Only had it 24 hours, but am addicted already.  Can't get enough of Space Engineers!

Update after a few years, in 2023:

OK, let me explain further, in terms of other space games out there.  As we all know, different games scratch different itches, so to speak.  Not all games can do all things.  SE, however, does a very good job of holding its own within the current (2023) panoply of space simulation games.  The following is a direct comparison (my opinions of course) of SE and other multiplayer space games out there today:

SE vs Elite and Star Citizen
- Elite is much bigger, overall, but you cannot build your own ships or bases.  You can't do much except "engineer" your own ship, giving its systems a boost or two of improvement.  Star Citizen is quite a bit smaller, but still a little larger than SE.
- SE has "jump" FTL drives, to move you around the given solar system more quickly, once you have found the right materials to build and power them.  FTL travel is therefore a mid-game capability.  In Elite, you get FTL travel from the beginning, but it's pretty limited in distance.  In Star Citizen, it can depend on what ships you buy to get started with.
- SE's ships, especially when using the blocks provided by the DLCs, can look quite nice, sometimes even holding their own against the in-game ships of Elite.  And, SE lets you design and inhabit the interiors, which you can't do in Elite.  I think some SE designs even hold their own compared to Star Citizen, which of course allows you to go inside and toot around, go to sleep, etc.
- SE NPCs are pretty much invisible.  Trading, contracts, etc. are all done by terminal.  Enemy ships and drones are pilotless.  If you see another character, they're a real person.  The reason you see them is only because you set up your SE server to allow other players of a certain type (friends, etc.).  It's not an MMO.  Of course, in Elite and SC, there are lots of NPCs to interact with.
- SE is moddable.  Planets, ship designs, base designs, planetary improvements, quality of life improvements...etc.  In Star Citizen (and Elite) pretty much everything you see is provided by the developers, and players don't build almost anything.

SE vs. Empyrion
I think SE's closest rival is Empyrion.  Both have resource acquisition and building at the heart of the gameplay.  Both have large and small grid sizes.  However:
- Empyrion has interactible NPCs of various factions.  SE also has factions, but you don't ever actually see them, so they always feel a little theoretical.  Hey, there goes another Faction X ship.  OK, they're gone.
- Empyrion's surface vessels are hovercraft, while SE focuses on rovers.  To me, the rovers are more fun.
- Empyrion planets seem loaded with a lot more flora and fauna, but a lot of it repeats on multiple planets, like those protein-rich "hot dog" plants.  
- Speaking of those plants, Empyrion's survival system also includes hunger, so you have to eat and drink, in addition to breathing and staying healthy.  You can also be poisoned.  So, there is a fairly extensive food prep and storage crafting system in Emp. that does not exist in SE.
- Both games have developer-provided scenarios to play, and Empyrion has a storyline that is fed to you by an "AI" via your HUD and data pad.  SE sort of does this in tutorial scenarios and maybe elsewhere.
- Both games have workshop designs for bases, large and small starships, ground vehicles, etc. where players can upload and share their creations and mods.
- Both games are moddable.
- Empyrion has oceans and lakes, while SE planets don't have these unless modded.

ALL games have ground and in-space combat.  Which (as noted in a recent article) is a bit too bad, given that peaceful exploration is a major draw for such games.  So...play as you want; you can in SE (and possibly also Empyrion) turn off hostiles / animal spawns and just chill out on your own planet, building bases and such.

ALL games have some form of mining / resource extraction.  I find SE's the most satisfying.  Mining the asteroids by hand is a lot of fun.  Building mining ships makes it faster.  Building auto-miners for planetary resources is also an awesome way to go.

ALL games have exploration.  In the case of Elite, going deep into the galaxy is the name of the game.  In Star Citizen, it's finding special details left by the developers.  In SE, you can find relatively nice spots on various planets and moons (roughly a dozen, modeled after our solar system) and setup homes / bases / mines on each, and perfect your ship designs.  Or face off against other players if you like the combat aspects.  Recent DLCs have enhanced the weapon types and ship designs to look more "military."  In SE, roleplaying is definitely encouraged.

Conclusion:  SE is still doing a great job in 2023.

Like....    I don't need to be able to see this hot mess of control panels and connectors and settings and formattings before you're ready to show me how to use them.  Make all that stuff hidden before its ready to be introduced so you don't mental-flashbang your newbies.

And if this is a sandbox game, make sure you specify that the tutorial missions are instanced so I don't spend an hour collecting every material I can get my hands on just for you to take it away from me when my ship has a scripted cutscene death in the open world sandbox game, effectively wasting all the time I spent collecting those materials immediately after being instructed on how to collect materials.

For real.  The game is like...  "Here's the farming tool.  Here's how to farm.  Here's a whole facility with spare stuff to salvage.  And your new ship has a lot of storage too!" ...  "P.S.Y.C.H! XD  Your ship died in a cutscene and all that farming was for nothing L.o.L.z XDXDXD." 


TL;DR:  Amazing potential.  Great foundations.  Needs a better tutorial and more polish.   Definitely gonna be worth the money, but wait for release.

This game is fun if you can look past the CONSTANT lag, rubberbanding, crashing, broken meta for ship fighting that hasn't changed since release, Servers modded down so much you need to download another games worth of data to join, and why not find out the rest for yourself? But no don't. There's many other sandbox survivals out there that are properly optimized. This sad excuse of stability is dead to me. Whats more the devs are hostile and defensive regarding ANY critiques turning on the fans that gave them jobs in the first place (I was once one of them). Get off your high horses and Un'fuq your game devs.

Edit: Still no update & no road map to find a planned update

Probably one of the best games I've played purely because of the creative freedom you're given. Spaceships, drones, bases, missiles, heck even gravity-driven warp rings. Paired with the amazing workshop creations and scripts, the limit really is your imagination.

This game, though fun, is full of bugs. It is supported more by the community than the developers. 
You have a unique ability to create whatever vehicles (wheeled, flying, small or large) you can dream of, but then you, don't. Blocks, such as pistons, rotors, hinges, wheels have a mind of their own. One day your ship is air tight. The next, you are tearing it apart trying to find the "leak". Impact damage to grids is inconsistent. You can touch down and your ship may explode. Other times you can crash face first into an asteroid with minimal damage. On board your ship, things should not float around at 1g, or any gravity rating over zero. This game can be so much fun while be the worst game ever. You can spend enormous quantities of resources and time building something very cool, only to rage-quit. This game has, had the potential of being something so much more than what it actually is.
